PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Boswell (from 2,124 citizens), and Senator Kernot (from 180 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes the increase in the Pension age for women from 60 to 65.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate take action to reverse this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia asks that the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993 be amended with the application of common principles. To ensure that all parents with dependent children are treated equally, allowing maximum freedom of choice in child rearing.
These Acts need to be amended to take account of:

PETITION.PARA: 1.the fact that 60% of married women in the workforce who have children, would prefer to stay at home and mind their children, but for economic reasons can't afford to (Institute of Family Studies Survey).
2.the failure to provide for equitable choice for women and families in allowing parents the maximum right to choose the most appropriate form of care for their children.
3.that there be recognition of a parent at home as a formal occupation reflecting its economic value and worth to society.
4.the need for equal payment of any subsidies and allowances for the care of children, paid directly to the parent.
5.the recognition that a family with more than one child incurs extra expenses.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request that the Senate amend the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993.

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 October, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was speaking in this debate last night I was considering several of the objections raised by the opposition senators on the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration who were party to the dissenting report on the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 . I was commenting on the setting up of a dual bureaucracy and I pointed out that there would now be a separate bureaucracy to manage the indigenous land fund in addition to the one that already exists under ATSIC. I had made several comments about unnecessary administrative duplication and waste at a time when all available money should be used to improve the appalling living conditions of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

PARA.TAB: The coalition senators on that committee also had very real concerns about the self-funding nature of the very large amount of money that has been put into the land fund. It is necessary that over the 10 years that this fund will operate the economic base of the fund be maintained.

Senator Chris Evans last night commented on the entrepreneurial nature of the funding proposal put forward by the Northern Land Council in conjunction with J. P. Morgan. Senator Evans should realise that it is necessary for this large amount of money to be managed properly to achieve higher returns other than by just investing in land so that there is less risk on the investment of the fund's capital. Land alone can be a risky investment and land values in Australia go up and down over time just like any other investments. People cannot maintain the economic base of this investment simply by investing in land.

Over the long term, the amounts available for land acquisition and management will be considerably less if the government does not take considered action to consolidate the funding base. It is all very well for Senator Chris Evans to denigrate what he calls entrepreneurial action but, unless some action like that is taken, the economic base of the fund will simply be eroded. There must be a range of options considered to ensure that the land fund is managed responsibly. If it is not the J. P. Morgan proposals, which were put forward in conjunction with the Northern Land Council, there must be another range of options put forward. That is what the coalition wants to see.

We have real concerns with this legislation, and those concerns have been expressed by my colleagues who spoke earlier in this debate. We have not been reassured by the hope-for-the-best attitude expressed by the government. It has dismissed our concerns by adopting the attitude of passing the legislation and then seeing what happens. We have already seen that with the native title legislation. That was passed in a flurry of enthusiasm and only now, and I believe for the next 10 years, will the real ramifications of this legislation become apparent. We do not want to see the same long-term effects happen with the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. There are too many generalities and too many unspoken assumptions, and there is too much emphasis on the words `may' and `might'.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples have a genuine expectation that this legislation will make their lives better. Coalition senators have advanced reasons why there is a very real fear that this may not happen under the present clauses and the way they will operate. We will move amendments to ensure that the supposed spirit of the legislation will be carried through in fact, if that is possible.

No-one denies that land is of fundamental importance to the Aboriginal people, and many government senators have cast aspersions on the feelings of coalition senators, saying that we simply do not understand this. I can assure them that we do. But any legislation to cover that importance of land to the Aboriginal people and their special relationship with the land must be drafted in such terms as can achieve the expression of that aim. We are not satisfied that this legislation is going to move on and do that.

Senator Forshaw should note that there has not been one mention in my remarks of any country but Australia. He seemed to think that we were thinking of many countries but Australia in our consideration of this legislation. I care about this country and I care about the welfare, in the truest sense of the word, of all Australian citizens. In its present form, the land fund bill cannot provide for the land aspiration of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. I will be participating in the committee stage of this bill to advocate amendments put forward by the coalition.

As a Victorian, I am obviously not as intimately concerned with the provisions of this bill as perhaps are senators from Western Australia or the Northern Territory. But close to my home, at Lake Condah, I have seen the operation of land which was transferred to Aboriginal people early in the 1980s with no real thought as to the long-term economic consequences. I think many of the Aboriginal people in south-west Victoria would be the first to admit that the transfer of land to them by the government has not improved their economic wellbeing to the point where they would be happy with it, and not sufficient thought was put into the drafting and the preparation of the legislation which gave them that land to enable them to manage it properly.

The very real fear that I have with this legislation is that, because it has not been drafted properly and because not sufficient thought has been given to the long-term consequences of this legislation, ultimately it will not work to the true benefit of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. It is all very well for the government to feel that it has the interests of those people at heart but, unless a lot more thought is put into the way this legislation is drafted and the exact wording of the clauses, this will not happen; and Aboriginal people will be cheated of what they see as their highest aspirations towards the ownership and the management of land. The coalition feels that it has a responsible duty to point out the shortcomings of the government legislation, and that is the reason why we will be continuing to move amendments during the committee stage of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 is a very important piece of legislation that addresses the need for all Australians to recognise the import of the Mabo decision of the High Court of Australia that our forebears, in their settlement of this land over 200 years ago, did not come to an unoccupied land, a land which in Latin we term terra nullius—no land—but came to a land in which there were legitimate ownership rights for the indigenous Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: The Mabo decision determined that there exists in this country a concept of native title and that that native title has been extinguished only when a government has issued freehold title or a lease. Those areas of Australia for which there has not been such an issue of title, an act of government, remain able to be claimed as native title.

It happens to be the case that in the last 200 years the majority of Australian land and the most economic parts of it have been alienated. Title is issued by government and native title is extinguished. It cannot be claimed. Therefore, to complete the Australian parliament's response to the import of this landmark decision of the High Court, it is appropriate for us to consider compensation and to consider justice.

For those Aboriginal Australians who cannot claim native title because it is extinguished, it is appropriate that the parliament consider a land acquisition fund provided with taxpayers' money so that a board can buy leasehold and freehold land and make it available to those Aboriginal people in Australia who are unable to exercise any claim under native title.

Those are the fundamentals of this legislation which, in its principles, is supported by every senator. As I understand it, I am the last senator, bar the minister in his summing up, to speak in this debate. I recognise that every senator who has spoken accepts the principle of just compensation and the principle which makes it possible for Aboriginal people of every kind in Australia to have access to land. There was a period earlier this year when there was such dissatisfaction within the opposition parties with the details of this bill, and with the original Mabo legislation that we debated for days last December—longer than any other bill in the history of the Senate—that they were saying they would oppose this legislation.

After more careful examination by my colleagues, I am glad to say that the principle at the foundation of this legislation has now been accepted by the Liberal and National parties, and the matters of contention are now only on the detail of provisions in this bill. Therefore, there will be a substantial committee stage debate and there will be a number of amendments moved by my colleagues. It will depend on the outcome of the debate on the detail as to whether the Liberal and National parties will be able to support the third reading of the bill.

I note that there has been no strong voice anywhere in Australia opposed to the principles of this land acquisition fund. The mining industry, the farming industry, and land owners generally, support the principles of this bill, so do the Aboriginal people themselves who have called for it, as do a number of interest groups such as the churches. I acknowledge that there has been no controversy in the community at large, but rather support for the principles of the bill. The details are another matter and we will come to them in the committee stage debate.

Generally, it should be understood that this bill provides, over a 10-year period, about $1 1/2 billion for the land fund. In each of those 10 years there will be a drawing down of about $45 million which is about double the amount that the taxpayer has made available in recent years through ATSIC's land acquisition program. This bill doubles the current rate of moneys available for land purchase for Aboriginal people and will eventually shift that money from ATSIC to a new ILC, a board of seven persons. As I have said, about $1,289 million will be put into the scheme over a 10-year period starting with $200 million this financial year. Most of that—some $800 million—will remain in the fund at the end of the 10 years and, at that point, only the interest on the capital deposit will be able to be spent year by year.

The board of seven members must include the chairperson of ATSIC and one other member of ATSIC. In all, out of the seven members, five must be Aboriginal. I accept that structure, but I would like to see an additional criterion that there be at least one person with explicit financial and land management experience included in the board. It is for the minister to appoint people and it would be very wise, whatever the fate of the amendment the opposition may move in due course, that that be the case.
The functions of the Indigenous Land Corporation, the ILC, will be to purchase land, to upgrade Aboriginal owned land, to manage land, and to set up national and regional land strategies.

I come to the three broad amendments that the opposition is proposing. The first is that we wish to have among the guidelines for the board an express weighing of the outcomes to be expected from the land that is to be purchased. We believe that the welfare needs and the economic capacity of the Aboriginal communities which have the land purchased for them should be enhanced and improved. It seems to me to be highly short-sighted if the government is trying to maintain that these land purchases should not address such a guideline.

I believe it would have been perfectly possible for the government to understand the goal of that first amendment—and I put it to Senator Gareth Evans in his summing up—and to say, `Of course, we understand the opposition's first amendment is not to change the notion of compensation which is at the heart of this legislation, but rather that, in the minds of the seven members of the board of the ILC, one of the guidelines for the purchasing of land will be to try to assess the priorities of land purchase so that they do improve the education, health and housing outcomes for Aboriginal communities, and improve their economic viability.'

The second broad amendment that the opposition is proposing is that there be accountability by the ILC for the way it puts in place the objectives set out in this legislation. We believe that that national land strategy should be so accountable to parliament that it is a disallowable instrument. We believe that there should be at least one board member who has business or financial skills and that the board in its strategy should be required to consult with the states, which of course have the major responsibility for the management of land in this country. I believe those are all perfectly reasonable improvements to this legislation that the government ought to genuinely consider.

The third, and the last, of the three broad amendments the opposition is putting is that priority of purchase of land be for those Aboriginal people who cannot claim native title under the Mabo legislation or under the generality of the High Court's native title determination. I believe it is in the spirit of the legislation that this land acquisition fund is primarily to exist to enable Aboriginal people to gain land who have not got access to native title because native title has been extinguished—or for whatever other reason.

I think it quite reasonable the we require the seven members of this board to take that priority into account. We believe that there should an exclusion of the possibility of native title on the land that is purchased through the ILC and that land subject to native title should not be purchased except under very exceptional circumstances.

I put it to the government at this final stage of the second reading debate that the government can win the Liberal and National parties' support for not just the second reading but the third reading of this legislation if the government genuinely understands the goals that we are seeking with regard to, firstly, an estimated outcome of improvement for the Aboriginal people for which the land is purchased; secondly, accountability; and, thirdly, a priority for land to be purchased that is not subject to native title.
I have not heard in this whole debate any substantial argument against these three broad amendments. I am aware, though, of an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald of two days ago which states:

The land fund then is a matter of justice, not welfare. Aborigines are entitled to welfare because of the continuing social and economic disadvantage they experience. They are entitled to the land fund as just compensation for past dispossession and dispersal from their land.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge that, and maybe Senator Evans will take a similar line with regard to the first of the opposition's broad package of amendments. I accept that the basis of this legislation is compensation. But why not, in the practical decision of determining the particularities of the compensation, have such health, education and housing criteria partly in mind or, as our amendment puts it, the economic viability of the community being improved, being enhanced, as a result of the practical decision about land? I concede that the superior principle here is compensation. We only ask that these other welfare and economic viability considerations be a part of the criteria in the particularities of deciding on land.

PARA.TAB: I can only urge that the government does understand the goals and does address our genuine concerns. This would be a change of heart on the government's part, because when we announced our position the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner, immediately, seemingly without any consideration of what we had said, slammed the opposition's position as lacking bona fides, as not being genuine and as being a stratagem to put up some barriers to the opposition's agreement to the detail of this legislation.

I, as a participant in the party room discussion on this matter, can only say to Senator Evans and the government that that is wrong. There is a genuine commitment by the Liberal and National parties to the fundamentals of this legislation, and there is a concern to have these three broad amendments genuinely considered by the government. Let them be considered on their merits—not dismissed in the way that was the initial response of the Prime Minister and the minister. Alexander Downer, on the day that we announced the package, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, we are happy to sit down with the Government and talk about the details of the drafting of the amendments.
I am disappointed Mr Keating has already rejected the amendments before seeing them.

Similarly, after the second reading debate, which is the stage we are at in the Senate, had concluded in the House of Representatives, a press statement released on 1 September by the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, my good friend and colleague Chris Gallus, stated:

. . . the Fund provides the greatest opportunity for dispossessed indigenous people across Australia to gain land. How can anyone not want to see the greatest degree of accountability to the Aboriginal people to ensure that their opportunity is not compromised by poor management or lack of guidance to the Board from the legislation?
The Coalition has sought to strengthen the accountability and expertise of the Board of the ILC so that the maximum available money is available for indigenous people to acquire land.
The Government has refused to discuss any of these amendments despite the fact that the Coalition supported the Land Fund Bill at the second reading.
Our amendments are genuinely intended and again I appeal to Senator Evans and the government to take them seriously, to argue them on their merits, and not to dismiss them out of hand.

PARA.TAB: In the last few minutes of this second reading contribution I wish to note that money alone does not bring the solution—I think we all acknowledge that. If there was time I would have quoted from an extensive article by historian John Hirst on page 25 of the Weekend Australian of 9 July where he puts forward four current fallacies, to all of which I am sympathetic. I think it is an essential article that needs to be read by all of us involved with Aboriginal affairs.

I conclude by referring to two fundamental issues that I addressed at the beginning of my speech: one is the issue of just compensation and the other is the important right of land ownership. In Australia—not least in the Menzies era of the 1950s and 1960s, not least in the Liberal and National Parties, and now common on all sides of politics—we have urged home ownership. We have urged Australians to have a stake in this country by owning part of the land. It was a constant goal of Australian governments through the 1950s and the 1960s—and remains quite bipartisan now—that all Australians ought to have the objective of owning their own home; of having a capital asset which is their security, but is also a stake in the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good idea.

—I agree with Senator Panizza that we should all own some land. I put it to any members of the Australian public who are still wavering that this is a quality that ought to be taken up by all Australians, including all Aboriginal Australians. Through this legislation there needs to be made available that same stake in the country, that same home ownership. I speak with a degree of irony because of course the indigenous people originally owned the whole of this country.

PARA.TAB: The second fundamental is compensation. It is in the constitutions of all parties in this place that there should be just compensation, and that is what we are fundamentally addressing in this legislation. I support the second reading of the bill. I hope that the government will give genuine consideration to the amendments that we will move in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their support for the second reading of the bill, even if a number of them have expressed a determination to gut and fillet it in the committee stage.
—Don't thank them for that.

—So far so good, as the person said jumping out of the 18th floor window. The bill before the Senate today represents an important historic step in relations between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. It is the second stage of the government's broad response to the Mabo decision, and a very important element indeed in that response.

PARA.TAB: As so many people have noted, the bill addresses indigenous dispossession by providing $1.5 billion over 10 years to set up a self-sustaining fund to provide land for economic, environmental, social and cultural benefits. The government is very conscious of the need for that land so granted and vested to be managed in an effective manner. The corporation that is proposed to be established to administer all this will therefore carry out the equally important function of promoting and supporting the sustainable management of indigenous held land.

I thank those senators from the government ranks who took part in the debate—Senator Coates, Senator Cooney, Senator Forshaw and Senator Chris Evans—and who made their normal constructive and thoughtful contributions. As to the Democrats, I thank Senator Kernot and Senator Woodley for their very thoughtful contributions. I notice that Senator Woodley in particular brought home just how recent some of the instances of dispossession have been. Senator Kernot expressed her party's concerns about the sustainability of the fund. That is an area where we do need to make sure we get it right and we will no doubt be discussing that in more detail in the committee stage.

As far as the Greens are concerned, I thought Senator Chamarette's speech was a rather unduly harsh judgment on the bill, particularly her criticisms of the level of funding. But at least it can be said that the Greens have some genuine appreciation of what the bill is about in terms of the significance to be attached to land ownership for its own sake.

As far as the opposition is concerned—although we noticed some mellowing of the opposition position in the course of this debate, no doubt reflecting the dilemma that is being experienced, having moved from outright opposition previously expressed to the present position of support with significant amendments—the dilemma seems to be that, as so often with the opposition, we have a bit of a mixture of those who are more thoughtfully and constructively inclined on these issues and those who are less so. We have a bit of a mixture of the redneck `Why are you throwing more money away?' kind of response from some quarters, but a degree of social concern no doubt genuinely held from others on the opposition benches. I acknowledge the degree of that concern that has been expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is generous!

—I have to say that in nearly all of the opposition comments, however—there have been some exceptions; I have not heard all the speakers, but Senator Teague may well be one of the exceptions—there has been still a significant lack of understanding of what we are actually dealing with in this bill: that is, the significance of land as compensation for the dispossession that has been suffered by so many.

PARA.TAB: Senator Knowles, for example, made a very impassioned speech on health, education and issues of that kind. They are acutely important issues which the government frankly acknowledges need to be systematically and comprehensively addressed, but they are not what this bill is about. We acknowledge the problems that face indigenous people entitled to welfare. More needs to be done in the areas of indigenous health, housing, education and employment. However, programs directly relating to these areas and to improving them are already in place.

While gains have been made, we recognise that there is still a long way to go; but we are doing our best to address them. What we do say is that it is not only through welfare programs that these issues can be addressed, but we have to get to the root cause of the poverty and disadvantage of indigenous people. That continues to be, to a very significant extent, their sense of dispossession and their resulting marginalisation from the social, cultural and economic life of this country. The main purpose of this bill continues to be to address that need—to return land in some reasonable way to indigenous people and, through that, give them access to the social, the cultural, the economic and the psychological support base that is necessary for true self-determination. What we say is that without land and without the justice that is associated with vesting some land back in indigenous people, any improvements in the socioeconomic status of indigenous people will be costly and extremely limited—as well as still having a whiff of paternalism about them. So what we say, and say again and again, is that to provide the means by which indigenous people can acquire land is not just more of the same, as is being sought from other sources, but is providing something much more fundamental: it is providing justice. The editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald on 17 October put it very well when it said:

SPEECH.PARA: To demand, as the Opposition does, that land purchased under the new fund be used to improve Aboriginal welfare is to confuse these two principles—
of welfare and justice. It continues:
It is also to deny that Aborigines regard their acquisition of land as a good thing in itself.

I know that is not a position shared by all opposition members who have spoken, but it is a recurring theme and it is one that goes to the heart of what this bill is about. We will obviously need to debate it further before this bill is concluded.

PARA.TAB: In terms of further debate on the bill, it is proposed that we defer the committee stage until this afternoon to enable some more discussions to take place between the parties to see if we can find some common ground on some of these matters.

I want to describe in outline what the government's approach will be to the committee stage. There are some policy issues which are absolutely at the heart of the bill as it is constructed and on which we simply cannot accommodate amendments. We will identify those as we go through the bill. Equally, on the financial provisions—except perhaps at the margin; we will need to debate that further—we can, for fiscal responsibility reasons, make no significant changes to the legislation in that respect. That has to be well understood, particularly by the Greens, who have been advocating massive increases in expenditure in addition to that which is proposed.

However, there is a third category of possible amendments: those which do not go to the heart of the policy of the bill or to the heart of the financial arrangements of the bill but which are aimed at various ways of improving the bill, making it work better and better reflect the aspirations which, at the end of the day, it may be we all share. There are some amendments on the opposition's list which might conceivable fall into that category. There are certainly some on the Greens' list which fall into that category. And there are some amendments on the Democrats' list which, on the face of it, have the potential for some reasonable discussion of that kind.

Our approach is simply to respond reasonably and persuasively, I hope, to every amendment that anyone wants to bring forward. Frankly, while there is no room for manoeuvre on basic policy positions, nor on basic financial issues, there may be some room for discussion and amendment in that residual area. We could adopt a very hard-nosed approach to this and say, `Go jump in the lake. See you in the House of Representatives and then see you back here in three months time.' That is a course not without its attractions, given the obvious support that this particular legislation has in the community at large.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel a double dissolution coming on.
—We are very conscious that there is a very strong measure of political support in the community for this legislation. I think—
—You've put a woman last on your ticket; I don't suppose you're too worried about it.
—We've got a woman on top of the ticket.

—Trust Senator Vanstone, when we are engaged in a high level of statesmanship and reasonableness, to descend into crude and vulgar politics. We will make a statesperson of her one of these days but it does not look as though it will be this morning.

PARA.TAB: I repeat: we will approach the committee stage in a constructive frame of mind. It might help to accelerate that committee stage if we allow ourselves two or three hours to focus on some room for possible agreement of this kind. It certainly might help us get through the morass of some 120 or 130 amendments a little faster than might otherwise be the case. That would be a blessed relief to the clerks, if nobody else.

I conclude by quoting again from what really was an excellent editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald. It states very nicely some themes that run through the government's response. The final paragraph says:

SPEECH.PARA: Some Aborigines will feel short-changed by the amount of money available to the fund. Others will say the legislation is incomplete because it does not broach sovereignty. And many Aborigines know they will continue to live in need even after the fund comes into operation. In short, of course there is a long list of amendments to the legislation that could be made. . . But that's not the point. A land fund doesn't preclude future negotiations over property rights or Aboriginal living standards. What the Greens and the Democrats have to ask—
and what the opposition should ask as well—

is whether the government's legislation represents a prudent response to Mabo in present circumstances. It does, and it deserves to be passed without the unseemly tug-of-war that was fought over Native Title.
I commend those remarks to the Senate, just as I commend the bill as a whole to the Senate for the second reading vote.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the bill in the committee of the whole be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day.
Debate resumed from 18 October, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the second reading debate on the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994 was adjourned last night I had just mentioned that the bill had been sent for consideration by a Senate committee. During the course of that consideration a number of important issues were brought before the committee by people who sent in submissions. Amongst those issues were the extent to which Australia Post is deregulated, price determination of postal services and the maintenance of competitive neutrality, the balance between community service obligations and profit making within the postal system, and the boundary of reserved postal services, together with the relationship between document exchanges in Australia Post. It was with those particular issues in mind that the report of the committee was brought before the Senate. Also, many other very interesting matters were brought forward by those people who gave evidence before the committee.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the extent to which Australia Post is deregulated, in submissions before the committee and in evidence to the committee, industry representatives called for even greater competition by broadening the scope of the bill and reducing the range of reserved postal services. In response to this matter Australia Post and the Communications Workers Union cautioned that any recommendations being made to extend the legislation should be monitored so that the recommendations did not go past the government's intention.

Industry representatives also raised concerns regarding the optimal point of interconnection between private mail organisations and the postal services market. It was pointed out to the committee that the bill exposed interstate line haul steps to competition but not the intrastate line haul or distribution. Mayne Nickless in particular viewed the intrastate work as the component of total costs most likely to benefit from competition and argued, therefore, that this segment be opened to competition. Naturally enough, Australia Post representatives recommended that intrastate line haul not be opened to competition in order to maintain clarity and simplicity in the Australia Post price structure.

With regard to the price determination of postal services and the maintenance of competitive neutrality, industry emphasised the need to ensure that Australia Post services which were exposed to competition did not accrue any ongoing advantage via cross-subsidies from the remaining protected services. Mayne Nickless also submitted to us at the hearing that Australia Post was entering the competitive market with an entrenched advantage due to some very strong legislative rights.

I guess one of the most debated areas is the balance between community service obligations and profit making within the postal system. As Senator Bolkus said in his second reading speech in clarifying the government's position, the government's ongoing support of community service obligations was one of its key arguments in restricting the level of competition to which Australia Post is exposed. In order to maintain uniform pricing and universal access to postal services, the government reaffirmed its commitment to maintaining many of Australia Post's activities as a reserved service. Even those of us on this side of the chamber are well aware of those community service obligations. As a matter of fact, I am one of the recipients of that community service obligation in that I, too, have roadside delivery of my mail at home and I am aware of Australia Post's community service obligation to people throughout Australia. So the balance between community service obligations and profit making within the postal system is an issue which must be looked at very carefully.

TALK.START.PARA: —You sound like a wet.

—Senator Schacht can draw his own conclusions. In talking about profit making within the postal system, Australia Post seems to be doing very well at present. Maintaining that balance between those community service obligations and profit making within the department is something that we certainly took into consideration.

PARA.TAB: Most industry groups expressed concern that the proposed legislation failed to clarify the boundaries of reserved postal services. In particular, we had evidence from Streetfile—which, I might say, came under some concerted attack by government members of the committee. But even Streetfile, in its submission to the committee, acknowledged that it was very much aware of Australia Post's community service obligations to deliver a letter and it works within that component of Australia Post's business.
Senator Chapman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that none of them are here but I guess that is because their position is not strong enough to defend. Streetfile submitted that there is an arbitrary inconsistency within the bill with regard to the packaging of magazines, books and catalogues. According to Streetfile, the bill allows private mail organisations to deliver magazines and books in opaque packages but not catalogues or leaflets, which must be sent in transparent packaging. Streetfile was at pains to tell us that it felt that that was an inconsistency in the bill.

PARA.TAB: Of even more importance is the relationship between document exchanges and Australia Post. I do not know whether I have generated some interest from Senator Murphy here but I am pleased to see that he is here, as he was part of that committee. In general, industry groups welcomed the government's recognition of the services provided by document exchanges—something which had not been officially recognised in the past. However, they were opposed to the provision which prevents couriers acting as third parties transporting material between document exchanges and client companies. Clause 11 of the bill allows couriers to perform such a role only when they are delivering to an Australia Post office.

We heard evidence from Ausdoc, the major document exchange in Australia. It is a company which employs some 560 people and uses a significant number of subcontractors. Ausdoc was concerned that document exchange business also includes courier business, which comprises more than 50 per cent of its business operations. Ausdoc, for the record, has in excess of 15,000 document exchange members and operates more than 400 exchanges throughout Australia, including many in country and remote areas.

When asked by some members of the committee how the company fulfils any community obligations at all, Ausdoc's representatives said that the company serves something like 90 per cent of the population. It does not include a lot of very small, remote and more sparsely populated areas, but the document exchange was not set up for that purpose. It was designed to be a speedy, daily service—a same day service for city businesses in many instances—and always gave a very prompt and secure service.

Originally, when lawyers, accountants, insurance companies and so on used Ausdoc, it did not carry many documents. Obviously the volume of business and the number of documents that it had to carry are directly related to the number of members of the exchanges, and those numbers have increased dramatically. Years ago, when the exchanges first started, it was very easy for a staff member to go to the exchange to pick up a few envelopes or documents and take them back to the office. However, now with the big increase in the use of document exchanges, often the volume of documents is too much for a person to carry, so for those reasons bundles of documents are carried by courier to the various businesses. Talking about the document exchanges and using post offices, most only use a DX number anyway, so it will involve extra work and costs for businesses to use document exchanges if this bill passes as it is currently set out.

Another area about which Ausdoc was particularly concerned was the definition of an organisation. The bill does not treat a company and its subsidiaries as a single body; it treats state government departments as separate organisations. Ausdoc noted that the implication is that, given that Australia Post has a reserve on mail services between organisations, private contractors are limited to providing services within an organisation.

The coalition's position is that, while the bill seeks to clarify which services and types of mail are not reserved to Australia Post—for example, catalogues and leaflets—the effect of the bill should not be to restrict current practices. To this end, the coalition will move amendments to ensure that there is no inconsistency between the current practices and the clarification of Australia Post's reserve services.

In relation to contracting out and document exchanges, industry participants who spoke to the committee expressed concern that the bill does not go far enough, because document exchanges will not be permitted to provide end-to-end services between individual members' addresses or exchange services. Ausdoc, which is a national document exchange service, expressed concern that provisions applying to document exchanges and internal mail will reduce its ability to continue to provide the current level of service. We think there is sufficient concern to warrant amendments to the bill to ensure that the current practices and services provided by document exchanges are not restricted and that the work that they currently carry out will be able to be continued.

The final concern in the minority report of coalition senators referred to postal services in rural and remote areas. As I said earlier, my concern is that rural and remote areas should continue to receive at least an adequate postal service through the community service obligations. This bill provides an opportunity for the government to expand Australia Post's postal services, through its community service obligations, to customers in rural and remote areas and communities.

In this bill, the government has chosen not to follow through with the Industry Commission's recommendation that when roadside delivery is only once a week, this service should be expanded to a minimum of two mail deliveries per week. In 1992 just over 3,000 households, or 0.1 per cent of all households, did not receive at least two roadside mail deliveries a week. While that does not seem a large number throughout Australia—and I concede that it is not a large number—for the more than 3,000 households that are not in receipt of mail once a week, it certainly is a very important issue.

I think the government's decision not to adopt the recommendation sits very oddly with its claim in the 1994 edition of The Rural Book: `Every effort is made to provide at least two services per week to rural householders, even in the most remote areas.' I do not think that is too much to ask. For those of us who are used to receiving at least five mail services per week, it is very hard to visualise how difficult it would be to receive only one. It is difficult for those people living in rural and remote areas, involved in primary industry or isolated because of their residence. They have every right to be able to conduct their business in a normal way and in a normal fashion by receiving at least two mail services per week. To this end, the coalition will move amendments to make sure that this takes place.

After receiving the submissions and hearing the evidence, the committee has produced both a majority report and a minority report which reflect differing points of view. The coalition will be moving amendments when the bill comes to the committee stage. Those amendments reflect the concerns that were expressed to us by people who are involved in the industry. In most cases, we are not asking for any increase in the current services that are available to people who are operating in competition with Australia Post.

We want to make sure that the current practices that exist are not restricted by this bill; in other words, that it does not make it more difficult for people operating under the current guidelines to continue with their business. I speak particularly in relation to Ausdoc, Streetfile and people who gave evidence to our committee. These matters will be debated at length in the committee stage. We certainly look forward to that debate when it takes place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some brief comments in relation to the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994. This bill is designed to encourage competition in some areas of postal services while ensuring the maintenance of some reserved services for Australia Post. The bill also contains provisions to enhance reporting mechanisms to improve accountability. I believe that in this instance the presentation to the postal industry was more a case of, `You accept something a little less draconian or we'll put something worse in.' That was the basis upon which many people ended up agreeing to a system which nobody is particularly happy with.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ferguson is concerned about the lack of postal services in rural areas. However, the general doctrine of the coalition is based on the user pays principle—privatisation and corporatisation. If we extend that to the limit and we continue to eat away at a government provided service which has equity and access built into it, it is inevitable that the service will degenerate to one of user pays. The service will be very inequitable and access to it by many people across Australia will be cut.

I have serious concerns about the rationale behind this push for increasing competition for some of the services currently provided to the community by government enterprises. Surprisingly, the opposition has not been critical of the government for not going far enough in this bill, citing the Business Council's call for the Hilmer report proposal to expose government enterprises to competition as being the top priority for economic reform.

The sad fact is that both the government and the opposition are committed to this competition policy and this commitment is often pursued at the expense of proper service standards for the community. A classic example at the moment is the work being done through the Council of Australian Governments on a review of Commonwealth-state service provisions. The review is largely being undertaken by Treasury officials from the Commonwealth and the states. It is a telling fact and is indicative of the lack of commitment by the ALP or the opposition parties to a qualitative assessment of services in the community.

In sectors such as education and health, as well as communication, decisions based on narrow economic criteria are the norm. At the state government level, particularly in my state of Western Australia, governments close down schools in the name of better economic management without considering the impact of such a closure on the local communities. This is particularly important in rural areas where the local school is often an important focus for many community activities and assists in maintaining connections between remote families. If, however, there are not sufficient students at the school according to the bean counters in the education department or the Treasury, the schools are forced to close down.

There are numerous examples where this blind adherence to economic fundamentalism or competition policy is resulting in great costs to both the community and to many families and individuals in those communities. The potential implications of this bill and also of the opposition amendments are of concern in this regard as they are continuing this push for greater involvement of the private sector in service provision and of a reduction in public sector services on the basis of economic cost cutting.

There is an inevitable consequence in the push for privatisation and corporatisation that in order to sell off more and more of the farm we have to sell off the more profitable and marketable sectors. It is inevitable that what is left under government funding becomes less competitive in comparison to those areas which have been sold off. The more we do this, the more we leave government open to an unfavourable comparison and push government sectors into becoming a mirror image of the private sector. This ignores the fact that the reason there are government services is that there are some things that only governments can provide. The marketplace does not produce the access and equity principles by itself.

There are other implications that I do not think have been thought out well enough in the deregulation of courier deliveries. There are already numerous examples within the city of Perth of couriers on bicycles and other forms of transport who, to speed things up, grab hold of the back of buses or engage in fairly dangerous delivery methods in order to be able to make money. The rates and conditions of those couriers are very low because it is a very mobile employment sector.

I am very concerned that what we will get here is an informal economy under the guise of competition, such as that pursued by the people one sees in any suburb delivering leaflets for very low rates of pay. Basically, we are getting a black economy of below award rates for people working at exploitative rates in order to provide so-called competition to the government services.

I am pleased to see that the Democrats have proposed a series of amendments in relation to performance standards. The Greens will support these amendments as we feel that they provide a greater guarantee of proper service to the community than is available under the government's bill or under the opposition amendments. In that context it is pleasing to see that the Democrats' amendment incorporates a role for the Auditor-General in determining the extent to which Australia Post meets the prescribed performance standards.

I am also pleased to see that the Democrats have proposed an amendment that will, in part, avoid the ludicrous situation that would have arisen as a result of the government's bill where newspapers, magazines, catalogues or leaflets would have had to be wrapped in plastic. If we think about the number of these items delivered per day, per week, per month to millions of people in Australia, we quickly come to realise that there would be millions of unusable, torn plastic packets. That material would end up on the garbage tip and cause local councils huge problems and incur them in great costs. Therefore, we are pleased to see that amendment because we had already expressed a similar horror to the government.

The disposal of plastic is already a huge problem for this country, and we certainly do not need that problem exacerbated as a result of a government initiative that was not properly thought through. It is another classic example of the narrow sectoral approach to public policy that had dominated this government's term of office. Structures must be put in place to facilitate interdepartmental scrutiny of all proposed legislation and regulations.
In the final analysis, however, whilst the Greens will be supporting the amendments proposed by the Democrats in order to improve a bill which we do not accept in principle, we will oppose this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994 makes a number of changes to the operation of the postal system in Australia. Yet despite that fact if one could summarise this legislation it would be to say that it is more notable for its omissions and for what it does not do than for what it does do and for the changes that it makes. That reflects very poorly on this government.

PARA.TAB: On the one hand, various government ministers go around this country saying, `We need a more competitive economy. We need to make our economy, our businesses and our productive and distribution processes much more competitive so that we can compete in the international marketplace and give our domestic economy much greater potential for wealth creation.' In a number of areas the government has introduced deregulation to improve competition. The ones that readily come to mind are the deregulation of the financial system and the deregulation of wheat marketing, and there are a number of other areas. But every time an issue of deregulation comes up that impacts on some of the union mates of those opposite, that issue hits a brick wall. Government members utterly refuse to proceed with deregulation when it is against the interests of their union mates. Of course, that is the achilles heel of this government. That is its weakness and that is why we find that, despite the government's claims, the economy of Australia is not performing to its optimum level.

Every time government members come to an important area of deregulation that impacts on their mates, they refuse to proceed. That is clearly evident in areas like the labour market and industrial relations, where further reforms are necessary, and it is reflected in this area of the postal services of Australia, as contained in this legislation. That is the great failure of this government and it is a failure that is reflected in this legislation. It is a significant failure because it is contrary to the recommendations of the Hilmer report, which was released at the end of last year and which advocated increasing competition, particularly with regard to government instrumentalities.

Ministers in this government—and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at the Premiers Conference in Darwin—have been lecturing state governments on what they ought to be doing with regard to state government instrumentalities such as electricity authorities and other state government instrumentalities to make them more commercial and competitive and to provide better service and pricing for the private sector. Yet when it comes to one of their own instrumentalities, they are not prepared to do what is necessary in that regard. Of course, I am referring to Australia Post. This legislation fails in that it is inconsistent with the recommendations of the Hilmer report.

It also fails in that it does not implement the recommendations of the Industry Commission. This government asked the Industry Commission to inquire into postal services. The Industry Commission undertook that detailed examination and came down with specific recommendations. In this legislation, which represents the government's response to the Industry Commission report, the government has failed to pick up a number of the significant recommendations of that report.

In terms of its general approach and rhetoric, this legislation fails. In terms of its response to the Hilmer report, this legislation fails. In regard to its response to the very specific Industry Commission report inquiry into postal services, this legislation fails. It was in part a result of that that this legislation was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for examination and report. Senator Ferguson, Senator Panizza and I are members of that committee and, therefore, have comments to make with regard to the findings of that inquiry.

With regard to the specific features of the bill: it reaffirms Australia Post's community service obligations to provide a letter service in Australia and a letter service that connects to overseas countries. It makes some amendments to the exemptions to Australia Post's reserved services. It introduces a requirement by the minister to have regard to movements in the CPI when approving or disapproving changes to the rate of postage for standard postal articles, as determined by the board. It also introduces a new part which contains some enhanced accountability and reporting provisions with regard to safeguarding the confidentiality of mail.

As I said, there are a number of shortcomings with this legislation. They have been raised by particular members of the community and were highlighted in the Senate committee's inquiry. Among those concerns are: the extent to which Australia Post is deregulated by this legislation; the issue of price determination of postal services and the maintenance of competitive neutrality; the balance between community service obligations and profit making within the postal system; the boundaries of the reserved postal services; the relationship between document exchanges and Australia Post; the definition of an organisation; and the definition of a letter. They were particular matters that were looked at in some detail by the Senate committee.

With regard to international postal services, this legislation removes from the definition of services which are reserved to Australia Post—those services over which Australia Post retains a monopoly—the carriage of letters between Australia and places outside Australia. But Australia Post retains the exclusive right to carry letters within Australia, irrespective of their origin.

While we in the opposition welcome that partial deregulation of international mail services, we are concerned about the continuing determination of the government to maintain the monopoly over the domestic carriage of international mail. It needs to be remembered that international mail represents only about six per cent of Australia Post's total revenue, while the domestic addressed letter service provides 55 per cent of its total revenue. So for the government to have gone that little bit further and totally deregulate the international mail service would not have been overly onerous in terms of its impact on Australia Post's revenue.

Perhaps more important are the changes which this legislation makes to the exceptions to reserved services generally. The most important of those is the exception of the carriage of letters within Australia for any charge or fee which is set at a minimum of four times the rate for a standard postal article. Currently, private sector mail operators can carry mail that weighs at least 500 grams and for which they charge a fee of $4.50 per item. This legislation reduces that monopoly which Australia Post has on any letter that weighs less than 500 grams and for which there is a charge of less than $4.50 per item. It reduces that weight requirement to 250 grams and reduces the fee to $1.80; that is, four times the current standard letter rate of 45c.

That is certainly some improvement on the current situation. It does introduce a degree of greater competition, but it falls well short of the recommendation of the Industry Commission. In fact, the preferred recommendation of the Industry Commission was that the weight limit be reduced to 250 grams and that the price of a postal item be reduced to the current amount charged for a standard letter—45c. The preferred option for the Industry Commission in its recommendations to the government was that there be virtually open competition with regard to standard letters in the postal system.

But even the Industry Commission recognised that that was a bit too much for this Labor government to swallow and that its rhetoric about introducing greater competition and deregulation would never be matched by its performance if the Industry Commission were to provide the government with only that recommendation. So the Industry Commission provided the government with a fall-back position.

The fall-back position was that the weight of a postal item which would be subject to competition from the private sector be reduced to 250 grams—that was in its preferred option as well—but that the fee to be charged be reduced to $1.20 from 1 January 1994 and thereafter progressively reduced at a rate of 10c a year for five years until the minimum rate charged whereby private sector firms could provide a postal service would be 70c. That would still be some 35c above the minimum charge that Australia Post could apply, and thereby there would still be a significant gap between the minimum charge that private sector postal service providers could charge and what Australia Post could charge. There would still be a significant degree of protection for Australia Post's monopoly. Nevertheless, this would move us much more towards a competitive and efficient system.

The Industry Commission recommended this on the basis of very sound evidence. The New Zealand Postal Commission provided evidence to the Industry Commission that the current margin which it has, of 35c, is quite adequate for it to be able to compete against those in the private sector who want to provide mail services. Seventy cents is the charge at which private sector operators can enter the market in New Zealand as against, as is the case in Australia, the current standard letter rate of 45c.

That margin is provided in New Zealand. The New Zealand Postal Corporation told the Industry Commission that it provided an adequate degree of protection against the private sector; yet, in Australia, the government would not accept that margin. In fact, in this legislation the minimum charge which the private sector must offer for a standard letter is $1.80. That fee is four times the standard letter rate offered by Australia Post, despite evidence from New Zealand that 35 cents would provide an adequate degree of protection for its core letter service from potential competitors.

We are effectively seeing the total exclusion of any private sector participation in the delivery of normal letters. That will have cost consequences for Australian business. As I said earlier, this government goes around touting itself as a government that wants to see Australia's economy operate as efficiently as possible, and wants to see our cost structure reduced so that we can become more and more internationally competitive—and that is important. If Australia is going to increase its export earnings, and if Australia is going to replace more and more of its imports with goods and services produced in Australia, it is essential that we have to introduce much more effective competition into our economy to reduce our cost structure and thereby reduce prices that the providers of those goods and services charge their customers. At the moment we are simply off the pace; we are falling behind the international competition.

The second issue that arises in relation to this legislation concerns the delivery of catalogues and leaflets. The current blanket exception from reserved services for catalogues and leaflets is to be removed and is to be replaced by an exception for unenclosed catalogues or leaflets; that is, catalogues or leaflets that are distributed loosely to post boxes at residences; catalogues that are enclosed in an opaque cover but not addressed to a particular person or address; and catalogues or leaflets that are enclosed in a transparent cover and which may be addressed to a particular person and address.

The effect of these provisions in this bill is that catalogues and leaflets that are not enclosed in a transparent cover, but are addressed to a particular person or address, will be reserved to carriage by Australia Post; in other words, Australia Post maintains its monopoly over these items. Evidence presented to the committee indicated that this is more restrictive than the current practice. This was disputed by Australia Post and by the minister. However, the practice has been that a number of the direct mail organisations—and the one that gave the most significant evidence to the committee was the firm Streetfile to which Senator Ferguson earlier referred—had delivered catalogues and leaflets in opaque envelopes in the past.

In effect, this legislation further widens the existing monopoly of Australia Post over these items. We believe that is unsatisfactory. In regard to this particular issue we will be moving an amendment in the committee stage of the legislation to attempt to ensure that existing practices in regard to the issue of catalogues and leaflets continue.

The third issue that arises concerns document exchange services. To our great concern, evidence presented to the committee indicated that the legislation will reduce the capacity of document exchange services to provide their current level of service because they will no longer be able to provide a courier service between their clients' offices and the document exchange service centres. A further concern in relation to this issue is the definition of `organisation ` in the legislation. There is concern that the Victorian government, under the new definition of `organisation', will be prevented from continuing to use a non-Australia Post carrier for its interdepartmental mail.

It is entirely unsatisfactory that, in a climate where we are supposed to be increasing competition, this legislation actually reduces the area of competition applying to Australia Post. In the committee stage, the opposition will be moving amendments to deal with that problem and to allow a much freer operation of document exchange services and a wider definition of `organisation'.

The next issue of concern is the bulk interconnection service. Under the legislation, private mail operators will be able to interconnect with the Australia Post system at designated mail centres and to obtain a discount from Australia Post based on the transport costs per letter that Australia Post has not incurred because it has not been required to carry the letter for the whole of its journey. In evidence before the committee, it transpired that these discounts would apply for only interstate bulk mail deliveries on the part of private operators and that intrastate deliveries would be excluded from this provision. That these discounts would apply only if the bulk mail had been transported interstate and not intrastate by private mail operator was even of concern to the Prices Surveillance Authority.

Mayne Nickless raised concerns about this issue before the committee and in particular highlighted that the greatest cost benefits that could be gained by private sector businesses that have the need for bulk mail services would be in the intrastate delivery sector rather than the interstate sector. So again the government is not allowing businesses that are dependent on and are substantial users of that mail service to benefit from the maximum possible cost reduction in this area of their business operations. There is significant concern about this that we will seek to remedy through amendments to this legislation.

The other particular area of our concern regards the capacity of the minister to sack members of the board. We believe this is an inappropriate power for the minister to have. Therefore, we will be moving an amendment in the committee stage to remove this power from the minister, because we believe it is unsatisfactory that the minister should have that power.

The final issue I wish to raise is with regard to the service that this legislation will provide to rural people. The Industry Commission report recommended that where roadside delivery is only once a week, it be increased to at least twice a week. It is interesting to note that in its 1994 edition of The Rural Book, the government boasted that every effort is made to provide at least two services per week to rural householders, even in the most remote areas. Certainly this ought to be part of Australia Post's community service obligation, yet in 1992 it was estimated there were 3,152 households not receiving this service. In our amendments to the legislation in the committee stage, we will seek to require that the government provide two services—(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994. This morning we resumed the second reading debate on this bill. Senator Ferguson resumed his earlier remarks and Senator Margetts of the Greens (WA) has also contributed to today's debate. We have just heard Senator Chapman's speech, and at this point it is appropriate for me, on behalf of the government, to reply.

PARA.TAB: It is fair to say that the speeches from the coalition take the theme that the government has not gone far enough in this legislation. However, from the Greens the theme is that the government has gone too far. It is not surprising that we in the government say that we have gone the appropriate distance, and I want to seek to set that out in some detail.

The Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994 gives effect to the government's response to the report of the Industry Commission following its inquiry into mail courier and parcel services in Australia. An appropriate way for governments to enact legislation is to ask the Industry Commission to inquire and present a report. The government then considers that report and frames legislation accordingly.

There is no obligation on a government to accept all of the recommendations of an independent inquiry. Governments should discriminate and take a view that is wider than the narrow focus of such an inquiry. They should take a wider and more community appropriate view of the recommendations. I think that is what the government has done here. It has balanced the need for efficiency and competition against the need for Australia Post to provide a community service, particularly to those in the community who, either by virtue of the fact that they are resident in rural areas or are at the low income spectrum of the community, want their needs met on a basis equal to the rest of the community.

I note with some interest that Senator Chapman, in arguing the theme that we have not gone far enough in accepting all of the recommendations of the Industry Commission, cited the example of New Zealand. If I understand what Senator Chapman was putting, he regards New Zealand as a country that has gone far enough—certainly, further than Australia—in this respect. But I have some information about the experience of the New Zealand experiment that might be of interest to the Senate.

New Zealand's reduction in price protection for its postal service—from 10 times to two times the standard letter rate in one step—resulted in the closure of 600 post offices over five years in a country of 2 1/2 million people. That was a radical step and one that provoked a reaction in the community that was quite sweeping and dramatic. It resulted in a reduction in New Zealand Post's net income from $31 million in 1988-89 to $5.4 million in 1991-92, and the imposition of an $80 annual fee for rural deliveries. The New Zealand government announced in June last year that the second stage of its postal reforms would not proceed because there were no demonstrable benefits from further change.

In managing change, we have to be concerned with the reactions to the actions we take. In the case of New Zealand, it went, as the opposition would describe it, far enough, or further than we did. But the reaction to the closure of 600 post offices over five years—namely, loss of revenue to the New Zealand postal service and higher charges on rural deliveries—suggests that we in Australia should learn from that lesson and respond in a more balanced way than the New Zealand government did to the so-called reform of its postal service. That is what this legislation does.

The government has agreed to increase competition in the postal sector but has adopted a phased approach to doing so. Its approach is to safeguard the basic letter service so that it continues to cost the same to send a standard letter—currently 45c—anywhere in Australia. Its approach is to ensure that the benefits of competition are passed on to the consumers and businesses in the form of price restraint, with standard letter prices subject to a price cap, while at the same time encouraging competition in value added services, such as bulk mail, document exchanges and express mail, and working towards the changes recommended in the Hilmer report on national competition policy.

Australia Post will remain in government ownership as a statutory corporation operating a national network but it will face competition in new areas. We believe that competition will sharpen its responses and provide greater efficiency in the economy. For example, Australia Post currently competes for about 40 per cent of its revenue while, as a result of the government's decision, it now expects to compete for about 50 per cent or even higher of its revenue because it will be exposed to greater competition in those areas.

This competition is expected to provide the impetus for Australia Post to continue to improve the services it provides to businesses and to households—but, importantly, without jeopardising services to rural areas, and, importantly, without requiring the closure of corporate post offices around Australia. There is no broad community support, in the government's view, for ending Australia Post's reserved letter service at this time. The Industry Commission was unable to identify the costs and, importantly, the benefits from full deregulation of the postal industry.

It is clear that a phased approach has worked in the telecommunications sector. So it has worked elsewhere. We are not adopting a model that has not been tried elsewhere. This is a model that has been tried and proven elsewhere. The telecommunications sector is a key example. In that sector there have been significant decreases in prices across the board. Both business and residential customers are benefiting from that. New services have been introduced, service quality has improved and the telecommunications market has grown significantly as a result. Consistent with the approach adopted for telecommunications, remaining limits on competition in the postal sector will be reviewed in 1996-97.

The bill introduced by the government represents a total package of reform of the sector. Nevertheless, individual aspects of it have come under scrutiny and some pressure has been brought to bear for amendments to address the particular concerns of some interests. I know the Democrats have some amendments, as has the opposition. I will go to those in a moment.

It is for the reason that some aspects of the bill have come under greater scrutiny that the government did not want to amend specific aspects of the package but it has agreed not to oppose some of the amendments put forward in the interests of ensuring the passage of the bill, but only where the effect is consistent with the overall approach that we have adopted. The most significant area in which we have accepted an alternative approach is in relation to catalogues and leaflets. The government will not oppose the proposed Democrat amendment to the bill because it essentially maintains the status quo under the 1989 act and accords with current practice.It was never the intention to deregulate advertising mail; the proposed amendment maintains that position, neither liberalising nor clawing back current legitimate activity.
