Under the amendment, catalogues and leaflets continue to be exempt from Australia Post's exclusive right to carry letters under section 29 of the act, irrespective of whether or how they are wrapped or whether a name and/or address is stamped, stuck or printed on any of the catalogues or leaflets or any of the wrappers of the catalogues or leaflets. Australia Post will still have reserved to it the delivery of all letters, including generic or pro forma letters which contain identical text sent to more than one person by use of that person's name or address. A leaflet or catalogue that is carried with a letter of a kind which is not exempt under any paragraph of section 30 will continue to be reserved by Australia Post, as under current legislation. The amendment will not prevent the enclosure or attachment of a single sheet—for example, a flysheet or address slip—with a catalogue or leaflet, the sole purpose of which is to direct the item to a particular person or address.

The opposition amendment is unacceptable because it would effectively deregulate the sector, which was never intended by the government. The opposition amendment requiring two household or roadside deliveries per week which claims to be in the interests of rural dwellers would have the effect of widening the gap between those receiving minimal service and those receiving none. It could even adversely affect those currently getting by with only one service per week.

The Democrat amendment requiring notification by Australia Post of instances where it has become necessary to destroy an item of mail that is physically offensive is also being accepted on the ground that it ensures accountability of the actions of employees rather than impacting on the power to destroy articles where and when warranted.

The government intends to back up this provision with a direction to Australia Post requiring it to adopt specific guidelines for its employees to ensure there are no abuses of power. Other opposition amendments will not be supported because of the reasons I have already stated. This bill comes forward after an extensive inquiry by the Industry Commission. We have accepted a balanced and phased way in which to adopt the findings of the Industry Commission. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clause 1 agreed to.
Clause 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 2, page 2, subclause (1), line 2, omit "subsections (2), (3) and (4)", substitute "subsection (2)".
(2)Clause 2, page 2, subclauses (3) and (4), lines 6 to 11, omit the subclauses.
A supplementary explanatory memorandum has been circulated explaining the purposes of those amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 3 to 7—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 8.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 8, page 3, at end of clause, add the following subclause:
"(2) Section 27 of the Principal Act is amended by adding the following word and paragraph after paragraph (4)(b):
`;and (c)that all households to which a road side delivery service is available have that service available at least twice each week.'.".

In concluding the second reading debate, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) mentioned the New Zealand experience and the closing of post offices. I would like to ask the minister just how many post offices have been closed in Australia. He talked about 600 post offices being closed in New Zealand; to the best of my knowledge, that is almost exactly the same as the number of post offices that have been closed in Australia. I happen to have some personal experience because my own post office was closed a month ago, which is why I am so concerned about roadside deliveries because I am now a recipient of roadside deliveries which, thank goodness, are made five days a week.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has moved this amendment because it seeks to enhance the community service obligation under section 27 of the principal act. This amendment has the effect of ensuring that all households to which a roadside mail delivery service is available receive such a service at least twice a week. This is in line with the recommendation contained in the Industry Commission's 1992 report on the efficiency of mail, courier and parcel services. In its report, the Industry Commission estimated that such an extension would benefit an estimated 3,152 households which currently receive only one service per week. In its submission to the Industry Commission's inquiry, Australia Post estimated that providing these households with two services a week would cost at least $3.7 million a year.
In its 1994 edition of The Rural Book the government claims:

SPEECH.PARA: Every effort is made to provide at least two services per week to rural householders, even in the most remote areas.

I guess it is reasonable to assume that the cost of such an extension would now be less than that estimated at the time of the Industry Commission inquiry. The Democrats have indicated to us that they will not support this amendment because it does not look into households that currently do not get any mail deliveries. By not looking at the households that do not get any mail deliveries at present, they are not helping any of those households that are currently getting only one mail delivery.

PARA.TAB: People in business in some of these rural and remote areas who received only one mail delivery a week would know how difficult it could be and how this could impact on the success or otherwise of their business. Only recently, we went to centres of Western Australia where not only Australia Post but also telecommunications and other communications are a problem. They cannot even use a fax service because the line will not carry a fax and there is no radio in some areas.

I think because of the community service obligation, at least to many of these places, it is important that those who are currently getting one service a week should at least get two services a week. If the Democrats are fair dinkum in their attitude towards rural areas, as we have heard that they are at great length from Senator Woodley in his many speeches in this place, I think they would support a situation where those people, as is claimed in The Rural Book 1994 and as recommended in the Industry Commission's report, receive at least two services per week.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats, as Senator Ferguson said, will not support this amendment. If the opposition is genuinely concerned about rural and remote areas, it will support our amendment. We believe that the very best way to achieve an increased and much better service for all rural and remote area customers is to have the minister set performance standards which must be met by Australia Post for rural and remote areas. In fact, later on we will move an amendment along those lines to this bill.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Ferguson said, the problem with the opposition's amendment as we see it is that it does not take into account those customers in rural and remote areas who have no service at the moment. If this came in, those customers would not get any service until Australia Post was able to give them two services. If it came to the point that those ones on the margin who get no service at the moment might be able to get one service a week, they would not get that service until Australia Post was able to give them two services a week. So we think it is more important for people on the margin who have no postal service at the moment to get that one service as soon as possible and, on top of that, that the minister set performance standards. That will later be one of our amendments to this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments come forward in this chamber one at a time, but they represent an overall view of the amending party. Taking the overall view, the opposition is saying that the revenue base of Australia Post will be reduced by greater competition. But this amendment imposes further costs on a reduced revenue base by directing certain things to happen, which removes some discretion from Australia Post to deliver the most efficient postal service for all consumers in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I really think that we cannot have it both ways. We cannot try to reduce the revenue base and then impose more costs and say that we are concerned about having an efficient postal service in this country. However, with specific recognition of this amendment Minister Lee, the Minister for Communications and the Arts, indicated to me that there are some remarks that I should make. Perhaps I should read from his note.

The government does not accept the coalition amendment. It is inequitable in the treatment of households currently receiving less than two deliveries a week in that it proposes no increases for households currently with no roadside delivery services available. It would not necessarily achieve its intended outcome of taking away from Australia Post the discretion of determining service frequency because Australia Post would continue to determine those households that receive one delivery per week, and it may run the risk of preventing Australia Post from introducing one service per week in places where it now offers none but where costs may preclude its offering two.

The government has confirmed that service standards to rural and remote areas be maintained and agreed that a letter service continue to be made available at a uniform rate of postage to all Australians wherever they reside. To safeguard rural postal services, the Minister for Communications and the Arts announced in a joint press statement in February this year a parliamentary review of Australia Post's community service obligations, which is to be completed once in each parliamentary term. Representatives of rural and remote communities will be invited to contribute to the review, which will provide these communities with an opportunity to have a direct say in their postal services. In addition to the mechanisms already available to the minister to change CSOs, the government considers this to be the appropriate policy for ensuring that services in rural and remote areas are adequate, equitable and up to date. For those reasons, we are opposing the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support opposition amendment No. 1. As Senator Ferguson has already indicated, it would require Australia Post to provide at least two roadside services per week in rural and remote areas where currently one is provided. The arguments that we have heard from the Democrats on the one

SPEECH.PARA: hand and from the minister on the other do not in any way negate the arguments as to why this amendment ought to be passed.

PARA.TAB: We heard from Senator Vicki Bourne on behalf of the Democrats that this amendment should be rejected in favour of their amendment, which would seek to have performance standards set by the minister apply with regard to mail delivery services. Of course, we do not know what those performance standards might be, and our capacity to control them would certainly be significantly limited, whereas this amendment moved by the opposition writes into the legislation a specific requirement that where there is one roadside delivery service per week, that be increased to two. This was a matter to which I referred towards the end of my remarks during the second reading debate. I indicated that, according to the Industry Commission report, there are 3,152 households in this situation. So it is an increase in the obligation on Australia Post to which Senator Cook referred, but it is a minimal increase.

We heard Senator Cook's argument against this amendment. It was—I hope I am accurately paraphrasing it—that if we require this service to be provided to those recipients of Australia Post services that currently receive one roadside service per week, it will be a disincentive to Australia Post to provide one service a week where it currently provides none. I do not believe that is an adequate response to this amendment. Clearly, with the relatively few number of households that are in this situation, to have that relatively modest—I stress `relatively modest'—increase in the obligation on Australia Post to provide a better service to these people is really no argument for not providing it to those who also receive no service in the current circumstances.

We need to remember that the community service obligation on the part of Australia Post is important, particularly in rural and remote areas. I guess that, in discussing this amendment, we could open up the whole issue of the way in which community service obligations ought to be provided. The minister, in his remarks closing the second reading debate, referred to the New Zealand experience, attempting to argue against the points that I made earlier with regard to the Industry Commission's evidence taken from the New Zealand Postal Corporation as regards the adequacy of its minimal postal charge of 70c for private sector competition as against the standard letter rate charged by the Postal Corporation in New Zealand of 45c; and he ascribed to that reduction to 70c in New Zealand the closure of post offices, the introduction of a fee of $80 for certain rural recipients of New Zealand postal services, and so on. As I said earlier, there is a significant margin of 35c provided in the New Zealand situation.

It is important that the community service obligation be maintained. The point is how it should be maintained, I guess. Should it be maintained by all of the users of postal services paying more than would be a competitive rate for the services they use and thereby subsidising Australia Post's capacity to provide its community service obligations perhaps to areas that are non-profitable? In other words, should the cost of those services to rural and remote areas in Australia be borne by the people who use the postal service, thereby increasing their costs of operation, or should it be borne by the community at large? Let us remember that it is described as a `community' service obligation.

Clearly, if there is a difficulty in this area, it ought to be provided by the community at large rather than by costs being imposed on one section of Australia Post's service users. The best way of achieving that would be for the community service obligation to be met directly by subsidy from general revenue so that the community at large is providing the service which is regarded as an obligation on that community rather than the users of the service. That is simply another point with regard to this particular issue.

If, as the minister says, the imposition of this particular amendment would possibly prevent Australia Post from providing one service per week to areas that currently receive no service per week, then the government ought to take up the responsibility of ensuring that that event does not occur and that, indeed, one service per week is provided to those people. It does not negate the opposition's argument that, where there is currently one service per week, two should be applied. As I said in my second reading remarks and as Senator Ferguson mentioned a few moments ago, the government boasts in its 1994 addition of The Rural Book:

SPEECH.PARA: Every effort is made to provide at least two services per week to rural householders, even in the most remote areas.

We simply want to hold the government accountable to that boast by writing into this legislation through this amendment the requirement that those two services be provided. The amendment ought to be carried.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister raised the issue of the coalition's amendments and stated that the reasoning behind our amendments was to introduce competition and to reduce the revenue of Australia Post. Let me say that we have been very careful, in drafting these amendments, to maintain existing services—not to introduce new competition but to clarify and to maintain operations that are currently existing in competition with Australia Post at present.

PARA.TAB: Australia Post does not seem to be suffering from a lack of revenue or from a lack of profit at present. We would see that the amendments that we have moved are not going to affect its current operations to any great extent, but we do believe that this is a very important principle. As I said earlier, I think those people who are not receiving mail on a regular basis would realise how difficult it can be in rural and remote areas to have only a once a week delivery of roadside mail. Let me say that once a week is better than none at all: I agree with the government on that score.

I would like to know how many households that have not been in receipt of mail in the past few years are now in receipt of mail; in other words, how many households that over the past years were not in receipt of any roadside delivery at all are currently receiving deliveries. The government makes it sound as though in the process we are extending the delivery to rural and remote areas at a far greater rate than I believe is currently taking place. Certainly, we are quite adamant—given the report of the Industry Commission in 1992, which made the recommendation, and, as Senator Chapman said, given that in the government's 1994 edition of The Rural Book it says that every effort should be made to provide at least two services per week to rural householders—that this amendment should be carried.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very concerned that the government does not wish to accept this amendment. The explanation that we received from the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) is quite extraordinary. He said that if this amendment is carried, it will impede the ability of Australia Post to efficiently serve all Australians. That is an extraordinary claim by the minister because at its heart is the assumption that one serves all Australians by depriving some Australians of a decent standard of service. That is totally unacceptable, it is a nonsense, and it ought to be exposed as a nonsense.

PARA.TAB: This amendment seeks to ensure that people who now get just one roadside service a week should get two. Surely that is part of the process of better assisting the body corporate of Australians. Instead, the minister merely says, `We are going to maintain the standard of service that exists at the moment and improve it in some areas.' But the problem is that in rural and regional Australia, the standard of service in many cases has declined over recent years. It is not sufficient to say, `We are just going to maintain that standard of service at the inadequate standard it is at the moment.' That is not good enough and the government has to understand that.

This government gets a lot of money in dividends out of Australia Post. That is the bottom line as to why this government does not want to accept this amendment from the coalition. The government gets in dividends very large amounts of money—well over a billion dollars a year—from Australia Post and is solely concerned about propping up its own profligate spending by ripping off the postal service. The government has the resources to provide a decent mail service for people in rural and regional Australia. There is no doubt about it. The sole question to be answered is why this government lacks the will to give ordinary people—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have to shout.

—In Senator Collins's case, I do have to shout because he never seems to listen to the points being made to him from this side of the chamber. He might do better, if he wants to interject, to do so from his own seat. The government does not want to listen to the fact that it is ripping this money from the public and is unwilling to provide a decent service for people in rural and regional Australia. That is the nub of the whole issue. The sole question those opposite have to answer is why they do not want to provide that service. They do not want to provide it because they want to get their hands on the money.

PARA.TAB: There are a lot of people in rural and regional Australia who deserve a much better go from this government than they are getting at the moment. Here is an opportunity for the government to show some sort of genuine interest in improving the lot of these people; but we are not going to see it. The government is not going to accept the amendment because at the end of the day the people in rural and regional Australia are second rate citizens when it comes to the provision of government services. That is what this amendment exposes. It exposes this government's callous lack of concern for those people. The government's concern is more with making money and propping up its budget than it is with looking after those people.

The other thing that annoys me is the fact that this government, when it talks about services, seems to consider that a postal service—decent deliveries to people in rural and regional Australia—is some sort of enormous gift. It fails to appreciate the fact that there is an obligation to ensure that all Australians have some semblance of equality. This government makes lots and lots of play on the words `equity' and `access', but where is the equity and access here?

The services we are talking about now—going from one delivery a week to two deliveries a week—would still be only 40 per cent of the services in capital cities in terms of mail deliveries. Yet the government seems to think this is some enormous gift that it cannot afford to give. It is a standard of service which ordinary Australians in cities would consider to be second rate if they received it. All we are asking for is a slight improvement, and the government is unwilling to accept that.

This government stands condemned for the fact that it will not accept this amendment. It shows that it has a callous disregard for Australians who live in rural and regional Australia. The fact that the minister on the other side of the table is smirking does not do anything to improve the situation. It just compounds the insult that this government gives to rural and regional Australia, and it compounds this government's lack of concern.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope we can dispense with this amendment fairly quickly. The only reason why I rise is that I recognise that Senator O'Chee just made a speech to this chamber which doubtless he will circulate to his rural constituents as a speech in which he upheld, in his view, the rights of his rural constituents. Of course, he did no such thing. It was just a piece of political grandstanding, and it did not go anywhere down the track to a sensible debate on this matter.

PARA.TAB: Let us get some facts into the frame here. Australia Post provides a letter service to some 7.4 million addresses. All Australians have access to the postal network, although delivery of letters is effected in different ways according to where people live. At an annual cost of $39 million, roadside deliveries are provided by Australia Post to about 355,000 rural and remote households, with a vast majority of them receiving five deliveries per week. So point one is that just about everyone gets a roadside delivery and that, among those who do, nearly all of them get it five times a week. It is not as though we are talking about every single person in rural Australia; we are talking about a fairly narrow group of people.

I am not saying that this point is not legitimate, but I am saying that, in terms of proportion and in context, it is not as significant as Senator O'Chee held it up to be. He raved on a little about this government not caring about rural Australians and so on. I will not paraphrase his terms; they were a bit of a joke. The point is that that is not the context in which real life is carried on and that is not the priority assigned here for rural and regional Australia.

Let me mention one of the other facts. Approximately four per cent of Australian households receive fewer than two deliveries per week—that is, four per cent overall. Of these, some 3,150 receive one delivery a week and about 125,000 in rural and remote Australia receive no delivery per week to their residence. But they do get deliveries. Where is their mail delivered? It is delivered to a community mailbag or to their post office box in the nearest town, or it is delivered by aerial drop to their neighbour, to whom they drive across to pick it up. These are people in quite distant, remote and peculiar circumstances.

What the opposition is asking the government to do is direct Australia Post to ensure that every one of those people gets a kerbside delivery twice a week. In terms of the management of a postal service, there has to be some basis to manage its affairs properly—and there is. The Rural Book, to which those opposite are referring, says that Australia Post should endeavour to do that. But if we impose an obligation on it to do it in the case of everyone, we may simply blow the charges through the roof and make the whole thing uneconomic.

That is not a care or concern of the opposition, because it is not in a position of having to manage Australia Post. But it is a care and concern of the government. Where appropriate, Australia Post is endeavouring to effect two deliveries a week. That is its obligation. That is what it is addressing. With due respect, to make it mandatory that in every case it does so is simply to make this an absurdity,

TALK.START.PARA: —In our amendment we refer only to roadside deliveries. We have never at any stage mentioned mailbags that are dropped by air to neighbours or anything else. We have specifically referred to roadside deliveries—not community mailbags or anything else. This amendment is concerned with only roadside deliveries.

PARA.TAB: In many cases, the provision of roadside deliveries is now where post offices used to exist. In my own case, up until a month ago, we had a post office to which people used to drive and collect mail. We now have some 14 roadside deliveries which, the contractor says, can be done at no extra cost because it is already part of the mail contract run.

It appears that roadside deliveries may be on the increase because of the closure of post offices. I can understand the reasons behind the closure of many of these post offices. Provided we have an alternative by way of roadside deliveries, I have no objection to many of those small post offices and post office agencies not being there. In these days of modern communications it is quite feasible that other methods be used, but for mail and things that have to be delivered by post—certainly some business items—it is absolutely imperative that, where roadside deliveries exist, there ought to be a minimum standard required of two deliveries per week.
Other services are a totally different issue but, where roadside deliveries have replaced rural and remote post offices, asking for two deliveries a week is not too much.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Ferguson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 9 agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have an amendment that would insert a new division 9A after clause 9. The government has asked for more time to consider that. With the agreement of the chamber, I will put that off until the very end of the committee stage. Leave granted.

PARA.TAB: Clause 10 agreed to.
Clause 11.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 11, page 5, paragraph (d), lines 1 to 15, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraphs:
"(d)by omitting paragraphs (1)(b) and (1)(c) and substituting the following paragraphs:
`(b)the carriage of a letter relating to goods (including any newspaper, magazine, catalogue or book) that is sent and delivered with the goods;
`(c)the carriage of newspapers, magazines, books, catalogues and leaflets which do not convey a unique message or information other than in the name, address or salutation;';".
Clause 11, pages 5 and 6, paragraph (k), proposed subsection 30(1A), line 34 (page 5) to line 13 (page 6), omit the subsection.

These amendments seek to ensure that the effect of the current exceptions to Australia Post's reserved services relating to catalogues and leaflets are maintained. This is done by omitting paragraphs (d) and (k) of clause 11 of the bill and replacing them with a more sensible exception, to be contained in a new paragraph (c) in the principal act, encompassing catalogues or leaflets which do not convey a unique message other than in relation to name, address or salutation.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 2 also seeks to clarify any possible anomaly between section 31(d) of the principal act, which provides an exception for `the carriage of a letter relating to goods . . . sent and delivered with the goods' and paragraph (l) of the bill, which does not exclude an article containing a number of things unless each of the things maintained in the article are exceptions from reserved services.

I know that the Australian Democrats have amendments with alternative wording to these two paragraphs. I think they are also going to oppose the clause which is the subject of our amendment No. 4. But the people who are involved and who have made submissions to us have expressed the view that the wording in our amendment is better, specifically because our amendment talks about not conveying a unique message or information. In other words, it covers a very broad range of the magazines and leaflets currently being delivered by people other than Australia Post. We think that our wording more accurately reflects what is required, although I understand that the Democrats have a different view.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Ferguson has just said, the Australian Democrats do have a different view. We believe that Streetfile and the major mail users of Australia have a legitimate complaint about the clauses in this bill which the amendments seek to change. We have our own amendments addressing those concerns, and I will come to them in a moment.

PARA.TAB: The problem we have with Senator Ferguson's amendments is that they go further in deregulating the system and liberalising the carriage of letters with advertising material. They allow personalisation of the advertising material to the extent that a form letter would qualify as a leaflet. We think that a form letter should qualify as a letter and be exclusive to Australia Post. We will be opposing these particular amendments because we have similar ones which do not go quite as far.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept the coalition's amendments. The proposed new section 30(1B) is unnecessary. The meaning of `goods' in section 3O(1B) of the act, which the bill does not propose to amend, is not weight limited only; it therefore normally includes newspapers, magazines, catalogues and books. However, the amendments could have the effect of suggesting that there are limits to the operation of that section.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the proposed new section 30(1C), the amendments seek to introduce the concept that catalogues and leaflets do not convey a unique message or information other than the names, addresses or salutations. Effectively, this amounts to a new concept of defining a letter on the basis of the uniqueness of the message, something that has not been adopted anywhere else in the world and which conflicts with the current definition of a letter, which is not being amended. The test of uniqueness is very stringent, is not defined and may have unforeseen consequences. The government reforms are a balance between the benefits of competition and the importance of the uniform postage rate as the principle that enables universal access to postal services.

What the opposition wants to do is dismantle Australia Post's reserved service. It is clear, we believe, that not too many National Party members have been consulted by Senator Alston on postal matters. What Senator Alston is proposing in all of his amendments is to substantially reduce the revenue stream available to Australia Post to provide postal services to Australians under its community service obligations. Australia Post estimates that up to $100 million in advertising mail would be put at risk, or $100 million worth of revenue would be put at risk. At the same time, he wants to add an inequitable community service provision that reflects a lack of understanding about how community service obligations are to be delivered. This policy of the opposition, as I say, we suspect has not been considered after any detailed consultation with National Party members, who have a particular interest in preserving postal services in rural areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only the National Party.

—I say to Senator Ferguson that 30 or 40 years ago the Liberal Party in South Australia took over the National Party and it does have an interest. Therefore, I am a little surprised that the opposition did not look at this a bit more closely because we believe this policy of the opposition could force post office closures, reduce postal services in rural areas and threaten the 45c stamp price, frozen by Australia Post until 1997.

PARA.TAB: The government will not be party to an amendment which could put at risk the principle of a uniform postage rate, the principle that enables universal access to a postal service and enables Australia Post to cross-subsidise its community service obligations. Senator Ferguson should remember this: if we reduce Australia Post's ability to cross-subsidise its community obligations there is only one other place to which it will come for the money, and that is here. We would be funding a direct allocation in the budget for community service obligations if that $100 million in revenue went to the private sector. In the end, quite rightly, the opposition would be talking about the service that Australia Post provides, particularly in rural areas, where everybody accepts that the services are less profitable and may even run at a loss in a number of areas. If the $100 million in revenue is taken off us—off Australia Post, that is—

TALK.START.PARA: —A Freudian slip!

—It is off us because we are the government; we have been in government for 11 1/2 years and I suspect we will be here for a few years to come. It is off us because we are responsible for the budget and for putting it before the parliament. We are responsible for providing the money to Australia Post as a fully owned statutory authority of the Australian government, on behalf of the people. If we remove the ability to raise revenue because the private sector has picked it up, it is not going to pay the community service obligation. It means this parliament will have to provide more money in the budget to fund the community service obligation, if we restrict Australia Post's present ability to have some cross-subsidisation. Therefore, we reject the amendment.

—In his response to the opposition amendment, Minister Schacht has again raised the issue of the community service obligation. There was some reference to this during the consideration of an earlier opposition amendment. He makes the point that if Australia Post's revenue were reduced by what the government claims would be $100 million if this amendment were passed and therefore it did not retain its monopoly over certain catalogues and leaflets, that loss of $100 million would have to be made up by the government to ensure that the community service obligations were maintained. I suppose one could question whether $100 million would be lost. No doubt, to try to convince the government not to accept this amendment, it probably overstated the amount of revenue it would lose. Notwithstanding that, let us remember that Australia Post, as I understand it, currently makes a profit of about $247 million.

PARA.TAB: I assume that a substantial amount of that profit goes back to the government. I interjected when the minister said, `This $100 million comes to us.' That was a Freudian slip on his part, because indeed it does go to them, as that $100 million is part of that $247 million profit.

TALK.START.PARA: —No; $100 million comes from us to them.

—The minister says that it would have to come from the government to fund the community service obligation. I just said there is a profit in Australia Post, currently, of about $247 million. Even if we take the $100 million off, Australia Post will still be making a profit of $147 million after it provides its community service obligation.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, Australia Post is meeting its community service obligation and still making a profit of $247 million. So even if we take $100 million off Australia Post, which I doubt will happen, Australia Post will still be making a profit of $147 million after it provides for all its community service obligations. To say that this amendment will mitigate against Australia Post's community service obligation is clearly nonsense. But let us assume for the moment that it does. As I said in the debate on the earlier amendment, one could have a debate about whether the community service obligation ought to be met by Australia Post generating the revenue to fund that or whether it ought to be met by the government itself.

Let us not forget that, with Australia Post funding the community service obligation from within its own revenue, in effect Australia Post is imposing a tax on the users of its service to the extent that it requires money from one area of its service to subsidise its community service obligations in other areas. So there is already a tax inherent in Australia Post's operation. Over and above that, of course, it provides further tax because a substantial amount of these profits is paid back to the government as revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a dividend.

—It is a dividend but, in effect, it is a tax on the users of Australia Post's services. If Australia Post was purely providing a government business enterprise service, it would be budgeted to break even; if it was really providing a service to the community it would not make a profit and pay a dividend back to the government, it would break even. Then one gets into the debate of whether we ought to have the government maintaining this monopoly or not, but we had that debate earlier.

PARA.TAB: A component of tax is therefore already built into Australia Post's operation but it is paid only by those people who use Australia Post. As I said in the earlier debate, one can argue about whether that is an appropriate way of meeting that community service obligation or whether the community at large ought to meet that obligation by Australia Post reducing its charges by that amount and by having the community service obligation funded directly by the government.

In relation to that, the minister also said that if one hives off this $100 million to the private sector, then not only would Australia Post not be able to deliver its community service obligation—a point which I think I effectively rebutted in my remarks of a moment or two ago—but also the government would have to find the funds to meet that community service obligation. That completely ignores the fact that, if this $100 million is hived off to the private sector, those private sector organisations would make a profit on which they would pay tax which would provide some of that revenue to the government to fund that community service obligation. So there is simply no argument in the community service requirements of Australia Post for this amendment to be rejected.

The legislation as it stands is completely arbitrary and illogical because a private sector operator of postal service articles can deliver a brochure, catalogue or leaflet addressed to an individual and a particular residential address if it is in a transparent envelope, but not if the article is in an opaque envelope.

The material in the envelope could be exactly the same. If it is in a transparent envelope, it can be personally addressed, but if it is an opaque envelope, it cannot be personally addressed. If it is in an opaque envelope, it can be delivered only by Australia Post, not by a private sector postal service provider. There is absolutely no logic in that at all, because the nature of the document that is being delivered has not changed. All that has changed is the wrapper around it.

We have moved these amendments so that any item can be delivered either by Australia Post or by a private sector postal service provider, provided the item is identical in all respects; in other words, it does not contain a unique message. It is not a letter which has varying content from one recipient to another. The contents of the item being posted are universal to whomever it is delivered. The only difference is that one is addressed to Mr Bloggs and one is addressed to maybe Senator Schacht. That is the only difference.

There is absolutely no logic in reserving that service to Australia Post. So we have moved amendments Nos 2 and 4 to ensure that a broader range of service providers can deliver these sorts of items, because the items are identical, the only variation is the addressee. The reason that we have done this is that the evidence presented to the Senate committee on this matter was that the legislation as drafted simply was not keeping up with technological change and the efficiencies that can be offered with these sorts of services. The sophistication of computers, which can personally address items, is ignored in the legislation as it stands. On the one hand, we find the government talking about information superhighways and all the other developments of high technology which it wants this country to embrace yet, in this legislation, it is preventing that from occurring.

Senator Bourne referred to direct mail letters. Again, in a situation where such a letter is identical for every recipient, other than its being addressed to an individual person—but the contents, the message and words in the letter are identical—there is no reason why a private sector mail service provider should not have the ability to deliver letters which are in the nature of advertising material. They are not personal letters, in the real sense, in that the content varies whether it is addressed to Joe Bloggs or Senator Schacht. The wording of the letter is exactly the same, except for the addressee. No restrictions should be placed on who can deliver those letters.

For all of these reasons, amendments Nos 2 and 4 that Senator Ferguson has moved on behalf of our shadow minister, Senator Alston, ought to be supported and passed by the Senate, so we get a more rational basis for the items that are reserved to Australia Post. In these amendments, we are not arguing that there are areas that ought not to be reserved for Australia Post. We are arguing about the nature of those items that ought to be reserved.

Clearly, material that is in the nature of circulars, catalogues and advertising material, irrespective of the person to whom it is addressed, which is not unique—save for the fact that it has an individual name and address on it to ensure that there is an individual recipient—ought not to be reserved to Australia Post. It ought to be open to competition, and these amendments ought to be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make only a couple of comments. The minister, in his earlier comments, talked about competition and the fact that competition is likely to reduce the revenue of Australia Post. If the government feels so strongly about competition, why did it introduce any competition at all?
—We get the correct balance.
—If the government were so concerned, it would not have let any in at all. The one thing competition has done is, in many ways, to improve the efficiency of the existing service.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that we are very careful about when moving amendments is to seek to ensure that existing services that are being provided by competitors will continue to be provided in the future. That is all we are concerned about. The main concern amongst those people who gave evidence at the committee hearing was that they would not be able to continue doing things that they had in practice been doing for at least the past couple of years.

We do not seek to extend the competition. What we are doing is seeking to ensure the maintenance of the existing provisions and practices that still enable Australia Post to make what I would consider to be a very reasonable profit—one which ought to enable it to cover all of its community service obligations and even extend them to the extent that we suggested in our earlier amendment. All we are trying to do is maintain existing provisions and practices under which people such as Streetfile and Ausdoc operate. The representatives of these organisations laid all their cards on the table when they were giving evidence before the committee. They were under intense questioning. The department had a chance to answer many of those—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you beat them round the head?

—It was not intense questioning always by us. Some government senators were very intense in their questioning, particularly of Streetfile. Let me say that their concerns and our concerns were only that they continue in the existing practices that have been going on for a considerable time now, not to introduce new elements of competition and certainly not to extend the competition.

PARA.TAB: As I said before, we are aware of the community service obligation that has to be provided. I think the amendments that we have moved are very reasonable. I do not see any reason at all why the government cannot accept an amendment which seeks only to maintain existing provisions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make just a couple of further comments on this amendment and on some of the broader issues. It is true that last financial year Australia Post made about $247 million profit, of which $62 million was paid as dividend to the Australian government as the shareholder on behalf of the Australian people. The rest of it was retained earnings to be used for reinvestment and to maintain and expand the service so as to provide the quality of service that the Australian public expect and, quite rightly in my view, demand.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has said—there is certain validity to its point in a way—that the government should forgo the $62 million dividend and that that be used to cover basically the cost of what I said was the $100 million forgone revenue. The opposition has to understand that what we have been trying to do over the last few years in Australia Post under our reforms of GBEs is change the culture away from that of being seen as a Public Service government department. These organisations need to be run on commercial lines. The staff should be able to get some credit, status and congratulations, in a sense, from being able to perform well in a commercial world. Like any other company, these organisations should have ability to pay a dividend to their shareholder. The dividend they pay is a measure of their success in the overall running of the operation.

Senator Ferguson has been a critic, to some extent, of another government area that I am responsible for—the Australian Customs Service. The Conroy review last year was all about culture change, and so on. We have had a significant culture change in Australia Post. I have only to go back 20 years to see the horrendous industrial relations problems in Australia Post. There were endless strikes. I am not apportioning blame to management, employees or the unions, but it was an endless dispute affecting the good standing of Australia Post, and the public were sick of it. There was a reduction in services. More and more services were being limited.

Over the last few years there has been a revolution in Australia Post in the services that it provides. Australia Post postmasters are now business managers. They are encouraged to go out and find new business and share in the profits, et cetera.

TALK.START.PARA: —We've encouraged that for years.

—Of course, you have. One of the consequences is that Australia Post should pay a dividend to the government because that is a measure of its success. If Australia Post does not pay the dividend because it is used for community service obligations or whatever, or in the old days in the form of a revenue gift to the government, I really think that is a bad sign for the culture of what we are trying to inculcate into Australia Post and other GBEs in other forms. I accept that members of the opposition have been supportive in many of these areas.

PARA.TAB: I think the opposition also has to balance this up a bit to show that there is a way in which Australia Post can provide some of those community service obligations by their own cross-subsidisation. If we are utterly ruthless about cross-subsidisation and eliminate it all, no matter how we pay back in increased community service obligations, I suspect that within the organisation people operating in the community service obligation area often will be seen as second-class employees. They will be seen as not providing the profit within the organisation.

If someone is seeking a promotion or a staff transfer and that person is put into the area of providing services to country areas, a losing area, one has to rely on the parliament appropriating money under the community service obligation every year for the area of that person's activity; whereas the future career prospects of the people who are down in the business district of a major capital city, where there is profit and where they are doing very well, will be measured differently or they would perceive that to be the case. So I think those opposite have to be a bit careful in effecting a holistic approach to Australia Post.

I was a senior private secretary to former Senator Reg Bishop, who was the last Postmaster-General of Australia when we broke up PMG into Telecom and Australia Post. That was a major reform at the time of the Whitlam government. Another major reform was in the mid-1980s with the adoption of the GBE approach. Those two major reforms have improved out of sight the provision of Australia Post services to the Australian public. I think everyone would recognise that.

Both management and employees in Australia Post have to be given great credit for the way that they have gone about accepting the need for a substantial cultural change. As Senator Ferguson would say, why not take the argument to its logical end or extreme and have no competition at all? That is not what we are about. We have to get a mixture of the competition with the public service.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what we are trying to do.

—We think those opposite are going a bit too far and that is why we reject the amendment. We think the substantial achievements of Australia Post are well recognised in this reform package. In our view the opposition wants to go a step too far. A bit like that old movie A Bridge Too Far, the opposition is going a step too far. What those opposite are doing is running into a couple of Nazi panzer divisions up the road which may affect the delivery of the service, particularly to Senator Ferguson's own constituents, considering his interest in rural South Australia. I think those opposite ought to be very carefully before they jump off that bridge. We ask the committee to reject the amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 11, page 5, paragraph (d), lines 1 to 15, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:
"(d)by omitting paragraph (1)(c) and substituting the following paragraph:
`(c)the carriage of a newspaper, magazine, book catalogue or leaflet, whether or not directed to a particular person or address and whether or not enclosed in any sort of cover;';".
Clause 11, pages 5 and 6, paragraph (k), proposed subsection 30(1A) and examples 1 to 3, line 34 (page 5) to line 13 (page 6), omit the subsection and the examples.
Clause 11, page 7, paragraph (1), lines 8 to 13, omit the paragraph.

These amendments seek to clarify the present act by exempting catalogues and leaflets and addressed envelopes and reserved services. The bill seeks to reserve the delivery of advertising material in addressed opaque envelopes from that exemption. This does not seem to us to be environmentally sound. We want the bill not to make plastic wrapping compulsory because most transparent plastic wrapping is not recyclable. Therefore, we do not think the proposal is very sensible. We want to make sure that paper envelopes could be used for this sort of mail.

PARA.TAB: In our opinion, our amendments preserve and clarify the present position that exists under the old act, but they do not go any further. Australia Post was concerned, when its representatives came to see us, that the amendment might allow an addressed form of letter to pass as a leaflet. That is certainly not our intention. I believe that with this amendment we have got that right.

Our amendments also remove the bundling provision and the definition of identical catalogues and leaflets on the grounds that they are redundant. The government believes that the laser etching of addresses onto catalogues and leaflets should and would be allowed. We endorse that interpretation as well. We certainly think that our amendments also achieve that goal. We hope that we have overcome what we thought were the legitimate problems that Streetfile, in particular, had.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not oppose the Australian Democrats' amendment to clause 11, paragraph (d), of the bill on the grounds that it maintains the status quo under the 1989 act. The government will not oppose it on the grounds that it will continue to exempt catalogues and leaflets from Australia Post's exclusive right to carry letters under section 29 of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989, irrespective of whether or how they are wrapped or whether a name and/or address is stamped, stuck or printed on any of the catalogues or leaflets or any of the wrappers of the catalogues or leaflets.

PARA.TAB: We will not oppose it on the grounds that it will continue to reserve to Australia Post the delivery of all letters, except where that letter is otherwise an exception to the reserved service under section 30 of the act. We will not oppose the amendment on the grounds that the reserved service will continue to include generic or pro-forma letters which contain identical text and will not prevent the enclosure or attachment of a single sheet, a flysheet or an address slip with a catalogue or leaflet, the sole purpose of which is to direct the item to a particular person or address.

Regarding clause 11, paragraph (1), as a consequence of the amendment to clause 11, paragraph (d): we are not opposing this on the grounds that the bundle of catalogues and/or leaflets with a letter attached to or included in one of the catalogues or leaflets in the bundle, or as part of the bundle, retains the status of a letter as defined in the act and is reserved to Australia Post unless another exemption in section 30 of the act applies. Regarding the Democrat amendment to clause 11(d), the Democrats also propose omitting proposed section 31(a) and the examples at the end of it. The government is not opposed to this consequential amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit surprised, because I have looked very closely at the wording of the Australian Democrats' amendments. There is very little difference between their amendments and ours. They may be phrased slightly differently and things may have been put in a few different places; but about the only difference I can see is that ours talks about conveying a unique message—
—Subtlety!
—It is very subtle. It seems strange to me that the government is now not opposing two of the clauses that it was most concerned about in the original—
—I think I explained that there is a significant difference between what you were on about with uniqueness and what the Democrats are proposing. We can live with that.

—I will just say that the opposition is prepared to accept that in order that these changes get through. It is just that it seems very strange that there should be so much angst for the government in the words `conveying a unique message', compared with the wording of the Democrats' amendments. I indicate that the opposition is also prepared to support the Democrats' amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 11, page 5, after paragraph (g), insert the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: `(ga)by inserting after subparagraph (1)(h)(ii) the following word and subparagraph;
"or (iii) a service centre of a document exchange service;".

This amendment relates to a service centre of a document exchange service. I say from the outset that all this amendment seeks is to allow document exchanges to continue to provide to members an end to end service by providing an exception to the reserved services for carriage of letters to or from a service centre of a document exchange.

PARA.TAB: This is an amendment that the opposition regards as most important to maintaining the provision of an existing service that is provided to people who use document exchanges, especially when we consider the volume of documents that are carried by document exchanges. In its submission to us at a public hearing, Ausdoc told us that it has in excess of 15,000 document exchange members, operating in more than 400 exchanges throughout Australia, including many rural and remote areas.

I think it is important that document exchanges be allowed to continue the existing practice—a practice which has not affected Australia Post to any great extent. As I said earlier, Australia Post still managed to make close to $247 million in profit last year. The work that is done by document exchanges is absolutely invaluable to their users. It is a daily service. It allows lawyers, accountants, insurance companies, and a lot of other business enterprises which require documents to be delivered with much speed, to carry out their work efficiently.

In evidence given to us people have said that in the long run Australia Post will not gain any benefit from the government not allowing this amendment to go through. As far as document exchanges are concerned, there are no addressees on the envelopes, there are only document exchange numbers. It would be an added expense for businesses to have to either collect documents from the exchanges or arrange for documents to be collected. By not allowing this amendment to go through the government will be placing an impediment on business, particularly those which require the use of document exchanges.

This method of transferring documents has grown over a number of years. Document exchanges are reliable, secure and speedy, providing a same day service. City businesses in particular use them, but I know of many legal firms and other businesses that use country document exchanges. The provision of an end to end user service is absolutely imperative if this service is to work as well as it should in the interests of the people who want to use it. They want to use this particular type of service because it relates to a specific sector of industry which requires the transfer of documents and the transfer of information on paper to be done in a very speedy way.

I cannot understand why the Australian Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. They claim that an end to end service is not expressly allowed in the principal act. The way things have been operating, certainly over the last year or two, an end to end service has been provided. I cannot see how we cannot allow an end to end service to continue to be provided to those people dealing with businesses, the costs of which we are trying to keep down.

We are trying to ensure that people involved in these sorts of areas are as competitive as possible. We talk about the high costs of legal services, accountancy firms and all those sorts of operations, and yet we are putting in their way a provision which would stop them keeping their costs down for consumers. I urge the Democrats to reconsider and support this amendment, which would allow the people who use document exchanges to have an end to end service, which currently is precluded under this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Ferguson said, this amendment would allow document exchanges to provide end to end transport for all mail. We have looked at it very long and hard and we have concluded that it raises the prospect that major courier firms could set up minimal document exchanges—say one in each capital city—for a limited number of large business customers. This would allow further erosion of Australia Post reserved services—particularly the transport of large volumes of mail between related companies.

PARA.TAB: We are aware that Ausdoc has offered end to end services for some time, and it is entitled to do so for mail which falls into the exemptions for reserved services. Ausdoc will still be able to do that after this bill is passed. However, it has not been entitled to do so for mail which falls into the reserved services. This fact has been made very clear to Ausdoc by Australia Post in the past. If end to end services have been operating outside the law for the last few years, that is not a good reason to make them legal now. In our view, this bill exposes a large slice of Australia Post's business to competition. It further deregulates the system and we are not going to support any amendments that allow for further deregulation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept the proposed amendment. I can agree with Senator Ferguson on one thing only: it is an important amendment because of the critical effect it will have on the postal service. We do not agree with the opposition's thrust.

PARA.TAB: The opposition wants to allow document exchanges to provide full end to end letter services. The result would be that, like Australia Post, they would become postal operators. They would be free to offer an end to end service without restriction. The document exchange would become a post office. The opposition also seems to want to advantage document exchanges in this respect, but no other postal operator. This is contrary to the government's policy approach in this area.

The argument that the risk to Australia Post's business is small is not correct. It is misleading for the opposition to claim that. Clearly, if the activity was to be legitimised in this legislation it would signal that there is a means of providing competition in end to end letter services. Such a service may be very attractive to the metropolitan carriage of addressed bulk mail, such as routine accounts and the like. This could result in considerable loss of business for Australia Post; it is estimated that it could be as high as $250 million in business mail. It would also put at risk the principle of universal service at a uniform price, as well as undercutting Australia Post's ability to maintain its community service obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point that the Parliamentary Secretary, for the government, and Senator Bourne, for the Democrats, are missing—or deliberately ignoring—in relation to this amendment is that our proposed amendment simply maintains an existing practice that developed under the previous legislation. We are not taking away from Australia Post anything that it currently does. In fact, if this amendment is not passed Australia Post will not pick up any additional business. What will simply happen is that an employee of the document exchange will have to deliver the document from the client to the document exchange, and from the document exchange to the client, or the clients themselves will have to do that.

PARA.TAB: It is simply denying the opportunity for those two particular legs in a process of document exchange to be contracted out to a private business to provide the service. It is increasing the costs to the business that wants to make use of the document exchange. If this amendment is passed, it will not result in a reduction of Australia Post's customer based income revenue. If it is not passed, it will not result in any increase in Australia Post's business and revenue. It will simply be an inconvenience, a cost, and an administrative burden to those who are using the document exchange.

In that sense this legislation will not in any way provide a benefit to Australia Post, but will cause difficulties and additional costs for the businesses that use the document exchange service. It therefore militates against making businesses as cost competitive as possible. That is the reason we have moved this amendment. Firstly, it will enable a more efficient use of document exchange services by those mainly professional organisations—lawyers, accountants and so on—that use this form of communication between their offices. Secondly, as I said, it will simply confirm existing practices. The fact that its doing that again reinforces the fact that Australia Post will lose nothing if this amendment is carried.

The legislation as drafted has the shortcoming of preventing couriers from acting as third parties to transport material between document exchanges and client companies. We have moved this amendment to overcome that shortcoming and it should be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reinforce one thing that Senator Chapman said. As I indicated earlier to Senator Bourne and to the government, not allowing this amendment through will not provide any extra revenue or business to Australia Post. The only thing it will do is provide an impediment to document exchanges like Ausdoc where the people who use those exchanges use them for two or three specific reasons. One of those reasons is speed of delivery. Although inconvenienced, they will still provide the end to end service by in many cases having the businesses pick up the documents themselves.

PARA.TAB: I am sorry that Senator Coulter is not present, because he was at the committee and heard very strong evidence from the representatives of Ausdoc as to how this would affect operations that have now existed for a considerable time. I am very sorry that the Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. While I understand the Democrats' concern that it might cause an expansion of small exchanges, there is no evidence to suggest that that will happen. I am very concerned about the effect this will have on the businesses that currently use document exchanges and have used them for a considerable time.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 11, page 6, paragraph (k), proposed subparagraph 30(1B)(c)(vi), line 34, omit the subparagraph, substitute the following paragraphs:
"(vi)any other unincorporated body; or

TAB.TAB: (vii)a group of bodies, whether the bodies are incorporated or not, that:
(A)are related bodies corporate within the meaning of the Corporations Act 1989; or
(B)have a common board of management; or
(C)carry on business or conduct operations under the same or substantially the same group name; and".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment deals with the definition of an organisation, as moved by Senator Alston on behalf of the opposition. It talks about letters carried between officers of an organisation. This is one of the other matters raised by those people who use document exchanges with regard to the definition of an organisation. They spent some time going through the difficulties that this bill will provide. Letters carried between offices of an organisation will be an exception to the reserved services under the provisions of the bill. However, the definition of `organisation' contained in the bill is excessively narrow. It will mean that many businesses and community groups will not be covered by the exemption.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe even governments.

—Maybe governments. Certainly departments of state governments—even Commonwealth departments—will be affected by this in that they will not be considered to be organisations. Because of the narrow definition given to `organisation', the government is in effect adding extra costs to its own ability to use exchanges.

PARA.TAB: The amendment seeks to extend the definition of the word `organisation' in the bill to include `related bodies corporate within the meaning of the Corporations Act 1989' or bodies with a common board of management' or bodies which `carry on business or conduct operations under the same or substantially the same group name'. This also is a very important amendment.

I have been led to believe that the Democrats will not be supporting the amendment. I am not sure as to the reasons why they will not support an amendment such as this. I will be interested to hear their reasons. When we consider there are a lot of organisations and companies which now cannot even have document exchanges between their different branches, we realise that an extreme penalty is being imposed.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 12.45, I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Walker—or, to use his correct title, the Hon. Frank Walker, QC—has announced an inquiry into the system of honours and awards in Australia. He has appointed a committee of what he describes as `eight distinguished Australians' to conduct the review. Mr Walker said:

SPEECH.PARA: The move follows criticism that the present system fails to recognise properly large sections of the community including women, migrants and the less affluent.
Mr Walker says that statistics support such criticisms. He went on to say:
The time has come to ask all Australians if they are satisfied with the present honours system introduced in 1975 when the Order of Australia, Bravery Decorations and the National Medal were created.
The government wants to hear all points of view before deciding if changes are necessary to better reflect the contributions made by all sections of the community.

I think the Australian community in fact knows very little about its honours system, and that is a pity. Indeed, I believe one of the reasons why women, migrants and the less affluent have not been reflected in the system is the lacklustre effort by a succession of Labor ministers to inform the Australian community about the honours system.

PARA.TAB: One of the recommendations of the report Women and the Order of Australia, released by Senator Reynolds in 1990, was that women's organisations have a unique responsibility to alert their members and encourage them to increase their nomination rate. I do not know if this report was followed through by Minister Walker or his predecessors. Certainly there was no mention of this report in Mr Walker's press conference. Indeed, the Reynolds report may point to the answer to one of the problems identified by Mr Walker. If nominations are not received, then the Council for the Order of Australia or the Decorations Advisory Committee, however composed, may find it difficult to address concerns about the numbers of women and migrants. It is interesting to note that in 1991 Mr Whitlam rejected any suggestion of quotas in the Order of Australia, saying that a political decision to set up quotas would `insult women'.

This inquiry can be used as an opportunity to build community awareness and address any problems relating to fairness and access, and examine the actions of the government in properly informing the community about the honours system. Society should bestow recognition on people who have made a special contribution to the community. Let me state what I see as the key principles which underlie any honours system.

First, the system must be seen to be fair and equitable. This avoids controversy regarding entitlements to awards. The transparency of the system by which awards are made helps build confidence in the Australian honours system. In relation to our system, it has to be said, there is very little controversy about awards when they are announced. This is in marked contrast to the United Kingdom, for example, where I understand almost every announcement of a new series of awards seems to lead to widespread public debate. It is important to underline that any individual or organisation may recommend any Australian for an award in the Order of Australia, thus making the process of appointment to the Order of Australia totally democratic and as egalitarian as most members in the community would want.

The second and related point I would like to make is that it is important that there should be a non-partisan approach to an award system. There is little point in every incoming government proposing major changes to the system. In this regard, it was clearly a mistake that Minister Walker made no attempt to consult with the coalition about the review, its terms of reference or its appointees. Indeed, there was no attempt to inform my office about the announcement. Even the courtesy of sending a press release was missing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator Sherry says, `Oh,' but a system of awards and honours is not a partisan project. It is a thing for all Australians and I would have thought that normal courtesies were appropriate. Indeed, it was a journalist who was kind enough to inform me about the announcement and send me the release. This might seem cute politics to Mr Walker but it is really a poor way to start such an inquiry.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, a system of awards should be non-partisan. Any attempt to use it for divisive political purposes will probably help ensure that any proposed changes are stillborn. There have been attempts to politicise the Order of Australia. In 1984, for example, there was a recommendation that awards should be recommended to the Governor-General by the Prime Minister and state premiers. Fortunately, this was overturned, thanks to the good work of the Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs. As Sir David Smith said in a speech in 1989:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . various attempts to compromise the independence of the Order by political intervention have failed . . . that the Order has achieved the degree of public acceptance that it enjoys today, is due to the efforts of our three Chancellors, each of whom has responded to the challenges which the Order has faced during his term of office, each of whom has taken seriously the responsibilities placed upon him by the Constitution of the Order, to be responsible for its administration.

I thought Mr Walker's comments as relayed on the Channel 9 news were singularly unhelpful in this regard. I must say that the minister's comments at the press conference can only arouse suspicions that there is a political agenda in the review—the desire to promote Labor's republic. I hope that is not the case and I would welcome his assurances on this matter, and the assurances of the chair of the review committee, that there will be no attempt to use the honours system to advance a political agenda.

PARA.TAB: What on earth did Mr Walker mean when he said that we need `a modern system that Australians own'? Who else owns the Australian honours system? Does he not know that the Australian honours system, the Order of Australia, was introduced by Mr Whitlam? The Labor Party may keep changing its mind about awards, but this I do not think reflects public opinion. Mr Walker must be the only person in the world who thinks the Australian honours system is owned by somebody else. I wonder if he knows that the system is administered by the Australian Honours Secretariat and that the awards are recommended by Australians.

In the terms of reference Mr Walker states that, except for the Order of Australia, the Australian system largely mirrors the British system. Let us face it, that is a pretty major exception for this review, which is in large part about the Order of Australia. When this is added to the fact that the defence decorations are also purely Australian—with the notable and honourable exception of the Victoria Cross—one wonders what Mr Walker is talking about. One of the functions of the committee I believe should be to inform Mr Walker about a few basic facts.

The third principle underlying an honours system I would have thought was the need for continuity. Continuity helps build respect for the system of awards. I think it is correct to say that the Australian honours system did take some time to achieve full community acceptance. Indeed, I think the standing of an honours system in part reflects its history. This does not mean that we should not have some finetuning. Of course we should. But to revamp radically a system which is barely 20 years old, as in some banana republic, could demean the honours which have already been awarded.

There are a number of observations I would like to make about the inquiry itself. I think there is a concern about the composition of the board. There is one senior public servant on the board, Michael Clarke, the Executive General Manager of Mr Walker's own department, the Department of Administrative Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good man, too: a Tasmanian.

—He is not known to me. Senator Sherry says he is a good man and I am sure he is a most worthy person but the minister puts public servants in a very invidious position by appointing them to such inquiries. Public servants could be placed in positions where they may face a major conflict of interests between the views which may emerge from an inquiry and those held by the minister. I believe it would be best if we have people on the inquiry who do not have this potential problem.

PARA.TAB: Mr Walker's press statement announced that the inquiry is to be chaired by Ms Claire Petre, a senior officer in the New South Wales Community Services Commission and a board member of the Administrative Review Council. We had to read in the Canberra Times that Ms Petre was a member of Mr Walker's staff when he was the New South Wales Attorney-General. I think the fact that this was not included in Mr Walker's press release has come as a bit of a surprise and led to some comment. To put Senator Sherry's mind at rest: this puts a special onus on Ms Petre to ensure that the committee is seen to be independent of the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it will be.
