—`And it will be,' says Senator Sherry, and I hope that is the case. As I mentioned earlier, there have been efforts to politicise the award system and this committee should be particularly careful to ensure that the barriers to politicisation are maintained. Judging from the minister's press release, there does not seem to be anybody on the committee who has a specific expertise in the area of honours. There seems to be no-one on the committee who has a close and detailed knowledge of the present system. I would have thought that at least one person on the inquiry should have such specific expertise. I think it has to be said that there are some concerns about the committee. The appointments that I have raised and the apparent lack of expertise in honours systems mean that the inquiry has not had a particularly good start if it is going to build community confidence.

PARA.TAB: It is not clear whether bravery decorations are included in the review. The press statement mentions bravery decorations but one reading of the terms of reference seems to suggest that they may not be included. I will be seeking further information from the committee on this matter. I think the minister himself has made some extraordinary comments which can only cause concern. Mr Walker describes these awards as not reflecting modern Australia. It is funny that no-one suggests that the Legion of Honour, which was established by Napoleon and survived the restoration of the Bourbons and a further four French republics, does not reflect modern France, a country whose artworks are so much admired by Mr Keating. The Order of Canada was created in 1967. Of course, that was one of the models for our Order of Australia system. I understand no-one is proposing any changes to the Canadian system.

We should not believe that our system happens to be wrong if it has a link to the past. Indeed, the French believe that this link is one of the strengths in their system. We must ask ourselves: are we not undermining the credibility and acceptance of the honours system if it keeps changing? Is not the better answer to promote and improve our existing system? Mr Walker revealed his true colours when he said, `I think the Governor-General has been doing a pretty good job so far in handing them out, but personally I would like to see a president doing it.' In the speech referred to above, Sir David Smith points out the important role the Governor-General has played in maintaining the system free of political interference.

I was asked by a TV interviewer whether political honours would be included in the review. This does not seem to be the case. It is a little rich for the Hon. Frank Walker, Queen's Counsel, to be critical of the British origins of awards. His two titles are rich in British history. If my memory serves me correctly, he was particularly anxious to obtain both the `Honourable' and the `Queen's Counsel'. The committee should avoid the plague of political correctness which is sweeping the land and the related sin of hypocrisy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter concerning Comcar driver Mr Dennis Reid and a letter which he had published in the Queanbeyan newspaper, South East Magazine, on 20 June 1994. The issue is an important one because it concerns the right of public servants who work in and around Parliament House to make public political comment even though they are in these positions. Mr Dennis Reid is also a local government councillor of some years standing on the Queanbeyan City Council and is a former deputy mayor. The letter published in the South East Magazine under the heading `A hard act to follow!' reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Sir.Senator O'Chee and Bob Katter both National Party members are a hard act to follow.

Bob Katter National Party MP and O'Chee (boy wonder) have, in my opinion, abused Parliamentary Privileges by their continued attack on retired Senator Graham Richardson over his issuing of a Shoalwater Bay Sand Mining Licence.
Have they a problem with the sand mining operations, that employ workers, or are they both `cupboard greenies' which we know lurk in the depths of the Nationals?
Surely they both realise that there are far more important issues to be debated other than Richardson's private life.
I will give you a clue, high fuel prices that we pay in the bush, against the pampered city folk who have ample public transport at foot.

The lack of specialised health services in country regions. The tariff cuts, subsidies to drought stricken areas. Get real about what you're on about, get on with the important issues that people face every day of their life!
Yours etc.
Dennis Reid
Queanbeyan.

The letter is strongly worded but that is not something unknown to people in public political debate, as senators in this chamber should know, and the sentiments expressed obviously could elicit a strong response. For the record, it will be apparent to senators that I do not agree with some of the implications of Mr Reid's statements in the letter.

PARA.TAB: But that is not the point. The issue is whether Mr Reid is entitled to make public political comment critical of parliamentary representatives even though he is employed as a casual Comcar driver and, in that position, is called upon to drive senators and members of the House of Representatives. Clearly, I would submit, the answer is yes, with only two exceptions which demand confidentiality. The first and foremost exception is information gathered from a conversation overheard in the car while transporting parliamentarians—or anyone else, for that matter. The second concerns matters which are confidential to the department served by the public servant—in this case Comcar or, in the broader context, the Department of Administrative Services. This latter area has been challenged to some extent by the whistleblower concept. However, that is a development which is irrelevant to the particular case I am raising.

It is perfectly clear that neither exception applies in relation to Mr Reid's letter and I am surprised that its publication attracted a complaint—in this case, from Senator O'Chee. To his credit, Mr Bob Katter did not lodge a complaint, as far as I could ascertain. I am somewhat surprised that Comcar management found it necessary to invite Mr Reid to a meeting where he was met by three high-level Comcar executives. From all accounts Mr Reid—not unnaturally, I would suggest—was a little taken aback and queried, `What is going on?' or words to that effect.

In answer to my letter to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) requesting confirmation of the right of public servants, including Comcar drivers, to exercise their right as citizens to engage in public political debate, the minister wrote as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: It was explained to Mr Reid very clearly that he certainly has every right to speak publicly or write letters but should understand that this could be perceived as a conflict of interest and in breach of the code of ethics to which public servants are expected to conform. In the case of drivers, this is particularly sensitive as an observer is likely to assume that he or she had the opportunity to have heard the information in the course of their employment.

I am delighted by the confirmation of public servants' rights but more than a little concerned by the implication that the exercise of these rights had best be avoided because someone could perceive such behaviour as a `conflict of interest' and `in breach of the code of ethics' of public servants.

PARA.TAB: I lay some stress on the word `perceive', because clearly in this case there was no breach of confidentiality. The matters raised in Mr Reid's letter—it does not matter whether one agrees or not—were on public record and clearly not overheard in the car. Yet somehow the suggestion is made that writing such a letter is behaviour that is undesirable and had best be avoided. I believe that the vast majority of members of this parliament would join me in rejecting such an implication. The minister's letter continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Reid was given the opportunity to discuss the situation with management but in doing so raised some separate concerns which need to be addressed.
The letter stated further:
Pending the outcome of the review, it is not appropriate to call on Mr Reid for work.

In the event, Mr Reid lost six weeks work. Not unexpectedly, the review that was carried out during that period confirmed what should have been obvious from the start—namely, that there was no evidence of a breach of confidentiality. In these circumstances I trust that Comcar management will find a way to compensate Mr Reid for this loss, in accordance with the suggestion made by his union representative that Comcar should do so.

PARA.TAB: Let me add a personal testimonial. I have had nothing but first-class, highly professional service from Mr Reid and, without exception, from all of his colleagues, be they casual or permanent drivers. I value that service very highly and regret the signs, which are becoming frequent, that the government is trying to starve Comcar out of existence. I hope I am wrong in that—it would be a most regrettable loss. This case is a good example. Even though I believe that Comcar management erred on the side of being overzealous, I believe also that it did so out of a desire to provide the best possible service to us at all times. It is, however, up to us parliamentarians to restore the balance—eagerly guarding our own rights, we must ensure that we do not trample on the rights of others, including the rights of those who assist us in our work.

In closing, let me give a bouquet not only to Comcar drivers but to all parliamentary staff. Having completed his law studies in Germany, my nephew Reinhart Liese is spending the current fortnight in my office looking us over. He has some knowledge of the workings of the German parliament and has offered the view that our staff is more efficient and more courteous than in the Bundestag, in Germany, and our parliament is functioning better than the Bundestag.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to give the fourth speech in a series dealing with the information superhighway and its implications for the future development of the Australian economy and Australian society. This parliament and the government must act decisively on a regulatory regime to focus and shape the new information age.

PARA.TAB: I had the privilege this time last week of attending a conference at the Australian National University on this subject. Listening to the government regulators and the people from Telecom, one would wonder whether they are aware of some of the vital issues that are facing us with the development of the information superhighway; and this is reflected in government action in this area. What the Labor government has done, particularly under the leadership of Senator Collins and Mr Lee, is just react to events as they happen. The government has a number of measures in place at the moment, but it is all happening too late, because by its very nature this technology is developing so rapidly that it is staying well ahead of the regulatory regime.

The ad hoc fashion in which the government is regulating this area is something we have seen before. Last year we had the pay TV debacle, media ownership rules and the problems with Telecom, and now, most recently of all, we have the problems with the ABC. These problems suddenly burst out into the public presence and the Senate scrambles around and sets up inquiries like the pay TV inquiry and the ABC inquiry. I can see that we might need to be in a similar circumstance very soon with the information superhighway if the government does not move into top speed in doing something about the regulatory framework.

The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has rather belatedly signalled a development in the area. He has set up the Broadband Services Expert Group, but that group is still deliberating and has not reported yet. He admits that technological change is upon us, and in his arts policy yesterday he more or less admitted that the technological changes are running well ahead of public policy. We have at the moment a whole set of regulations in different industries that are no longer appropriate. We have converging industries, and rules such as cross-media ownership should be revisited because in converging technologies they may no longer be appropriate.

I saw in the United States how far ahead of us the Americans are in this area. Not only are they moving rapidly to get the regulatory framework in place, but also a number of states have set up model developments which have the infrastructure well placed to deliver services right across particular states by the end of this century. I refer particularly to North Carolina and Iowa. In the case of North Carolina, all the population will have a nodal point from which people can access information on the information superhighway within 20 miles of them. Al Gore, the Vice-President of the United States, has been a major leader in this, and has called on all states to do this by the year 2000. They are moving—they are under way—and we are not seeing that sort of thing happening in Australia.

Let us see what the Broadband Services Group recommends. It has brought down a preliminary report and it is starting to discuss some of the major issues; but, unfortunately, while this process has been going on the technologies of computing and broadcasting and telephony are converging. The big companies that are involved—and I referred to this at some length in my last speech—are positioning themselves extremely well in the market to take account of this. It is quite possible that by the time we have a regulatory framework in place, it will be just too late.

I will give an example. In recent times, the big Packer-Murdoch-Telecom conglomerate suddenly broke up and the new Packer-Murdoch-Optus-Continental conglomerate was created. As well as international interests, two of the huge media magnates of Australia have come into this system. Guess what they have decided to do with their system? They have decided to make it a closed shop. They have said that only their services and the services they designate are going to run on it. Yet, in the United States, at the conference we attended last week and, indeed, in the Broadband Services Expert Group report, we are told that one of the central concepts of this sort of approach is open access. Given that we are only going to have two networks in this country—basically one dealing through Optus and one dealing through Telecom—one of them is already locked up. What is going to happen with Telecom? We do not know. We certainly do not know from this government because we do not have any guidelines or public policy principles that will show us.

This has all been coming for 10 years. It has all been seen for 10 years. We can look to other countries to see what has been happening there. We have a department of communications in this country, and yet there was no real recognition in the 1992 broadcasting act that this was all about to happen. However, two years down the track, it is all upon us. If the government had looked overseas, it would have seen it coming.

The marketplace, in its own right, is actually starting to respond and starting to get something right, even if the government cannot. It is very interesting that one of the huge computing networks that is now developing is coming out of the university sector, such as originally happened in the United States. The university sector has created AARNet, which is a link of the major university computing systems across Australia. The growth of that is now moving expedientially, as more and more people want to get onto the system. This is really the only viable network in this country. As it was said at the conference last week, AARNet is the only game in town. Not only a whole lot of Public Service providers but also private providers want to get onto this system. However, it is financed by public money; it was supposed to be free.

Where is the government in this sort of environment? We really need regulation, direction and leadership in this but the marketplace is scrambling around out there in a regulatory framework that is totally inappropriate with converging technologies. A number of basic principles of regulation need to be laid down. Uncertainty or bias in new regulations could inhibit investment and stall broadband network content. That sort of bias needs to be taken out of the system. Everyone agrees that the principle is universal access to information service for all customers and service providers. Before the government has even really got to the legislation, this has been seemingly trumped already by one of the big conglomerates.

Where private sectors cannot deliver, there is a real role for the government, for the community service obligation. We have had very little discussion of this. How is the community—particularly in remote rural areas and in some urban areas where there is very little access to this sort of thing—going to be guaranteed access? That is a fundamental principle.

Another principle is that we must encourage investment in this sector, and not just through the mega corporations that I mentioned before. Smaller companies should be allowed into the game. When two mega corporations run it, they can, as the Optus consortium has done, start to lock out small investment and private players. If this principle is followed, that should not be happening. It is a tragedy that it is happening, because in this country now we have a lot of people who could potentially build industries on this information superhighway but, because the regulations are too late, they are going to be cut out and industry that could grow is not going to grow at all.

There is a great need, therefore, to avoid the concentration of power and the development of a duopoly structure. We must try to avoid the haves and have-nots in rural and regional Australia, and I referred to this in detail in an earlier speech. Yet, as one of the senior executives of Telecom said in one revealing comment, `Yes, we are first linking up all the high density areas. We are working in Mosman; there are a lot of units there. We are getting that all linked up.' The most revealing comment he made was, `When we get the money and profit back from that, we are going to plough that into the next stage.' So the aim is to borrow as little as possible on what is pretty much a sure bet in terms of business development and to start ploughing money back in. That is going to be a very slow process. It is going to leave behind the people in the country areas in particular.

The government has not even really started developing the issue of privacy on the information superhighway. There are some very sophisticated electronic tapping devices with which people can delve into companies and what is happening in private conversations and what people are doing on the information superhighway. They talk in America about creating firewalls technologically between businesses and the prying eyes of people who are, to use that interesting expression, surfing the international superhighway and trying to find out information.

There is the whole issue of intellectual property rights. If someone creates information and puts it on the information superhighway, what sort of access to it do other people get? What sort of money do they pay the owners of the intellectual property? How do those people get that sort of money? All these issues are still out there and there needs to be a very firm set of regulations to make sure that all this happens properly. The law should be set up so that companies are treated similarly if they are in similar situations yet there is no guarantee that that will happen.

There must be an encouragement of basic community service obligations across the whole network but we are not hearing from the government exactly how it is going to do that. There should be a guarantee of access to the information superhighway through regulation to all public institutions so that all libraries, universities, galleries, museums and hospitals can have open access across the system. Again, we do not have a regulatory framework that will actually do that.

The greatest worry in the current developments to date is that that basic regulatory principle—that there are common carriers and access to those common carriers—has already been blocked by the Optus closed circuit deal. That is a great worry to this parliament.

I believe that particular case should trigger enormous concern across society that a new technological development that offers to usher in a new age of industry and social development in this country can be actually squashed and diminished because this government has not acted in time, has not planned for this change and has not got its regulatory act together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our President this morning set a precedent by sending a birthday cheerio. I would like to follow that precedent by sending one to our Deputy Clerk, Anne Lynch, who I note is at the table.

PARA.TAB: My purpose in rising this afternoon was not to sing birthday greetings but to debate and discuss the area of competition and market policy as outlined by the Hilmer report—in particular, as it relates to state governments. The federal government has been grossly hypocritical in its approach to this matter. While seeking to coerce and cajole the state governments into adopting an appropriate competitive policy, it is sheltering its mates from the sort of competition and commonsense approach that one would expect from Labor if it were fair dinkum.

As a Tasmanian senator, I am proud of the reforms that my state government has implemented under the excellent leadership of Ray Groom. The Tasmanian Liberal government is well down the reform track. The government has reformed my own profession. There is no longer compulsory membership of the Law Society of Tasmania; that profession has been deregulated. Other examples include the corporatisation of the Forestry Commission, the TT-Line and the Government Printer. My government has sold off the Tasmanian government insurance office and has transferred the government pathology services to the private sector. It has also undertaken considerable pro-competitive reforms to industrial relations.

The Hilmer report on principles of the national competition policy were initially considered at the last COAG meeting in my home state of Tasmania, in February this year. More recently, on Friday, 19 August 1994, a follow-up COAG meeting was held in Darwin. Micro-economic reform was one of the key items for discussion. It was quite clear that the Commonwealth would reap significant benefits from such reform through increased economic activity in the private sector and, as a result, increased taxation receipts. All that the states sought was a fair share of any such revenue increase to offset any loss of revenue that results from increased competition for state owned enterprises. It was, therefore, vital that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) provide an appropriate formula to share the financial benefits of the Commonwealth national competition policy reforms. Clearly, what the Prime Minister did was present the policy and seek to cajole and blackmail the states into supporting the proposal without giving the states the appropriate rewards for such an initiative.

It is interesting to note that the federal government itself has not seen fit to move on a number of important areas of micro-economic reform to ensure proper competition. For example, I can refer to the legal services provided by the Attorney-General's Department to the other areas of government. Although the government is paying lip-service to this issue, it is quite clear that it is allowing the Attorney-General's Department to enter into long-term agreements with other Public Service departments for ongoing provision of legal services, even after the cut-off time for the freeing up of legal services to the private sector. It was clear from the outset that the government would play lip-service and continue to provide protection for the public sector.

Honourable senators will be aware of the fuss that has been made lately about how the Attorney-General's Department is to be opened up to competition with private law firms and how the Commonwealth and the state governments are determined to expose themselves to the discipline of the Trade Practices Act. They even set up a separate entity called the Legal Practice to compete with the private sector for the business of the various Commonwealth departments and agencies.

The date for all this to take effect is 1 July 1995. The cabinet had wanted it to happen this year but a report from an interdepartmental committee that just happened to have a majority of officers from the Attorney-General's Department on it surprisingly persuaded Cabinet to wait until next year. In the meantime, I have learned that people from the Legal Practice have been going around signing up departments for the exclusive provision of legal services to the various Commonwealth departments and agencies. Of course, if companies were to do this kind of thing, they would most likely be in breach of the Trade Practices Act.

I asked for a copy of these agreements, but was told that to be given them would seriously erode the Legal Practice's competitive position. Then I put a question on notice to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) as a follow-up. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Has the part of the Department known as The Legal Practice sought authorisation from the Trade Practices Commission for it to enter into contracts, arrangements or understandings with the Department of Defence and a number of other Commonwealth departments or agencies, or otherwise sought a ruling for the commission in relation to the matter; if so, when were the relevant authorisations or rulings provided; if not, why not.
What was the answer? I will read the relevant bit, which states:

In respect of the arrangements between the Legal Practice and the Department of Defence and other Commonwealth departments and agencies in relation to the exclusive provision of legal services I am advised that no authorisation has been sought from the Trade Practices Commission because it is considered that the Trade Practices Act 1974 has no application to those arrangements because they are, in effect, internal administrative arrangements for the provision by the Commonwealth of legal services to other emanations of the Commonwealth.

Honourable senators should consider carefully the implications of this answer. What the Attorney-General is saying is that competition is okay for everyone else but, when it comes to the Commonwealth government's lawyer public servants, different rules apply. These collusive agreements are just `internal administrative arrangements for the provision by the Commonwealth of legal services to other emanations of the Commonwealth' if we are to believe the Attorney. That is, I suppose, one view of the law. But I invite the Senate to consider what the Trade Practices Act actually says. Section 2A states:
. . . this Act binds the Crown in right of the Commonwealth in so far as the Crown in right of the Commonwealth carries on a business, either directly or by an authority of the Commonwealth.
It goes on to say:
. . . this Act applies as if . . . the Commonwealth, in so far as it carries on a business otherwise than by an authority of the Commonwealth . . . were a corporation.
There is nothing in the act about emanations of the Commonwealth. I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General (Senator Bolkus) who gave this advice, and whether he stands by it.

PARA.TAB: More to the point, I remind the government of the competition principles agreement. Clause 3(1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Government businesses should not enjoy any net competitive advantage simply as a result of their public sector ownership.

The Attorney-General's reply to my question flies directly in the face of this principle. It reveals a situation where the government says one thing about competition—and what everyone else should do—but something else about all its so-called commercialised activities. It shows that the government is anything but fair dinkum when it comes to opening Commonwealth services to true competition.

PARA.TAB: If we turn to the area of industrial relations we see exactly the same sort of policy being pursued by Labor. A major area in glaring need of greater competition is our highly regulated and anti-competitive labour markets. Since its re-election in March 1993, the Labor government has reduced competition in the labour market areas.

The principles which the Prime Minister so rightly asks the states to embrace and which are contained in the Hilmer report were totally absent when his soulmate Laurie Brereton wrote the Industrial Relations Reform Act last year. That act, along with other initiatives, was an absolutely unprincipled cave-in to the vested interests represented by the ACTU, which is the senior partner in the Labor government. It was simply an election payback for services rendered and moneys provided. The removal of sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act further highlights that point.

Another area where the federal government has failed with regard to competition is its operation known as Asset Services. At the many national organisational meetings within the building and maintenance industry in Australia, concern has been voiced at the insidious competition by Asset Services against private enterprises. Asset Services competes with the private sector for the installation, maintenance and alteration of buildings, without being required to submit competitive prices. That is, government instrumentalities are accepting prices direct from Asset Services without any further prices being required or obtained from competitors in private enterprise.

This practice, quite frankly, is unbelievable. Yet it is being allowed to be perpetuated by the Labor government, the same Labor government that seeks to sermonise, lecture and pontificate concerning the way the states ought to operate themselves. No private enterprise in Australia is put in this sweetheart position of giving prices to one of the Commonwealth or State government agencies without having to compete with other contractors. This is an unbelievable, uncompetitive and unacceptable position.

It is on the public record from the general manager of Asset Services Australia that Asset Services does not pay payroll tax. Asset Services does not pay fuel excise tax, Asset Services pays no sales tax on vehicles where the client department is exempt and Asset Services pays no financial institutions duty cost to its bankers, the Reserve Bank. In all these areas it has an unfair advantage over its private enterprise competitors. Private enterprise is loath to invest and compete when it does not get asked to price, and if it is asked to price it cannot win. In these circumstances, how can private enterprise accept any responsibility towards increasing employment? In the true Australian tradition, all that is being requested by private enterprise is that Asset Services be made to give other Australian firms a fair go.

So much for the Prime Minister's call for the states to get with it and become competitive. Why does he not do it with his own enterprises over which he has control; why does he not do it with the trade union movement over which he has control; or do they control him? Labor calls on the states to cut expenditure but itself expands expenditure. Mr Keating and the Labor government need to learn that what is good for the state goose should also be good for the Commonwealth gander. At the end of the day, national leadership is shown not by the way the Labor government forces, blackmails and cajoles the states into submission, but rather by the actions it takes for and on its own behalf in relation to the areas that it appropriately has jurisdiction over. Labor's actions speak a lot louder than its words.

TALK.START.PARA: —Early this year the Brisbane retailer McDonnell and East closed its doors for the last time after a century of trading in Queensland. The last of the employees had to endure not only the pain of losing their jobs and livelihoods but also the prospect of receiving only a minor fraction of their superannuation entitlements. While the purpose of superannuation is to provide an adequate income in retirement, this nest egg may also be a financial safety net for retrenched employees who are faced with bills and mortgages to pay but have no income with which to pay them.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, 35 former McDonnell and East employees were faced with this very situation but the superannuation safety net for them was missing. The question here is: who is responsible for the $500,000 deficiency in the superannuation fund? This amount represents 65 per cent of the benefits owing to those 35 unfortunate members. How was the fund allowed to get into such a seriously underfunded situation? It seems to me that either no-one was minding the shop, or those who were supposed to be minding the shop were not doing their job properly.

Let us then take a look at who should have been minding the shop. There are generally at least five parties who play a direct role in managing and investing fund assets, or oversighting those activities. So which of the five parties have failed to do the shop-minding job in the McDonnell and East case? I have been following media reports on this case and honourable senators will not be surprised to learn that not one of the parties involved has stood up and said, `Sorry, it's our fault.' On the contrary, they have either remained silent or have denied responsibility for the funding shortfall. The responses of the trustees and fund manager to media reports are particularly interesting.

In June 1990, all the assets of the North Quay Ltd—owner of McDonnell and East—in-house superannuation fund were transferred to division one of the Norsec superannuation benefit plan. The trustee of Norsec at that time was Burns Philp, but was replaced by Permanent Trustee Company Ltd by court order in October 1990. Permanent was the trustee at all times after that date.

The chamber can therefore imagine my surprise when I found that in a letter to the editor of the Australian Financial Review on 14 February 1994 the managing director of Permanent Trustee claimed that his company is not trustee of the superannuation fund that held the assets of the McDonnell and East members, but rather the assets were held in the North Quay superannuation fund and the trustees are the officers of North Quay Ltd. That fund had invested assets in the Norsec fund. This may sound very confusing—it is. As far as I know, the so-called North Quay superannuation fund does not exist.

It is also quite clear that North Quay was a participant in division 1 of the Norsec superannuation fund. The McDonnell and East employees were members of that fund and, as such, Permanent Trustee Co. Ltd had trustee obligations to those members. The 35 former McDonnell and East employees who have suffered substantial losses can take little comfort from the knowledge that the trustee which was supposed to be exercising all due diligence and vigilance in carrying out its functions and duties in watching the rights and interests of the participants and members appears to deny that it ever had such a responsibility.

The reaction of the fund manager to a further media report is even more interesting. The fund manager was Northern Securities Management Ltd until 1993, when its name was changed to Peregrine Investments Management Australia Ltd. An article published in the May 1994 edition of Superfunds suggests that, contrary to earlier reports, North Quay's financial difficulties were not the main cause of the superannuation fund deficiency, rather the shortfall was largely attributable to the nature of the investment strategy adopted by the trustee and fund manager.

Based on information and documents presented at an Industrial Relations Commission hearing, the authors of the article state that, for the period since North Quay joined the Norsec super plan, the fund had suffered approximately $500,000 loss on the market value of investments; a major proportion of the fund's assets were invested in unlisted property trusts; the investment strategy deviated from the investment authority given by North Quay; and that, by exceeding covenanted levels of investments in associated trusts, the fund was in breach of the trust deed and the Corporations Law. This led to the auditor issuing a qualified audit opinion on the funds accounts. It is noted that those property trusts were also managed by Northern Securities/ Peregrine, for which Permanent also acted as trustee.

It is obvious that Peregrine took exception to the article, if the letter from Peregrine's managing director to the editor, published in the August 1994 issue of Superfunds, is anything to go by. In that letter Mr Meek claimed that the May 1994 article contained factual inaccuracies regarding the role of the manager and that the opinions of the authors were based on inadequate assessment of the relevant material. I would like to take some time to examine the points raised by Mr Meek to see whether we are able to gain an insight into what the real facts might be.

The first point is to do with the original investment authority given by North Quay which requested that superannuation fund assets be invested in the market linked option. North Quay management understood this option to include 45 per cent invested in capital guaranteed products and 17 per cent in each of the two Norsec property trusts. When members of North Quay management received the financial reports for the first 12 months in the Norsec fund, they saw that 80 per cent of the fund assets were invested in the Norsec property trusts and they sought an explanation for this deviation.

At that time, Northern Securities' response was that the large number of payouts to retrenched McDonnell and East employees had caused an imbalance in the asset mix and action was being taken to adjust the asset allocations. However, it turns out that the superannuation fund was then stuck with a high proportion of investments in the property trusts because in July 1991 the government imposed a 12-month freeze on unlisted property trust unit redemptions.

In his letter to the editor, Mr Meek claims that the Superfunds article implied that Northern Securities had misled North Quay in relation to the timing of any alteration to the asset allocation. He claims that this is a fallacious suggestion and makes a number of points about the circumstances surrounding the superannuation funds investment mix, defending the actions of Northern Securities. These comments bear closer examination because I believe that the superannuation fund's financial problems stem from the first 12 months of operation. Explanations of the events occurring within that period probably hold the key to who is responsible for the funding deficiency. I will therefore address the points made by Mr Meek.

Mr Meek states that the asset allocation for the investment authority given by North Quay was indicative only, and the original investments were made in accordance with the indicative allocation. An examination of the Norsec super fund's June 1991 financial statements confirms that this was so: about 17 per cent, a total of $750,000, was invested in each of the two Norsec property trusts. However, 12 months later the financial statements show that this percentage had blown out to 80 per cent. As I mentioned earlier, at the time the fund manager's explanation for this was an imbalance in the investment mix caused by a high number of payouts to terminated employees. Mr Meek also refers to the payouts placing `undue strain on the liquidity and investment structure of the fund'. However, a closer examination of the financial statements shows that there is an inconsistency between this explanation and what actually happened.

The accounts show that, some time between June 1990 and June 1991, the dollar amount of investments in the property trusts increased by $457,000. So some time in that 12-month period, someone disregarded the indicative investment authority and transferred almost half a million dollars of the superannuation fund's assets from the capital guaranteed investment to the property trusts. Therefore, the reason that the property trust investments jumped from 34 per cent to 80 per cent was not solely high levels of benefit payouts but largely the deliberate action of the trustee and/or fund manager to reduce the proportion of lower risk capital guaranteed investments and increase the proportion of the higher risk property trust investments. A number of critical questions arise here. I do not have time to answer all of those questions. There are many other points I would like to make but time prohibits me from going into those.

The last of the players in this sorry saga whose role needs to be examined is the employer. I have already referred to the employer a number of times when discussing the role of other players. I make the general comment that the employer clearly should have been more vigilant in monitoring the investment and performance of the superannuation fund. I also make a specific comment that relates to a possible conflict of interest. From the time that the McDonnell and East employees' superannuation moneys were transferred to division 1 of the Norsec superannuation benefit plan in June 1990, to November 1992, there was an individual—Barry Maranta—who was a director on the boards of both the employer, North Quay Ltd, and the fund manager, Northern Securities Management Ltd. The question is: did this common directorship play any part in the decision making with regard to the investment strategy adopted by the superannuation fund, changes to that strategy and changes to North Quay's investment authority?

If public confidence in superannuation as a secure means of saving for retirement is to be maintained, it is important that controls are put in place that help to avoid such situations and, when such cases do arise, ensure that swift remedies are available for members to recoup losses.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table a document which I have received from the Premier of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief comments as to why I am asking to table this document. As the chairman of the Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing, I forwarded a copy of the committee's report to all the premiers in Australia, asking them to look at the recommendations that may be appropriate to their states, particularly the need for complementary state and federal legislation. In the case of Queensland, there was also a recommendation that certain cases might be looked at once again.

PARA.TAB: I have now received a response from several of the premiers saying that they are looking into it but, in this case, the Premier of Queensland has gone to some lengths to respond to the committee's report. He has advised me that the Queensland government will be introducing comprehensive whistleblowers legislation into the state parliament in the October sittings. He sets out some of the details of interest of that legislation and he also responds to the recommendation about further inquiries relating to Queensland cases that were brought to our attention. As it was a select committee and is no longer in existence, I feel that the appropriate thing to do is to table, for the interest of honourable senators, the Premier's response to a very important national report.

(a)That discussion of matters of public interest be not further proceeded with this day.
(b)That intervening business be postponed until after consideration of Government Business order of the day no. 10—Student Assistance (Budget Matters) Amendment Bill 1994.
(c)That this order have effect till not later than 2 p.m. this day.
Debate resumed from 20 September, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Student Assistance (Budget Matters) Amendment Bill 1994 makes two changes to Austudy and Abstudy provisions. It changes the rules so that if students receive Austudy or Abstudy after 1995, they can repay all or part of it so that they can have more room to take out a bigger Austudy or Abstudy loan supplement. The second change means the supplement will be available to students who have missed out on Austudy and Abstudy because of the income of their spouses. If that income is below $35,000 a year, students will be able to borrow up to $7,000 per year to supplement their income.

PARA.TAB: The whole notion of this bill is for the government to make more money from low income earners. At a time when the `r' has been taken out of free education, the government is now trying to expand the loans scheme to people who might be a little more reliable in paying it back.Currently, a student has to be an Austudy or Abstudy recipient to get the option of a loan. The student trades in up to $3,500 of the money that is meant to be government assistance for $7,000 worth of debt per year. What a deal! Of course, if a student cannot manage on Austudy, which is way below the poverty line, then any bad financial offer looks attractive, and so the supplement as an option becomes no option for those who are poor enough.

The government could change all this by providing parity between the dole and Austudy by adding a rent assistance component of up to $30 per week to Austudy. This would especially aid the students on the east coast of Australia who have to pay the greater part of their Austudy in rent. This lack of rent assistance has resulted in at least 185,000 students experiencing housing related poverty. That estimate emanates from the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

These 185,000 students, who are below the poverty line, borrowed a staggering $160 million in 1994-95, which DEET estimates that they would not have borrowed had they received rent assistance. This is a clear example of the federal government trying to make $160 million, with interest, from the poorest students who enter higher education in this country. The government consistently looks at the Austudy loans supplement scheme to get more and more people off Austudy and onto the loans, which is just another way of saying `fees.' It is for this reason that the Greens will not be voting for this bill on principle.

The burden of costs for students is burgeoning. Not only do students currently have minimum HECS debts over three years of $8,000 each when they graduate from university, but if they take out an Austudy loan over that time they will also have a $30,000 debt before they even start their working life.The government does not want to stop there, though, and is currently looking at the private funding option in the DEET working paper, Resources allocation in higher education. If this recommendation is adopted, each student, regardless of HECS and loans debts, will be required to pay one-off, up—front fees of between $500 and $1000.

I move to the amendments proposed by the Democrats and the opposition. The opposition's amendments are much narrower than the Democrats' and are only for families in exceptional circumstances. The Greens, however, would like to see there be Austudy for low income families regardless of assets tests for all farmers. There is not a major government outlay, and the lack of Austudy to such families is a major barrier for rural students to take the plunge and move to the cities to study.

The opposition's amendment has left much of the detail up to the regulations and the amendment, as it is written, does not convey the intention that has been verbally communicated to us about this Austudy provision being drought specific. It is broader than that in that the amendment says that Austudy will be provided for students of families in exceptional circumstances for a specified period of time.

The Greens would prefer to see the Democrats' amendment adopted, which would enable all low income rural families to access Austudy despite their assets. This would be a more permanent gesture towards the rural population and fix an anomaly we have all felt for a long time. It is not before time that we make such a change, as this was a long awaited budget promise from 1993-94, which the government unkindly reneged on. I hope we can rectify this reversal of a government promise today. I trust that all senators will give this motion their serious consideration. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of motion, add "but the Senate:

PARA.TAB: (a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) estimates that at least 185,000 students are suffering housing-related poverty because they are receiving full Austudy and Abstudy rates which hold them below the poverty line, and
(ii)that those 185,000 students borrowed a staggering $160 million in 1994 and DEET has estimated that low income students would not have borrowed this money had they been receiving rent assistance;

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government to immediately extend rent assistance to students receiving the independent or away from home rates of Austudy or Abstudy which will also avoid the need for low income students to place themselves heavily in debt in order to obtain a tertiary education; and
(c)resolves that there be laid on the table, by the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, on or before the first sitting day in 1995, a report which states:

TAB.TAB: (i)what action the Minister has taken to investigate programs to extend rent assistance to students;
(ii)the results of those investigations; and
(iii)the Government's proposals to address the urgent need to establish such programs."

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Robert Ray will be absent from question time today and tomorrow to enable him to represent the Prime Minister at the 50th anniversary celebrations of the Leyte Gulf landings. I will answer questions relating to defence. Questions on industrial relations and tourism should be directed to Senator Cook.

—I should indicate that Senator Hill has a better excuse than some of my colleagues, perhaps, having been detained in Sydney. In those circumstances, I ask the first question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's predilection for the politics of hyperbole, which scaled new heights yesterday when he claimed that no government has ever delivered a national cultural policy on anything like these dimensions. In view of this apparently serious self-assessment, was the Prime Minister disappointed that he did not receive a standing ovation for yesterday's performance?

—That is one of the more comprehensively pathetic contributions from Senator Alston, and I do not think Senator Hill need to worry about staying away permanently from the chamber. There is no chance of even him losing out on his job if that is the best that can be done.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister is delighted with the reaction, as is the government, to the cultural statement, which is one of the most comprehensive—if not the most comprehensive—statements ever made about our national aspirations and ways of realising them. It covers an enormous spectrum of important new, innovative activity, not only so far as the major arts organisations and familiar ones are concerned but so far as the creation of a number of new institutions: the national indigenous people's dance institute and the performing arts centre in Queensland; the proposed new gallery of Aboriginal art here in Canberra; the proposed new academy of music in Melbourne; and the steps that are taken to substantially increase, of course, the funding of the Australia Council so as to enable the benefits of government support to extend to a very wide range of artists right across the spectrum of literary, visual and performing arts.

Moreover, a number of measures are to be taken to increase the accessibility of major arts events and performances to the Australian public at large through many more dollars being available for touring performances by those companies and many more opportunities for access, as a result, by Australians in many parts of the country.

The part of the statement with which I am particularly pleased is the $7 million that has been allocated for external promotion of Australian culture abroad in the form of $4 million worth of support for touring overseas by major performing companies with associated visual arts exhibitions and, in addition, a provision of $3 million being made for the continuation of the pattern that we have established in recent years of major integrated promotions in particular target countries following on from what we have done successively in Korea, Japan and Indonesia.

This is a hugely important package, and one of the things that makes it so distinctive and innovative in its character is the fact that it not only does all those things but goes beyond what has been regarded as the traditional reach of cultural or arts statements and has gone into the realm of new technology—innovative technology, multimedia—and support for the new kinds of contributions that are going to be made through the film and television industry and through the computer industry and people preparing material for those industries in the new information superhighway and elsewhere.

This is what the statement is all about. It is ahead of the game; it is ahead of the cutting edge of technology; it is ahead even of people's perceptions hitherto of what arts policy should be about. It is $252 million worth over four years of comprehensive, innovative and sensitive advancement of Australia's interest. Under those circumstances, for it to get the put-down that it gets from the opposition is just yet another demonstration of how flat-footed, as well as incompetent and insensitive to national aspirations, this opposition is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I noticed in that soporific response that the minister did not demur from the proposition about the lack of a standing ovation for the Prime Minister's performance. In those circumstances can he explain why the Prime Minister's wife publicly expressed disappointment to that effect?

—I am not aware of any comment that might have been made by Annita Keating or anyone else about that. I know that the performance yesterday had a rapturous response from those who were there from the arts community. There was an awful lot to digest and absorb, an awful lot of new information coming at them. They were very impressed indeed, as the opposition will find out when it deals with the responses to this from the arts community and the Australian public when it next faces the barrier, and may it be soon.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Residency English Test: Chinese Students

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Is the minister aware that about 200 Chinese students protested on the steps of the Victorian parliament last Sunday? Is the minister aware that this protest concerned certain aspects of the Australian government's decisions made on 1 November on matters relating to Australian residency for citizens of foreign states, in particular, the need to pass an English test? Is the minister also aware of the calls by some Chinese students for a boycott of the English test? Does the minister intend to alter the requirements of the 1 November decisions to dispense with the English test?

—Mr President, I am aware that demonstrations were held by some members of the Chinese student community in Melbourne on the weekend. I am also aware of the fact that about 550 people signed a petition objecting to the need for applicants for a class 816 visa to pass an English test. Senator Carr rightly refers to the 1 November 1993 decision. As the Senate would be aware, class 816 is one of four new visa classes which I announced on 1 November 1993. As I made it very clear at that time—and I reiterate now—the announcements do not amount to a general amnesty for all Chinese students.

PARA.TAB: I also place on record the fact that since 1 November last year more than 40,000 PRC nationals have applied for permanent residence under the classes announced on 1 November 1993. By 7 October, just on 14,000 had been successful under visa class 815. Of these, all but 500 are students who had arrived before the Tiananmen Square massacre on 20 June 1989, and their dependants. This was the group to which Prime Minister Hawke gave an undertaking that they would not be forced to return to China against their will.

On 1 November 1993 we also made announcements in respect of students who arrived in Australia after Tiananmen Square. They had not been given any such undertaking. However, they were allowed access to classes 816 and 818 permanent residence permits, which, of course, are available not only to people of Chinese background but to people of all nationalities. Those granted residence in the 816 category, as was announced then and still operates, must have lodged applications for refugee status on or before 1 November 1993. They also had to meet certain eligibility criteria related to age, qualifications and English language ability, and they were also counted against the skills component of the annual migration program.

It is important to remember in this context that all others who come to Australia as a skills migrant need certain qualifications which have a direct effect on their ability to live and work here successfully. They need to pass a points test. In doing so, they also have to cover age, qualifications and English language ability.

The level of English that we require in the 816 visa class is an ability to communicate in a mix of social and work situations. In that context, one of the factors I took into account when deciding on the 816 category was that the vast majority of applicants in this class would already have lived in Australia for a number of years. So it is reasonable to expect they would have acquired some English language skills in that time. I think that is particularly so for those Chinese students who came here with the express purpose of learning English. I made it quite clear on 1 November last year that English language skills would be a criterion in this visa class. No-one criticised it at the time. In the last few months my department has explained the requirement in great detail to interested community members.

I have said on numerous occasions that the government has no intention of changing the requirement for 816 applicants to sit for an English test. About 8,000 people will do so in the first week of November at locations across Australia and I expect that, given the time that these people have spent in Australia, a large proportion will have no trouble in passing the test. Those who fail will have the opportunity to sit the test a second time.

I should say in respect to the last part of Senator Carr's question that talk of a boycott is irresponsible and reckless. Boycotting will only reduce an applicant's capacity to pass the test and it will only reduce an applicant's chances of staying in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of several ministers' warm endorsements of Mr John Prescott's views that an increase in interest rates is unnecessary, can the minister give an undertaking that there will be no further increases in official interest rates and mortgage rates between now and Christmas?

—What Mr Crean and many other ministers, or several other ministers I think, have said, as I have said, is that Australia's economic fundamentals are such that the long-term interest rates, bond rates, in this country do seem at odds with that particular situation and it is very difficult to understand why the Australian markets in that respect should be, as I said yesterday, so spooked by what are, basically, developments overseas which have no likelihood of having a direct or immediate impact on Australian rates.

PARA.TAB: So far as the more immediate interest rate situation is concerned, what Mr Crean and others have been saying is no more than that monetary policy should be set in this respect—again, according to real fundamentals—not according to knee-jerk reactions, not based simply on people's expectations or advocacy of a response for response's sake rather than economic necessity.

Of course, it is the case that it may be necessary for official interest rates to be further adjusted, as appropriate, to reduce the risk of the economy overheating 12 to 18 months out. But if we continue to make such adjustments as are necessary in this respect, such an approach will of course mean that interest rates will not need to rise to anything like the same extent as they have in past cycles. That is a point that has been made over and over again. It is not being suggested for a moment that it is not likely that there will not be some further increase in interest rates as the economy takes off. That was always anticipated.

The important thing is to make those increases small and timely in such a way that we can ensure that we do not have the environment bursting away as it has in the past. We certainly expect the cycle to be under much better control in that sense than was the case in the past and that will continue to be so, so long as we respond in a measured way to the stimuli as they arise and have regard throughout our consideration—this is true, of course, for the Reserve Bank too—to the real fundamentals in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I was only speaking about a fairly short span of time—between now and Christmas. So, given what John Prescott has said, given that several ministers have endorsed that, and given that we are talking about the short term, can the minister please categorically assure the people of Australia that there will be no rise in official interest rates or mortgage rates between now and Christmas?
—Mr President, I have nothing to add to my previous answer. I have responded to that already.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. The Age reports on its front page today that Ms Philippa Smith, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, has raised the issue of untoward examinations, including body searches, carried out by Australian Customs officers on people arriving in Australia. Has the minister addressed this issue in any way and, if so, what way?

—Mr President, I am aware of the report in the paper. Of course, the Commonwealth Ombudsman's report for 1993-94, which was tabled yesterday, amongst other comments did have a section on Customs and about the use of searches of people coming through the barrier, as it is called, at airports.

PARA.TAB: I think the remarks of the ombudsman were constructive and indicate that, in her discussions with Customs, there has been a positive response from Customs in looking at all ways to ensure that the intent of the legislation passed by this parliament is effectively carried out. This means there is a balance between treating people and their normal civil liberties. Senator Cooney has a long history in this place of being a protector of civil liberties of the citizenry. That is recognised, and it is appropriate that he asked this question.

Also, this parliament has passed legislation empowering customs officers to carry out various forms of searches at the barrier when people are entering Australia. In 1991, this parliament carried legislation unanimously, I think, to enable officers to carry out what is called a frisk search. It is an informal search of padding of the passengers, carried out by someone of the same sex, who usually looks for things that can be removed from their person without any difficulty. Then there are the other two types of searches: the external search and the internal search. Both these searches require authorisation by either a senior officer of Customs or a judicial officer. There are very strict procedures.

The ombudsman has raised the issue that people subjected to these searches were not properly informed at times of their full rights. That is a matter of concern to me, and I will have discussions with the Customs administration to ensure that all those rights are brought to the attention of the individuals concerned. I want to assure Senator Cooney that that is a matter of concern to me. I already note that in the ombudsman's report there has been a positive response from Customs on those issues she has raised.

Many honourable senators, on behalf of constituents, from time to time write to me complaining about the operation of the barrier and of customs officers in the way they carry out their searches and duties. This is a very vexed area. Honourable senators have to recognise that since, for example, the frisk search was adopted more than 30 million people have passed through the barrier in Australia, of whom only nine have complained to the ombudsman. It is a very large number. Further to those nine, I probably deal with several scores of queries a year as the minister for Customs. There is a very thorough review of every one of those complaints from the public, particularly from members of parliament on behalf of their constituents.

I think it should be recognised that people arriving at the airport have often been on a plane for 30-odd hours or more and are probably lacking sleep or are a bit short-tempered. Of course, they want to get through customs as quickly as possible and that often leads to some angst accordingly. But we have to carry out the laws as prescribed by the parliament to protect the barrier, and we will continue to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. At the meeting of the Basel Convention in March, did Australia assent to a consensus decision to cease totally the export of hazardous materials to non-OECD countries for recycling by December 31, 1997, in short, to close the recycling loophole? Is Australia now attempting to negotiate the continued export of hazardous waste to non-OECD countries such as India after 1997? Finally, will the minister give an assurance that after December 31, 1997 no toxic metalliferous waste such as lead acid batteries will be exported from Australia to non-OECD countries, either for disposal or recycling?

—At the second conference of parties to the Basel Convention in March, Australia did, indeed, join a consensus to phase out by the end of 1997 the export of hazardous waste from OECD to non-OECD countries for recycling or recovery. At the conference, we did seek to retain more flexibility with regard to a ban than other countries were willing to accept. In seeking a more limited ban, which would have specifically allowed a window for properly regulated trade and hazardous recoverables between OECD and non-OECD countries, Australia was not trying in any way to defend environmentally unsound practices or to preserve opportunities to dump its wastes on others. A major concern rather was that the OECD/non-OECD distinction is not manifestly ideally suited to this part of the world where very few countries are members of the OECD.

PARA.TAB: We were also concerned that, in the absence of effective arrangements for managing hazardous waste, the decision would do little to protect vulnerable countries from trade between non-OECD countries. At the present time, we are of the view that no firm decision should be taken concerning the implementation of that decision until there have been consultations with our non-OECD regional trading partners. To that end, bilateral discussions with our trading partners commenced this week. A delegation is currently visiting India, China, Japan and South Korea with our trading partners.

To answer Senator Coulter's second question, Australia is not attempting to negotiate the continued export of hazardous waste to non-OECD countries, such as India, after 1997. The purpose of the visits that are currently being made by the Australian delegation to the region is simply to collect information on the management of current bilateral trade in hazardous waste and, in particular, the conditions for recycling. This effort is being made to ensure that our obligations under the Basel Convention are, in fact, being met.

As to the third question, I can assure Senator Coulter that no toxic metalliferous waste will be exported for final disposal from Australia to non-OECD countries after 1997. It remains premature at this stage to make a final statement on the matter of such exports for recycling. The recycling ban will not come into effect until the end of 1997, nor is the decision on such recycling legally binding. We need some time—and we will take some time—to reach a position on this matter. We will do so only after extensive consultation with community and industry groups, with regional trading partners and with other parties to the Basel Convention.

I will add a further comment on this subject. I was frankly appalled at the treatment of this item on an Australian television news service which was beamed throughout the entire region last night. I happened to see the 6.30 a.m. version of it this morning. The second headline item, after a reference to the China-US defence agreement being signed, was in these terms: `Australia accused of dumping toxic waste in Asia.' When we got to the item itself, around four-fifths of it was a complete, thorough-going bucket job on us, based on the Greenpeace assault, for allegedly seeking to undermine a UN convention. Only a couple of sentences of the report were devoted to the reply.

Of course it is the case that no-one can object to Australian television being fiercely independent of the government, nor does anyone suggest that individual items of this kind have to pass some loyalty test before they go to air. But it is quite another thing to engage in gratuitous Australia-bashing of the kind that was contained in that item. They have to expect to be responded to in this particular way when they do that, if they want to continue to expect any support from anyone here in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Recognising very clearly that the convention allows trans-boundary movement of wastes, while the consensus decisions taken in March would prohibit this movement after December 1997—I point out that Australia was a party to that consensus decision—I ask the following question. How does the minister reconcile the statement in the CEPA September report which said that the aim of the present negotiations with India was to achieve `agreements and/or arrangements in conformity with the Basel Convention on the basis of which environmentally sound trade could proceed beyond 1997,' with a statement reported in today's Age, and attributed to the minister's department, which described the purpose of the negotiations as seeking a `cooperative approach to ensure that any trading up to the end of 1997 was environmentally sound'?

—I dealt with all those matters in my initial reply. The basic purpose of the consultations is to make the system work for the remaining period until the end of 1997. There are some unresolved questions as to what will happen after 1997 because there is no legally binding obligation in that respect. A number of questions need to be answered. In respect of that, we are also seeking—as I said in my answer—consultations with regional countries about their attitude to the proper treatment of this issue after 1997, bearing in mind that the OECD/ non-OECD distinction has very little application in this region. It is a serious policy issue which we are addressing seriously. Again, there is absolutely no foundation for any suggestion that we are seeking, in any way, to undermine that important UN convention.

—My question is addressed also to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to statements made by Mr Ralph Nader in Canberra last Friday in which he referred to the fact that the United States Nuclear Non-proliferation Act of 1988 has been identified by the European Community as legislation likely to be deemed impermissible under the World Trade Organisation regulations because of its conditions stipulating end use. In the context of our own stringent bilateral agreements on uranium exports, and in light of the imminent signing of a nuclear cooperation agreement with Indonesia, can the minister assure the Senate that there is no chance that any agreement which places conditions on the use of uranium, nuclear technology or fissile material can be successfully challenged under the WTO regulations? Can he indicate what the implications would be if these treaties or agreements were deemed to be illegal?

—Whatever Ralph Nader's contribution might have been to raising consumer consciousness in a helpful way in the past, I think his judgments on a lot of matters these days can only be described as unsafe at any speed. The truth of the matter is that he has this one absolutely wrong. The issue raised by Senator Margetts does not appear to be one that we need to be in any way concerned about.

PARA.TAB: The NPT and its verification provisions, the IAEA safeguard system, provide the essential international framework for secure trade and cooperation in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy. To the extent that peace and security issues do arise in the GATT/WTO context, it is to ensure that the GATT/World Trade Organisation regime does not constrain its contracting parties from taking action to protect their essential security interests or their obligations under the UN charter for the maintenance of international peace and security.

Australia's obligations under the NPT would be protected by these provisions, as would our bilateral nuclear agreements covering uranium exports in the highly unlikely event that there were to be a challenge to them under the GATT/WTO. The GATT/ WTO provisions do not empower in any event the WTO to declare another international agreement illegal. We therefore see no reason whatsoever to believe that implementation of the GATT/WTO agreements would place at risk the implementation of our NPT commitments through our domestic legislation, through the Nuclear Non-proliferation (Safeguards) Act of 1987 or through our bilateral nuclear safeguards agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister, but he appears to have skirted the point altogether. He talked about the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. He did not specifically talk about the situation that the European Community is likely to act in terms of the legislation which the United States has put in to implement the treaty—indeed, the minister did not talk about that at all. Given these doubts about the ability of nations to place any restrictions on agreements relating to nuclear technology or fissile materials, can the minister advise the Senate on the status of the proposed nuclear science and technology cooperation agreement with Indonesia, when the agreement is to be signed and whether the minister is confident that adequate safeguards can be placed on this agreement? Under the Uruguay Round of GATT this is to do with the essential security of countries, it is nothing to do with regional security and it does not mention anything to do with such things as end use certificates and the ability of countries to on-sell technology or armaments to other countries.

—As to the first bit of the supplementary question, Senator Margetts asked in her original question about Nader's reference to the US act being identified by the European Community as legislation likely to be deemed impermissible under the WTO. I am just saying that whatever people might perceive the situation to be, it is our clear analysis and reading of the situation that there is nothing in the GATT/ WTO regime which would so operate to make legislation of that kind and safeguards agreements or anything else inoperative for all the reasons that I spelt out.

PARA.TAB: As to the agreement with Indonesia on nuclear science and technology matters, I am not able to give Senator Margetts an updated readout as to when that will be signed. It is still in the process of discussion, or hovering about in some procedural wilderness that it has been in for some months now. The content of it, as I have said on many occasions, is utterly uncontroversial in the sense that it does not in any way cover the supply of uranium to Indonesia or anything of that kind. It is simply a technical cooperation agreement and it ought not to be something Senator Margetts loses any sleep over.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. He would be aware of a series of full-page advertisements assuring ANL's customers and suppliers that ANL would continue to operate. Those ads started last month, and I notice that they reappeared in this morning's press. It is a different ad, but the same idea. Were these advertisements made necessary by the statement by Mr Brereton that ANL was bankrupt and could not be given away? What was the extent of the fall-off in ANL's business as a result of the minister's statement? What was ANL able to do to reassure its creditors, who must have been very alarmed by Mr Brereton's statement and the subsequent spate of advertisements? Is there not a degree of recklessness and impropriety in Mr Brereton's action in undermining the value of ANL to its customers and supporters when there was another respectable advice that ANL should be sold as a going concern?

—With the greatest respect, I think that last issue is as dead as a maggot in a Mortein factory. It is about two or three months old now at least. I am not personally familiar with the particular advertisements that Senator Gibson has referred to, but ANL has been engaged in advertising its ability to provide services and look after its customers for as long as I can remember.
—No. This is new.

—Not no, Senator Parer. Yes, Senator Parer. ANL has been advertising. Not only has it been putting out newspaper ads for years, but it has been issuing glossy brochures, drink coasters and so on. It has been quite actively promoting, as we would expect a company would, its services. I do not know why Senator Gibson would consider the latest ads to be exceptional. I am sure I can find him 50 just like it over the last four or five years. So far as the other questions of detail are concerned, I will refer those to the minister.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, it seems to me that these ads are exceptional. They are big ads and they are unusual.
