They are about trying to reassure customers that ANL was staying in business. This was after the minister's statement. I seek leave to incorporate these ads in my question. My question is: something is wrong; where is ANL's business today?
—I think you would have to seek leave to table, not to incorporate. You cannot incorporate it; it is as simple as that.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I have indeed incorporated such things before and I know that it is technically possible.
—I am advised that, simply on the size of it, Hansard would have great difficulty incorporating it. Is leave granted to table it?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the big difference between the attitude towards ANL of whichever part of the coalition front bench we want to pick and our attitude towards ANL is that those opposite wanted to sell it off and close it down. That is what their front bench said. What the minister and the government have announced is that we have put a new board into place for the purpose of this company continuing in business. Those advertisements, therefore, are totally in line with that objective.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: North Korea/United States: Nuclear Framework Agreement

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, relates to the agreement which has been reached between the United States and North Korea and which sets out a framework for resolving the problem of North Korea's nuclear weapons development. Is the government satisfied with the outcome of what must have been delicate negotiations on this important matter? Is it possible for the minister to comment in the Senate on the terms of this agreement?

—It should be said that the nuclear framework agreement that was concluded yesterday our time, 17 October, between the United States and North Korea is a major breakthrough. It will make an important contribution to reducing tensions and halting the threat of nuclear weapons proliferation in north-east Asia. It will build trust and contribute to a more benign security environment on the Korean peninsula. This could open the way for progress, furthermore, in the dialogue between North and South Korea. Australia, along with the rest of the international community, has preferred to see a negotiated settlement of the problem. We very warmly welcome this outcome.

PARA.TAB: The centrepiece of the framework agreement, which is to be formally signed in Geneva on Friday, is the commitment by North Korea to permanently freeze the operation of its existing graphite moderated research reactor, to seal its plutonium reprocessing facility, to retain in storage and eventually ship out of North Korea the spent fuel recently unloaded from the research reactor, and to halt the construction of two new large graphite reactors.

North Korea, very importantly, has also agreed to the full implementation of its obligations under the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and in accordance with its safeguards agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency. This includes a commitment to cooperate with the IAEA in resolving doubts about the quantities of plutonium it has produced in the past outside safeguards. The DPRK, in return, will receive assistance from an international consortium to construct two new light water type nuclear-powered reactors to meet its energy needs. Light water reactors are less sensitive from a proliferation point of view because they are much less readily configured for the production of high grade plutonium. They would be operated, furthermore, under full IAEA safeguards.

An important point to emphasise—and it has been by the United States—is that no significant nuclear components for the reactor project will be delivered until the DPRK has fully complied with its IAEA safeguards obligations, including the requirement to verify its past activities. Full IAEA safeguards will provide the essential non-proliferation assurance that Australia, the United States and the rest of the international community have demanded in relation to the past, the present and the future nuclear activities of the DPRK.

Clarification of some of the DPRK's past activities may take some time but the important point is that full verification will be achieved. The fundamental authority and integrity of the IAEA safeguards system will be protected. The US will also provide North Korea, as part of the package of measures under the agreement, with security assurances covering the threat or use of nuclear weapons. Trade restrictions will also be eased and the two sides will move towards the full normalisation of political and economic relations. It is also very pleasing that the DPRK has agreed to resume dialogue with South Korea. So the agreement does provide the foundation for a nuclear weapons-free Korean peninsula. It will make an important contribution to global and regional security and it offers the basis of a resolution to an issue of the highest security importance for us in Australia.

Finally, South Korea and Japan are expected to play a central role in financing the light water reactor project. Australia has no nuclear power industry and we are not in a position to become directly involved in this element of the package. There may, however, be other opportunities for Australian participation in the provision of an interim energy alternatives. We will be examining these possibilities as the consortium details are worked out and as needs and priorities are defined. Any Australian involvement would depend, of course, on the DPRK's full implementation of its safeguards obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. The minister has welcomed the news that the Asia Pacific Business Forum has endorsed a timetable for free trade to start before 2002 and no later than 2010, some 10 years ahead of the APEC Eminent Persons Group timetable. The ASEAN countries have rejected any timetable, as well as calling for the disbandment of the Eminent Persons Group. How can the Bogor meeting work if there is such a conflict already?

—The government remains optimistic that the Bogor leaders meeting is on track for a very important declaration of principle about free trade in our region by an agreed date. Whether it is the agreed date recommended by the Pacific Business Forum, that recommended by the Eminent Persons Group or another date within that ballpark, is a matter for the leaders to decide. I am not going to speculate about what it might be.

PARA.TAB: At this stage, the signs are encouraging that that remains possible. Nothing I have seen take place to date makes me doubt that it is a significant possibility. The outcome will depend upon the dynamics of the meeting and how that particular debate goes. We expect Prime Minister Keating to play in it the constructive and important role that he played at Blake Island during the Seattle leaders meeting. We have no reason to believe this meeting will be less successful.

As to the point that Senator Brownhill raised about the proposal that the Eminent Persons Group be abolished, that is not a proposal with which Australia is uncomfortable. We have indicated that at this stage we see no continuing role for it either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How does the minister rationalise his confidence in the meeting's success—which is basically what he just said—given that the ASEAN countries are backing off from supporting the Eminent Person Groups and given that ASEAN is pivotal to the success of APEC? The Prime Minister is very much APEC oriented, which is fair enough, but unless the minister's confidence is as well placed as he thinks it is, I think the government is heading for a bit of a catastrophe.

—I suppose it is true that, if I am not right, I am probably wrong—which is the sort of import I got from that question. The important thing to note about ASEAN is that it is true that the ASEAN economic ministers did not endorse the Eminent Persons Group outcome, and nor did we. We simply say that both it and the Pacific Business Forum report are very important contributions to the debate. Their key drive towards agreement about a date for free trade in the region is something that we support and, most importantly, President Suharto supports. We are simply supporting him. It is unlikely that we will get an ASEAN consensus to conflict with the position advocated by the President of Indonesia.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I draw the minister's attention to the report entitled Good cause for gambling: the prospects for a national lottery in the United Kingdom produced by London Economics and Impact Consulting. Further, I note that the UK government is to introduce a national lottery to fund social service delivery by non-government organisations along the lines suggested in the report. Given that Impact Consulting and London Economics are consultants to the Industry Commission for its inquiry into charities, and that Australian state governments are already using revenue from gambling to fund community and welfare groups within their borders, what plans has the Australian government to use gambling revenues to fund its responsibility to these groups in the future?

—The sting of this question is: what plans does the Australian government have to fund welfare from lotteries in the future? We have no plans. Let me just go back to some of the details of this question. Of course I am not surprised that the United Kingdom's government, a conservative government, would look seriously at a report from an international consulting firm about using lottery profits to fund its welfare obligations in its own community. It is the sort of thing that conservative parties always think about.

PARA.TAB: Conservative parties take the user-pays approach to the delivery of welfare. It is true that a number of state governments in Australia which run lotteries use some of the profits to fund what I think is top-up funding—not mainstream funding—for welfare delivery programs and to provide some funding for arts groups. That approach comes with being conservative and taking the conservative view that welfare is somehow a rip-off, to which people in desperate straits are not entitled, rather than a social obligation that a caring and compassionate government and community should provide for those people who are in need.

The fact that the consultants to the United Kingdom government are also consultants to the Industry Commission should not be seen as evidence of any particular government intent. The Industry Commission is conducting an inquiry into charities in Australia. That inquiry has a completely different focus from what I understand was the focus of the inquiry that was conducted in the United Kingdom.

After all, these are international economic consulting firms of high reputation. It is not surprising that the Industry Commission would consult them to help it complete its inquiry. There are no conclusions to be drawn from the fact that they also worked in an inquiry conducted in the United Kingdom for another purpose entirely.

To come back to the main point of the question: this government has no plans to go down the route of a Tory government in Britain; in fact, it is an abhorrent idea to us although, given the interruptions from the opposition, it may well be something that appeals to those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. If, after 11 years, the government is so concerned, as is shown by its strong criticism in its Creative Nation statement, about the failure of the Australia Council `to carry out the role the government requires of it', why is the government now widening its responsibilities so significantly? How can a government that is so critical of the Australia Council at the same time be confident that the council has the capability to take on extra jobs such as: to develop an international export strategy; administer a major organisations board which apparently is to take over all funding of national arts bodies; take responsibility for the Foundation for Australian Cultural Development; and enhance private sponsorship of the arts? Is the government's public criticism of the Australia Council simply an excuse for a further centralising of arts administration that effectively tightens the Prime Minister's personal stranglehold over the direction of arts funding that is aimed at achieving Labor's political agenda? (Time expired)

—It does make a change to get an arts question from someone who knows something about the arts. I have never criticised the Australia Council. There has not been an organisation made that is beyond criticism, and the Australia Council is not it. But the Australia Council has done and continues to do a good job for Australian arts. I think it has a lot of merit, but there is room for improvement. To the best of my knowledge, the chair and the general manager share that view. I welcome the fact that we have given more resources to the Australia Council; it reaffirms the role of the Australia Council as one of the country's most important cultural resources. The statement has increased the resources to the council. It increases its role in a number of areas which I think are important. This will coincide with a number of the other initiatives, including some of those that Senator Evans referred to earlier concerning international cultural projection.

PARA.TAB: I think this is a proper recognition of the potential which the Australia Council has to play a positive role in Australia's cultural life. I am confident that, given the extra funding and the new functions, the Australia Council will perform that role exceptionally well. I think the council's new management, its new role and its current funding will give it the capacity to do that job very well.

I do not criticise the previous management, many of whom I know well. I think they did an excellent job. But the role of all organisations develops over time. One of the great problems for the Liberal Party is that it has not yet learnt that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his kind remarks, but I would point out to him that there are evident criticisms of the way the Australia Council operates; criticisms which I have expressed over many years and which are reflected in the statement. For example, the government believes that a peer assessment system which is not efficient in time and resources for both council staff and its clients should be changed. It says that a cultural education system that is concerned simply with the development of the skill of artists and workers in arts industries is inadequate, and so it goes on. As the government is now directing the Australia Council as to how it should change its operations, where it should change, and how it should spend arts money, does arms-length funding really only mean the length of Mr Keating's arm?
—The fundamental difference between us and the opposition on arms-length funding is that we support it all the time and the opposition supports it only when it agrees with the decisions.

—I direct my question to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. There is increasing concern about the Queensland government's ability to adequately monitor the impact of construction works adjacent to the Hinchinbrook Channel. I understand that permits have already been issued for the removal of old-growth mangroves which protect the foreshore of the channel. Therefore, will the minister ask the Queensland government to urgently upgrade its environmental monitoring by, firstly, reconsideration of those permits; secondly, the immediate introduction of scientific water sampling procedures for setting baseline data, not just the visual monitoring that is taking place at the moment; thirdly, an independent engineering assessment of the current condition of the bund wall, particularly its vulnerability during the forthcoming and most likely wet season; and, fourthly, the establishment of both an on-site state environmental inspector—(Time expired)

—I am not in a position to amend procedures that have been established for either baseline studies or permits in relation to this particular development. They are set out in a deed of agreement that has been reached between the Cardwell Shire Council, the Queensland government and the developer for the Oyster Point development.

PARA.TAB: The baseline studies cover three aspects of the local environment—seagrass, water quality and turbidity. The Commonwealth will be involved in assessing the results of these studies and will also be involved in the setting of appropriate standards. The turbidity and water quality studies will involve systematic water sampling and laboratory analysis techniques. The seagrass study will take the form of a visual survey of the seabed, using transect methodology.

As I indicated in the Senate on Monday, my department has advised me that the bund wall has not collapsed, although there has been some subsidence into Stoney Creek under the weight of heavy equipment that is working there. The Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage, which is responsible for the supervision of this site, has advised my department that the area in which the slumping occurred will be infilled in the process of diverting the waters of Stoney Creek into a new access channel. I believe that the intention of the developer is to have these works completed before the onset of the wet season.

The site supervisor, who has been appointed by the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage, will monitor the threat that has been caused by this incident and seek additional advice if necessary, including the advice of an independent engineer should the early onset of the wet season warrant such a course of action. I can assure the Senate that we will continue to take seriously the issue of investigations. I will be ensuring that my portfolio agencies, including the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, will be involved in further investigations and will keep me, as the federal environment minister, advised of any developments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister. I know that his efforts are very much appreciated in regard to the monitoring of this issue. However, there remain outstanding issues. I think it would be appropriate if the minister could ask the Queensland minister to conduct an on-site inspection with him and with the Coordinator-General, who has prime responsibility for this project, prior to the onset of the wet season so that we can be assured that there will not be, as predicted, some kind of disaster during that wet season.

—Mr President, I stress that, as far as the land based development at Oyster Point is concerned, that has been a responsibility of Queensland authorities. I stress that the deed of agreement has been drawn up between Queensland, the Cardwell Shire Council and the developer. The Commonwealth's responsibility is to protect the World Heritage values of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area, and that is a responsibility that I have taken very seriously indeed.

PARA.TAB: But I stress to Senator Reynolds that the boundary of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area is in fact the low watermark of the Hinchinbrook Channel, and these land based developments—indeed, the area where the honourable senator's question concentrated, the bund wall—are matters that are the responsibility of the Queensland government. But I will take seriously my responsibilities. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I note today that the Prime Minister is to meet the banks to discuss the issue of farm debt. Whilst this is a useful first step, will the Prime Minister recognise that what is needed now, because of the seriousness of the debt crisis, is a proper national debt summit at which the banks, farm organisations, small business bodies and state and federal governments can discuss creative long-term solutions to the debt crisis? Will the government give consideration to providing tax incentives to banks that want to provide partial debt write-offs to keep struggling businesses in rural areas afloat, because the cost of not doing so would undoubtedly later be much higher because of the write-downs through losses that would be incurred on other businesses and the cost to the public revenue?

—Mr President, I will make sure the Prime Minister is made aware of Senator O'Chee's suggestions in this respect. The government is deeply conscious of the rural community's problems as a result of drought, and the financial implications of that. Of course, small businesses, like farmers themselves, have substantially benefited from the Commonwealth's funding assistance to farmers as a consequence of the significant flow-on effects of the drought relief package in rural regional economies.

PARA.TAB: I think the Senate is well aware of the scale of that particular assistance package which has been costed at some $164 million over two years, with that amount expecting to be exceeded if additional circumstances declarations are made or if the drought persists well into next year. I do not think I need to track over the details of that package; they are familiar to the honourable senator. As I said, I will pass on his suggestion to the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Evans may not be aware that many rural businesses are suffering massively because there is just no business coming in, and none of the financial support will lead to that because it is really money to put food on the table.

PARA.TAB: I therefore ask again: will consideration be given to particular assistance for small businesses in rural areas to ensure that they do not close, because their closure will not only mean losses to other rural businesses, as they write-off bad debts, but also, at the end of the day, losses to the government through losses to revenue?

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I hear what Senator O'Chee has to say. At the same time, we have to take into account our responsibilities to the overall fiscal climate. The budgetary implications of massive support programs of this kind are very great indeed and, in the present environment, we obviously have to take that into account, as Senator O'Chee, from his side of the chamber, keeps preaching to us.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, we are conscious of the problem, and I will pass on the honourable senator's suggestion to the Prime Minister to see whether he regards it as a constructive one, a helpful suggestion, or one that simply cannot be honoured in precisely the way he is suggesting. But nonetheless we will be taking it into account as we further develop policy in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Trade. Yesterday the Prime Minister launched Creative Nation, setting out the government's cultural policy. A number of initiatives were announced, some of which are designed to have a positive impact on our export performance. In this context, will the minister inform the Senate of the role of services in our export performance and, in particular, how our cultural industries will contribute to strong growth in exports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The services exports part of Creative Nation is a very small part but from a trade point of view it is important. Creative Nation also is just one of a series of positive initiatives in services exports that the government has taken. The previous one to which I wish to refer is the launch in early September of the LEK Partnership Pty Ltd intelligent exports studywhich showed the substantial performance of services exports in the Australian economy. It also pointed out that although the services sector accounted for 70 to 80 per cent of GDP and employment, it accounted for only 20 per cent of our exports.

PARA.TAB: Over the past decade we have seen a dramatic turnaround in our services exports, an upward trend in net services from a deficit of minus 1.6 per cent of GDP in June 1984—that is, a trade deficit in services—to, 10 years later, in the June quarter of 1994, a slight surplus of 0.1 per cent. As will be seen from the graph, it is consistently an upward trend. I seek leave to incorporate this appropriately sized graph in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The graph read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: [GRAPH OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 2048]

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that there is an export deficit in the cultural area and there is a very good reason for it. But we hope we will do something to narrow that gap. In services overall, there has been a very substantial improvement in our trade performance—particularly, for example, in education, which went from virtually zero in 1986 to $1.5 billion in 1993. In fact, in the past 18 months Australia has passed the United States as the major destination for students from both Singapore and Indonesia. I think Australians do not appreciate the significance of that change. The cultural industry is at a similar take-off point now. That is why Cultural Nation did set out—
—Try Creative Nation.

—Creative Nation; I thank Senator Alston. That is why it did set out to give support for further exports and that is why there is significant potential to add to our exports there. We have a sophisticated basis; we can promote it more. At this stage, Senator Alston does not quite have the proportions right but he is correct that we have a significant trade deficit in the cultural area. We do need to do better there. I think an open society like ours where people have the opportunity to enjoy culture from all around the world will continue to have a deficit. But if we can export more, that will tend to narrow the gap. Those initiatives will be important, they will be helpful and they will have a positive impact on our cultural industry and on our export performance.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time yesterday, 18 October, Senator Alston asked me a question without notice about the treatment of copyright issues in the cultural statement. I seek leave to have a longer reply than he deserves incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to Senator Alston's question:

The copyright issues which Senator Alston has identified have not been omitted from the Cultural Statement through oversight. Each issue is being dealt with thoroughly through a process of examination and consultation. The outcomes of these processes should not be pre-empted.

It is untrue to say that the Government has no idea what copyright protection is appropriate for the new communications environment. The Government's record shows that it has moved quickly to maintain comprehensive protection of copyright owners' rights in the face of rapid advances in technology.

In January 1994, the Minister for Justice established the Copyright Convergence Group (CCG) to examine and report on any amendments to the Copyright Act that may be necessary as a result of the convergence of forms of delivery of copyright materials to consumers—analogue and digital transmission over the air, via satellite and microwave and via cable. The group also considered the protection of multi-media works.

The CCG has now completed its task, and presented its report to the Minister for Justice, who released it on 26 August. The Minister for Justice is formulating a proposal for a Government response to the report.

In relation to the protection of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural materials under the Copyright Act, the Government recognises that the law as it now stands is not adequate to address all circumstances. The Government is committed to reform in this area as part of the continuing process of reconciliation, and its broader social justice package.

Next week the Ministers for Justice, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, and Communications and the Arts will release an Issues Paper outlining current copyright protection for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander arts and cultural expression, and options for more appropriate legislative schemes.

The Government is seeking contributions, particularly from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, about the limitations of the law and on options to address the issues discussed in the paper. Submissions will be due next January.

In addition, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation have been undertaking an extensive consultation process with indigenous communities and organisations on social justice issues. Widespread comment has been received on intellectual property issues during this process. ATSIC and the Council are expected to report, separately, to the Government on a wide range of social justice proposals. These two reports are due in early 1995, and are expected to include recommendations on intellectual property issues including indigenous cultures and knowledge.
Again, it is totally false to accuse the Government of refusing to give details of its commitment to the protection of the moral rights of all copyright creators.

A discussion paper entitled `Proposed Moral Rights Legislation for Copyright Creators' was released by the Ministers for Communications and the Arts and Justice in June this year. That paper set out options for amending the Copyright Act to provide for the moral rights of attribution and integrity.

The Attorney General's department received around 80 contributions on the discussion paper by the final date for submissions and comments in September. These are being examined, and the Minister for Justice will move shortly to introduce draft legislation to secure these rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be asking to incorporate my answer, Mr President. On Monday, Senator Watson asked me a question concerning the Native Title Act and capital gains tax. I have obtained the following answer from the Treasurer: the tax consequences of the making of a payment related to the loss or impairment of native title is being actively considered by the government. The government considers that the taxation of native title compensation payments should reflect the approach to capital gains tax on compensation payments generally. This approach is outlined in a draft taxation ruling issued by the Australian Taxation Office on 4 August 1994. The government also recognises that there are issues peculiar to native title which need to be addressed. In the context of the current consideration of taxation and native title issues, it has not yet been determined whether specific legislation will be appropriate.

—During question time today, I answered a question from Senator Cooney about the Ombudsman's report on customs. I said there were nine complaints dealt with by the Ombudsman. There were nine complaints investigated by the Ombudsman about personal searches since 1991. There were 12 complaints lodged with the Ombudsman about personal searches since 1991. The Ombudsman declined to investigate three of them.

—I have further information about a question asked of me by Senator Harradine in my capacity this week as the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Although I thought it was a very fulsome answer, I can provide Senator Harradine with some further information.

PARA.TAB: In answer to Senator Harradine's question, it is a fact that Professor Healy has obtained approval from Family Planning Victoria ethics committee for two clinical trials involving RU486 under the clinical trial notification scheme. Matters related to these notifications have been discussed in detail at Senate estimate committees and have been the subject of direct correspondence to Senator Harradine from the minister's office.

I am advised that two previous applications in 1987-88 for clinical trial studies had been evaluated and approved by the then therapeutics division, the body responsible for approvals before the Therapeutic Goods Administration was established in 1990. These applications were received prior to the commencement of the clinical trial exemption scheme but were approved as CTX trials after the scheme commenced in 1988.

The first application involved the use of RU486 in the treatment of foetal conditions. The second application involved the use of the drug as an abortifacient. Both studies were approved by the ethics committee of Queen Victoria Hospital, one of the precursor institutions which formed the Monash Medical Centre. The first trial was completed; the second was withdrawn by the applicant company prior to commencement. There is no information available to TGA which suggests that Professor Healy was refused permission by the Monash Medical Centre to conduct trials involving RU486.

In response also to the supplementary question that Senator Harradine asked of me yesterday, I am advised that Family Planning Victoria established the inquiry and the membership of the review team in consultation with the department. Professor Funder, one of the three members of the team—

TALK.START.PARA: —I went to school with him.

—is the director of the Baker Institute for Medical Research. He is a highly qualified, eminent and respected medical research scientist. There would be very strong professional reasons to have him as a member of the review team. I am advised that it is true that he wrote a report in 1990 on the biology and bioethics of RU486. This in itself does not label him as strongly supporting RU486. Rather, it might be seen that any support he has developed for the drug has been based on scientific analysis and through the review of the related literature. This background would give a justification for him being a member of the review team. And I sympathise with him for the fact that he had to go to school with Senator Alston.

—Yesterday, Senator Spindler, I think it was, or Senator Bourne, asked me some questions in respect of the continuing saga with Telstra and the DPP and the AFP. In answer to earlier questions from Senator Spindler in relation to this matter, I gave some information; I would now like to give some more in response to yesterday's questions.

PARA.TAB: I am informed that the AFP has advised the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) that initial legal advice from the DPP concerning search warrants had little or no effect on the final outcome of the AFP investigation of Telecom. This information was relayed to the Senate on 17 October and is still valid.

I am also advised that the material in question consists of a small number of audiotapes. It certainly does not extend to rooms full of tapes, as Senator Spindler's question suggests. I am not in a position to debate the nature of evidence collected or engage in crystal ball gazing inspired by ill-informed assumptions as an interim brief of evidence that has been submitted for advice. That is the advice from the Minister for Justice.

In respect of representations made by Telecom to the DPP and the police about Telecom's supposed shield of crown immunity during the course of police investigations, and if there were some, what they were, I am informed by the minister that no such representations were made to either the AFP or the DPP by Telecom.

I can also add that the Minister for Justice has advised me that, in the light of recent clarification of Telecom's status regarding shield of the crown, he has requested the Acting Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to re-examine whether the AFP is now in a position to obtain the material in question. I understand that the AFP is reconsidering this issue and I will advise the Senate of any further development when and if appropriate to do so, given that this is a continuing operational matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that the minister read that answer pretty comprehensively, I ask that he table the letter.
—Yes, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 81, Senator Parer raised with me a matter of privilege. The standing order requires me to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence, having regard to certain criteria laid down by the Senate. Those criteria relate mainly to the seriousness of the matter raised and the availability of another remedy. I and my predecessor have explained to the Senate in past cases the interpretation and application of those criteria.

PARA.TAB: The matter raised by Senator Parer concerns an allegation made by Senator Woodley in debate in the Senate on 21 September 1994 that, when Senator Woodley raised matters concerning the Port Hinchinbrook development with the principal involved in that development, he was threatened by that person. When it was suggested by way of a point of order that this was a matter of privilege and that Senator Woodley should substantiate the allegation, the Acting Deputy President, Senator Colston, ruled:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a question of order; it may be a matter of privilege.
Senator Woodley then said:
I can produce the documentation which is required . . .

The making of threats to a senator is declared by privilege resolutions of the Senate to be a matter which may be held to be a contempt. Any allegation that a senator has been threatened has always been taken very seriously. There is no requirement in the procedures of the Senate that such a matter be raised only by the senator who has received the alleged threats. On the contrary, the procedures make it clear that such a matter may be raised by any senator.

PARA.TAB: The allegations that he was threatened having been made so unambiguously by Senator Woodley in debate, there is no doubt that the matter meets the criteria which I am required to consider in determining whether a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence. I therefore determine that a motion to refer this matter to the Privileges Committee may have precedence in accordance with standing order 81. I table the letter from Senator Parer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

TAB.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges: Whether Senator Woodley was threatened in relation to the Port Hinchinbrook development in the manner referred to by him in debate in the Senate on 21 September 1994, and, if so, whether any contempt was committed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts why a question that I put on notice on 24 August 1994 has still not been responded to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Knowles did me the courtesy of advising me that she was going to raise this matter, and she also gave me notice last week that she intended to do so. I sought to get an answer for her last week and again today. I have not been successful. I cannot give her a more satisfactory explanation. The answer is overdue, and I have sought to provide it to the senator. I can only assure her that I am seeking and will continue to seek to do so.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Crichton-Browne)—by leave—agreed to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That in inquiring into the matter referred to it on 19 October 1994, the House Committee have the powers to send for persons and documents, to move from place to place, to meet and transact business in public or private session and notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston this day, relating to the Government's cultural statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to comment briefly on the hyperbole expressed by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in recent days in relation to the cultural document released yesterday because I think it is very important that Australians should understand. In my question, I asked the minister about the hyperbole and the Prime Minister's wife's disappointment at there not being a standing ovation.

PARA.TAB: The answer to that is very simple. Members of the arts community have a bit more intelligence than the Prime Minister and his wife give them credit for. They recognise that this is a pretty shameless pitch. It has a lot to do with words and rhetoric and not a great deal to do with very specific initiatives. Indeed, the answer provided to me this afternoon shows that there is a lot more work to be done on things such as copyright protection.

To develop this point, I want to draw to the attention of honourable senators some of the statements made yesterday by the Prime Minister. For instance, he talked about there being `a need to overturn a lot of received wisdom,' and the notion that we were `a country without history'. Whoever said that? I do not think I ever had any doubt about our history. We all learnt it at school. We all understand it. We all relish it. We all travel overseas, we come back to Australia and we are proud of the place. But he is not. He says, `The tide of our national consciousness has turned. Nothing has done more to free us from our insecurities.' Whose insecurities? He might have them. We do not. We do not suffer from cultural cringe. He might. He talked about it when he said, `I hope we are also saying a final goodbye to all those manifestations of cultural insecurity.'

This is the Prime Minister setting up straw men. He says that he wants to pay tribute to Rosemary Follett. She certainly was not very grateful. She now wants a cheque for $45 million as a result of yesterday's little effort. He says, `The Australia Council continues to be pivotal,' yet his cultural statement contained three pages of criticisms of the Australia Council.

We have to look only at last night's Lateline to see how far the hyperbole goes. The Prime Minister talked about the cultural statement as `an important strand in the rope of Australia'. Have you ever heard a more tangled metaphor in all your life? Whoever thought of Australia as a piece of rope? Maybe he is thinking about the place being strangled by the `recession we had to have', which was supposed to cure the current account deficit, and clearly did not. He said, `We are heading for the big identity in cultural round-up.' This is very crass stuff. This bloke is massacring the English language and does not even seem to realise the violence that he is doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are your policies?

—Senator Sherry will get them in due course. Kerry O'Brien asked the Prime Minister about the phrase `crossing the technical rubicon into the realm of consciousness, the realm of culture'. Kerry O'Brien was basically saying, `What an extraordinary use of the English language. Would you like to justify it?' The Prime Minister said, `I wrote that line myself, so thank you for picking the best line in the document.' It is just meaningless words and verbiage.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister, for example, obviously does not know the meaning of the word `euphuism', which means `high-flown rhetoric'. It is precisely what he is guilty of here. He uses the arts as some sort of battering ram to criticise others. He talks about hyphenated names, yobs with cans in their hands and gauche, nouveau riche characters. I would have thought that if ever there was a classic self-definition, it is that one, but I think he had other people in mind. He certainly did not mind bagging Balmain basketweavers and the blue-rinse set fund members.

We only have to go through his version of culture, his definition of what makes Australia, to see that it is just his definition. He is the one who has a view of the world. He wants everyone else to conform to it. He wants culture to be based in Sydney, so we will have a Sydney Symphony Orchestra elevated to great heights. Why did we have 11 out of 11 creative fellowships based in New South Wales and the ACT? Because that is where the Prime Minister lives.

What did he say about the Thai teak table when the press had the temerity to criticise him? He said, `It is only the peabrainedness of the press gallery that would run that rubbish in the first place. Great art punches you in the heart.' Peter Smark from the Sydney Morning Herald said that Mr Keating had told reporters that the Gould parrot prints bought for the cabinet room were part of his grand design to make us culturally sophisticated, despite ourselves. I could go on and on with examples of hyperbole. The important thing to realise is that Smark described the Prime Minister as `the TAFE certificate holder from hell.'

It is a classic example of someone who wishes that things were a lot different, who bitterly resents a lot of the Australia he was brought up in, who has a very big chip on his shoulder and who thinks he can get rid of it by moving to Woollahra and indulging in things that most Australians would not have the slightest idea about. I just hope that one day people will understand what a cultural phoney he really is. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that the real problem in the cultural statement, and certainly the problem that emerged from the non-answers to questions on it today, was the fact that there will be greater centralised control over the arts in Australia as a result of the changes being made in the Australia Council. This poses a simple and, for me, pretty direct problem because it is much easier when control is centralised in one body to effect control over it. I do not want to overstress the evident links that already exist between the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Australia Council, particularly of course when the chairperson of the Australia Council becomes a full-time chief executive. These links are both personal and practical.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me to be a genuine matter of concern that making the Australia Council much more `evidently powerful' and therefore much more directly capable of being the creature of the Prime Minister creates a serious problem for the arts in Australia, a serious problem for their independence and a particularly serious problem relating to the extent to which this Prime Minister has already shown a predilection to use the arts for achieving his political objectives as part of his political agenda.

To that extent, I must say I express serious concern at the apparent direction that the funding of the arts will take—I trust the arts themselves will be capable of resisting this—under this centralised body directly under the influence, the aegis, the control, the direction of the Prime Minister. That is why I asked in a question today, which was not answered, whether the words `arms length' used in relation to the arts in terms of there being funding at arms length really means just the length of Mr Keating's arm.

I must say that many of the criticisms in the cultural statement take up a lot of the points that I raised over the three years or so that I was shadow minister and which were continually dismissed by the government. That is why I was very grateful to hear Senator McMullan give me some commendation. Obviously now the points that I was making have been recognised belatedly by this government. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the government now says it believes:

SPEECH.PARA: the Council—
the Australia Council—
as a matter of some urgency, has to turn its attention away from the `supply' side of the arts equation to the creation of a higher level of demand from arts consumers.
It believes it has to:
undergo a process of structural change to meet the new requirements of its role.
It believes—I will repeat this because it is a vital point and I got strongly criticised for my comments about peer assessment:

a peer assessment system which is not efficient of time and resources for both Council staff and its clients should be changed. [The Government] further believes that the process of applying for, and being assessed for, funding should be simple and transparent so that those clients who are unsuccessful in their applications can clearly understand the reasoning behind the decision. The Australia Council should also squarely address the question of whether any change is needed to its current means of defining `peer'.
That was one of the points I continually made. The government also believes:

Changing the peer assessment process will not of itself, however, be enough to equip the Council to carry out the role the Government requires of it. The Australia Council structure, which has evolved over 20 years, should be simplified in order to enable the organisation to respond more flexibly to the changing needs of the arts community.
The next generation of arts funding must be a better combination of private and public . . .

That was the crucial centrepiece of the sorts of arts policies that I was pressing publicly and in private over years. At last this government is acknowledging, after 11 years in office, that the philosophic base that is the base of the Liberal Party approach to the arts is factual and reasonable. That is the issue. This government has provided no stimulus and it is not encouraging that in this statement. It is simply talking about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the comments of my deputy leader, Senator Alston, and also Senator Baume, who has a lot of experience in the area of the arts. It is interesting how, piece by piece, opposition policies are being stolen by this government to try to give itself some credibility. The fact is that this cultural nation statement ignores the needs of Australians living in regional Australia. According to the Labor Party and its vision of the arts, basically if people do not live in Sydney, Melbourne or Canberra, they must be living in a cultural wilderness. This statement will make sure that they will continue to live in such a cultural wilderness if they do not live within that Bermuda Triangle of Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra, into which all arts funding appears to disappear without any trace.
—What rubbish!

—I ask Senator Sherry: what does the cultural nation statement do for the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra, which has been in temporary premises now for years and years? It needs a permanent home. The cultural nation statement does nothing whatsoever for the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra. Indeed, the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra has a reputation worldwide. It is nothing short of an excellent orchestra. Yet for some reason, undoubtedly only political, the Sydney Symphony Orchestra has been chosen to be the beneficiary of a lot of funding.

PARA.TAB: I ask Senator Sherry and the government: when this great new supersymphony orchestra from Sydney comes to visit Tasmania, where is it going to perform? Is it going to perform in the Odeon Theatre, which is not good enough for the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra? How on earth would we then get the Sydney Symphony Orchestra to perform? The simple fact is that this government does not have a cultural policy for this nation. It has a cultural policy for the Bermuda Triangle, as I have described it, of Canberra, Melbourne and Sydney.

I would have thought that any celebration of culture within this country, any acceptance of culture within this country, ought to acknowledge and celebrate the diversity of this great nation and the diversity of the different symphony orchestras. If the government is genuinely concerned about giving all Australians access to our cultural heritage, then it is vitally important that all states, and bodies such as the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra, get appropriate funding to ensure that they are able to continue to provide the excellent cultural experiences that, for example, the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra has provided to the people of Tasmania, and indeed the world, over many years.

The government's charter of cultural rights supposedly seeks to guarantee all Australians the right of access to our intellectual and cultural heritage. I challenge the government by asking: where does it assist all Australians? The answer is that it does not. If people live in Sydney, Melbourne or Canberra, okay, but if people do not live within that triangle they will not get the benefit of what this charter of cultural rights supposedly guarantees to all Australians, that is, the right of access to our intellectual and cultural heritage.

Australia's culture—indeed, it is not unique to Australia: all societies are cultures—is, in effect, the heart and soul of society. It represents different strands of thought within society. Usually, cultural pursuits such as theatre are ahead of their times in relation to social policy; they are ahead of community attitudes. But if we are to give the experience to all Australians, then all the various forms of our cultural achievements ought to be funded. Our culture is sometimes reflective, as in poetry; at other times it is a celebration of the achievements of a nation or a particular region within the nation.

Let me simply say that the cultural statement shows that the Labor Party is not interested in the diversity of Australia and is not interested in ensuring that the regional communities within Australia get a fair go.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond very briefly to that non-contribution of total ignorance from Senator Abetz.
—Don't be rude; he is very well informed.

—Senator Newman is obviously not very well informed. I will inform her in a moment about what we are doing for the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra. It should be noted that we in Tasmania are very fortunate to have such a fine orchestra. Given the number of people in Tasmania, we are very fortunate to have an orchestra. We have continuing support from the federal government through the ABC, and that is as it should be. We are very fortunate that that per capita contribution—I do not have the figures before me—is much more significant than for any other state in Australia. We have our own symphony orchestra based in Hobart, in a state that has a relatively small population compared with mainland states.
—So we don't deserve it?

—We certainly do; and I am just about to come to the further assistance we are giving the orchestra in Tasmania. As part of the package announced yesterday, a number of arts companies under the program known as Playing Australia will be given additional funding to spread the cultural message around the country. I can inform the Senate—I certainly have to inform Senator Abetz—that under this program the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra is to be given a grant of $60,000. It has not been ignored in the statement.

PARA.TAB: These moneys are for the very fine orchestra we have in Tasmania which, as Senator Abetz rightly says, is of world renown. It is, as I have said, funded by this government through the ABC. Those funds are for a tour of Alice Springs, Darwin, Mackay, Mount Isa and Brisbane. There is also funding for some other activities. So Senator Abetz is totally incorrect, and I suggest he go back and read the statement. He may find out a little more than he knew when he made his contribution.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Woodley this day, relating to the funding of social welfare through gaming and lotteries.

SPEECH.PARA: When I look at some of Senator Cook's answers to what are notionally very simple questions, I never cease to be amazed at how he tends to be able to weave into his remarks a web of what I would consider to be unimportant matters. But the point I really want to make is that if Senator Cook had stopped at the end of his first sentence, when he said that this government has no intention of using the proceeds of lotteries or gambling to fund social welfare, I might have believed him. I am not quite sure though, because the track record of Labor governments in Australia with regard to the introduction of gaming and lotteries to fund social welfare is not all that good.

PARA.TAB: I can only speak for my own state, and I am sure that Senator Coulter will back me up. We know that back in the 1960s, after a long period of Liberal Party government in South Australia, we had a Labor government that introduced the first forms of gambling into that state in order to bolster government revenue. It said it would use this revenue to provide money for hospitals but, in reality, the money went into general revenue and hospitals did not receive any more money than they had under previous governments.

It is Labor governments, not conservative governments as Senator Cook might try to suggest, that have used the revenue from lotteries and gaming to try to bolster support for social welfare or welfare payments—or, in the case of South Australia, for hospitals. It so happens that the building that houses the Lotteries Commission in South Australia is called the Frank Walsh building, Frank Walsh having been the first Labor premier in South Australia for a considerable time—I think some 26 years after the Playford government. So we have a Labor government thinking that the revenue from lotteries and gaming is so important that it will name a building after the first premier.

It was in the late 1960s that a Labor government sought to introduce lotteries, gaming and gambling in order to fund certain of its payments which previously came out of general revenue. Then, in the early 1980s, when the Labor government saw that gambling and lotteries revenue was really a form of voluntary taxation, one that seemed to be pretty painless for the people involved, it introduced a casino, various forms of scratch money tickets, betting on the football with the TAB—as a matter of fact, there is hardly anything these days in South Australia that people cannot bet on if they really want to.

With the introduction of each form of lottery and gaming, the sole purpose was to provide revenue for the government. In this case, it is revenue that the government says it will put straight towards the funding of hospitals and other institutions which it otherwise should fund from taxation and general revenue. But the government prefers to use this form of voluntary taxation through gambling to fund all of these enterprises.

I am surprised that Senator Cook should try to link, as though it is a conservative disease, some move by a Conservative government 12,000 miles away to use gambling or lotteries to fund some of its social welfare payments. To the best of my knowledge of Australian history—Senator Cook, having been a long-time member of the Labor Party, ought to know this—Labor governments, certainly in South Australia and, I am quite sure, in every other state, have used the revenue from gambling and lotteries to bolster insufficient support for hospitals and other welfare institutions within their own state boundaries.

As I said before, if Senator Cook had stopped at the end of his first sentence in his answer to Senator Woodley, we might have believed him when he said that this government has no intention of using gambling or lotteries to try to boost or to help with social welfare payments in Australia. Unfortunately, as is Senator Cook's wont, he decided he would not stop then. He likes the sound of his voice so much that he went on to try to make us believe that this is something that conservative governments do and that Labor governments will have nothing to do with, when in fact history shows that Labor governments have been responsible—particularly in my state but probably in most states—for the introduction of gambling to provide revenue for social welfare purposes.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Margetts this day, relating to safeguards for the disposal of nuclear materials.

SPEECH.PARA: While the minister made an attempt to depict Mr Nader as a spent force, it seems that the European Community's listing of this law has the potential to be prima facie evidence that it could be challenged. The challenge may not be successful, but the judgment has not come down. It appears that the European Community believes that there is a case.

PARA.TAB: I note as well that the European Community is also currently challenging the United States' auto efficiency standards and its gas guzzler tax through GATT. The French appear to believe they can challenge a Californian law restricting lead in wine casks which leads to wine contamination. New United States national labelling requirements will also be challenged through the World Trade Organisation. Canada is challenging the United States ban on asbestos.

I would like to quote from a paper prepared by Associate Professor Janet McDonald which suggests that no interference with international trade will be tolerated, even if there is a legitimate overriding public purpose. The document on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which of course has now been updated to the World Trade Organisation, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed
(a)to require any contracting party to furnish any information the disclosure of which it considers contrary to its essential security interests . . .
And goes on:
(b)to prevent any contracting party from taking any action which it considers necessary for the protection of its essential security interests

PARA.TAB: (i) relating to fissionable materials . . .
(ii) relating to the traffic in arms . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the fissionable materials and the traffic in arms are mentioned is not sufficient under law, because of the reference in the overriding paragraph:
. . . shall be construed
(a)to require any contracting party . . . contrary to its essential security interests . . .

Therefore it is necessary for Australia, the United States and any other parties which have specific legislation and specific safeguards written into their legislation with regard to such things as nuclear proliferation to have the ability to restrict the import of certain goods and the ability to decide to whom they export. They can only do that if they can eventually prove that it is in their essential security interests to do so.

PARA.TAB: In relation to a number of types of defence related equipment, fissionable material and nuclear technology, if it is the case that it is not possible for Australia to prove that such an activity is against its essential security interests or the security interests of the region, or that it is related to end use certificates—that is, whether or not a country may on-sell to other regimes which may have poor records on human rights, or which have been known to on-sell to other regimes which may be problematical to regional security—it is challengeable under international law.

These cases have not been fought yet, but we know that the tuna-dolphin case was lost in relation to environmental issues because it could not be proved that only environmental issues were involved. The fact that it is very difficult for any of these issues to be proved in relation to nuclear technology, because it is a very secretive industry, means that we might have very serious problems in relation to our ability to act. I refer to such things as our restricted imports act. We talked about the United States nuclear non-proliferation act and we talked about other ways in which countries can make their own decisions in a whole raft of areas, including environmental standards, which clearly can be challenged under the new World Trade Organisation conditions.

In his reply the minister clearly tended to brush over the matter, in as much as he only talked about the treaty. He did not talk about the ability of countries to implement standards relating to those treaties which, indeed, should be of great concern to the government and are certainly of great concern to the Greens.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to the export of toxic wastes.

SPEECH.PARA: Back in March, just before Australia went to the Basel convention meeting, I raised this issue and Senator Gareth Evans repeatedly indicated that Australia was seriously considering the environmental circumstances under which wastes which were exported from Australia were handled in other countries. What one finds today is that the delegation to which the minister referred is now in India and is looking at `a cooperative approach to ensure that any trading up to the end of 1997 was environmentally sound'.

PARA.TAB: In March the minister also gave an indication that the inquiry as to the environmental soundness of this treatment had been going on for some time under the previous minister for the environment. Now we find that he has only just now, in October 1994, sent a group of people to India and the other countries which he named in his reply to investigate this fact.

This indicates a great laxity on the part of the government. The government has not been doing its job properly. It has not satisfied itself up to now as to the environmental soundness of this operation, and that leaves open the other question: that the government intends to continue the export of this hazardous waste post-December 1997 with the idea of avoiding the consensus agreement which was entered into at the Basel convention meeting in March this year.

The minister is quite correct when he says that that does not have the force of law, but it was a consensus agreement to which Australia was a party. Therefore, there are two aspects of this whole matter which are entirely unsatisfactory, and I think the television program to which the minister refers is entirely responsible for bringing that matter to the attention not only of Australians but other people in Asia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 2 of 1994-95—Department of Defence—Follow-up Audit—Management of Army Training Areas—Preliminary Study—Acquisition of Additional F111 Aircraft.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an important report of the Auditor-General's. Two years ago he gave us audit report No. 38 in connection with the management of army training areas and the acquisition of additional F111 aircraft. What saddens me is that, in his going back over activities since his report, there is a surprising number of recommendations which have not been implemented. Thirteen of the 17 recommendations which were accorded the highest priority for implementation in audit report No. 38 have not yet been fully implemented. Of the 43 recommendations made in the report, implementation had been completed in regard to 13; no action had been initiated to address five; and some action was under way on 11, but only proposed on 14.

PARA.TAB: I realise that Defence has problems like every other department in terms of funding, and Defence has perhaps suffered more than most in having a large number of jobs to do and inadequate funds with which to do them. However, one of the things the Auditor-General has pointed out is that existing funding mechanisms may not be adequate to ensure the timely repair, maintenance and environmental sustainability of training areas. That is something we should all be concerned about.

If repair and maintenance of training areas—or any other part of our defence facilities—are skimped, eventually we will pay a big price. In addition, if we skimp on protecting the environmental sustainability of our training areas, the nation will also pay the price for that. So the government must look at the Auditor-General's comments and see why it is unable, as a government, to provide sufficient funding to ensure the timely repair, maintenance and environmental sustainability of training areas.

I also found it interesting that the Auditor-General said that, following his report two years ago, army conducted its own study of the management of training areas, confirmed the ANAO findings that it had examined and also recommended action to be taken to implement the audit recommendations. Nevertheless, many of the tasks which arose out of it were still at a preliminary stage at the time of the follow-up audit—two years after the original audit report.

One of the surprises I found in reading the Auditor-General's report is a matter which relates to the Department of Finance. The Auditor-General pointed out that, in the period since the report was tabled in June 1992, Finance—as a result of its assessment of Defence's responses to the original recommendations or of advice received in the quarterly reports prepared by Defence—decided that no further reporting was necessary by Defence on 29 of the 40 recommendations which Defence had agreed to or had agreed to in principle.

What saddens me is that Finance has not been prepared to keep a close enough watch on this matter. The ANAO, using its powers to access Defence records, has formed the opinion that Defence has not yet fully implemented 18 of those 29 recommendations. So Finance was not looking closely enough at what was actually happening. It took Defence at its word. I suggest that in future it will have to look a good deal more closely to see whether the action matches the rhetoric.

The Auditor-General was pleased, as I am, to see that Defence is now adopting a tri-service approach to addressing some of the issues, but referred to a number of other matters which should be put on the record. There is the need for completing the development of management information systems. That has been dragging the chain. Once again, I guess the lack of funding for the necessary equipment is probably behind the delays.

Defence has had a long jump to try to improve its information technology over the last few years. I recognise that it cannot do everything at once, but these management information systems are important and they will make the job of managing our training areas much better once they are in place.

Another matter which the Auditor-General raised was the need for the development of policy or procedural guidance regarding training area acquisitions. That is not entirely agreed by army, for example, and I think it is wrong. Although army argues that its acquisitions take place only spasmodically, people come and go in Defence and in the defence forces and they do need guidelines, even if they are basic check lists for people to learn from the lessons of the past, to avoid the mistakes of the past. There have been some pretty awful mistakes in the past in the process of acquiring training areas, so I do not think that succeeding generations should be put in the position of making the same mistakes again.

The criteria needed by army to usefully analyse training area utilisation and cost data are yet to be completed. That is a recommendation which it is in army's own interests to develop. The recommendation was that army review the cost and utilisation of the training estate on a regular basis, and that a set of criteria needs to be developed to provide army with a management tool to highlight low utilisation of a training area; to compare the operating costs of all training areas; to enable army to assess the costs and benefits of a training area; and to enable army to review options available in regard to the use of training areas. Back in 1992 army agreed to that. However, that has not really been put into place effectively yet. The Auditor-General considers that the army should hurry on with that, and I believe that is right.

Another matter of importance to the nation is the security of these training areas. Questions of trespass and unexploded ordnance are in the interests of all of us. We do not want people who do not speak English or children straying into areas where they could be harmed. I was surprised to find that there are not adequate security notices which can be easily understood by all Australians. Although there has been movement since the original report, it is still dragging the chain and it is something that we should be monitoring to see that it is improved. The Auditor-General says that he considers that a need still exists for policy guidance on security and that the department should implement recommendation 15.

There was a most serious accident at Holsworthy which resulted in a board of inquiry. The Auditor-General in recommendation 19 had recommended that the lessons learned from that incident should be communicated to other training areas. Two years later the Auditor-General has come back and tried, through his investigation of manuals and materials within the department, to see what has been done, but could not find evidence that the lessons learned had been transmitted to other parts of the Defence Force, and recommended that it should occur at the corporate management level within the army. The distribution of the lessons learned is the second part of that recommendation. I could not agree more, and I find it surprising that that action was not taken speedily. In this case it was not a question of cost; it was a question of commitment. I am surprised that it has not been done.

The Auditor-General raised again the need for close liaison between the environmental management sections within the department and the army. If there is not such close liaison there may be duplication in the roles and activities fulfilled by each area, which increases the potential for duplication of policy development effort. There are limited enough resources to go around, few enough Defence dollars. We do not need waste and duplication. When it is not necessarily a single service issue, when it can be done on a tri-service basis and when we can avoid duplication, we should be striving to achieve that.

I noted with some wry amusement that at the time of this new audit the two sections were seeking to reach formal agreement regarding their respective environmental management responsibilities and were intending to establish a committee to meet regularly with a view to avoiding duplication of effort. Honourable senators would know that I have spent a good deal of time in this place over the years talking about the monstrous regiment of committees in the Department of Defence. When I last had responsibility for a portfolio in this area there were 90 committees. I have been trying to find out how many of them have gone whilst I have been engaged with other portfolios. Although a few have been whittled away, I believe it is not very many. But that will be something for another day; we will follow that up then.

So it is necessary for the department to pursue the finalisation and release of a departmental environmental policy and guidelines to be consolidated into a single manual of environmental policy and procedures. Each service needs to develop its own strategies, and that is not disputed, but the services are still proceeding with the development of individual strategies and there still appears to be a duplication of policy development effort. As I have already said, duplication should be avoided.

Before I conclude, I would like to refer to the second part of the Auditor-General's report, which is entitled `Preliminary Study: Acquisition of Additional F111 Aircraft'. There was a need seen to extend the original life-of-type target for the F111 fleet. In order to achieve this, the government bought aircraft, F111Gs, from the United States at a reduced price. I want to make a couple of comments about that acquisition, which is referred to in the Auditor-General's report, although a detailed study was not conducted here as was done with the training areas.

One of the interesting things that I found in this section was the recognition by the Auditor-General of something which the opposition has been saying for several years now, that is, the problems which we will be facing and which we have already started to face in the bulge in the capital equipment program. It has not been carefully staged so as to allow proper personnel and training funding to go hand in hand with the capital equipment program, and we will pay a heavy price for that imbalance and for that distortion of the budget.

The purpose of the F111G acquisition was to allow the consideration of any replacement for the F111s to be delayed by five to 10 years. The Auditor-General noted that this could be pretty important for Defence as the current projections for major capital equipment investment showed that a significant congestion in the requirement for capital funds is due to occur around 2010, the original life-of-type target for the F111 fleet. This projected expenditure includes the acquisition of replacements for existing tactical fighter aircraft, strike-reconnaissance aircraft, destroyers and armour. That is something which not only this government but succeeding governments will have to juggle with unless more funds can be found. It is of serious moment to us all.

Before I conclude on the subject of the F111G, I would like to say that there will be some logistic support difficulties with the introduction of this aircraft. There will be no increase in flying hours, but there will still be additional operating costs associated with this model due to the need to manage additional unique spares and equipment for this G model, and also the need to conduct some initial maintenance in accordance with the USAF calendar-based maintenance philosophy.

The bottom line is that these additional costs have been estimated at $3 million per annum. As we are now in a situation with the defence budget whereby every dollar that we can put towards training and personnel costs is a dollar worth while, it is sad to see our being up for another bill of $3 million a year because of logistic support difficulties with a different model. It is the price we are paying to extend the life of the F111C. There is also a problem with personnel in relation to the purchase of these aircraft. There have been potential difficulties in providing adequate F111 trained service personnel. The Auditor-General's report states:
