SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO was advised that a temporary increase in manpower had been approved . . . and that Air Force will manage the personnel required to sustain operations in the context of its total constrained establishment and the Chief of the Defence Force's (CDF) Preparedness Directive.

That flags, for me, ongoing problems in the future in terms of the provision of personnel. The money for those personnel will have to come out of an already limited personnel budget. Just as the navy is already struggling to find the personnel to man the ships, it looks as though the air force, down the track, is going to be in a similar position in order to man the F111s.

PARA.TAB: It is urgent that the government give proper consideration to the problems which it has caused through the imbalance in its defence budget through the shopping list of capital equipment that it undertook all at one time, instead of staging it in the way in which a good, frugal housewife must do. One cannot buy it all on this week's pay. Some of it has to come out of next week's, next month's, next year's. But Mr Beazley, when he was minister, went on a shopping spree par excellence. The trouble is our obsolescence will all come in a heap as well.

In the meantime we must face this very serious problem of affording the manpower, training them and using them to defend Australia. It is all very well to have the ships and the planes but if they sit on the ground in their hangars or they are tied up at the dock, they are not going to be ready to defend Australia as and when needed. That is a serious matter. It is only obliquely or minutely referred to in this report. But the Senate should be aware that that is a problem facing the defence of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 14th report of 1994 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 15 1994, dated 29 September 1994.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO JAPAN AND THE REPUBLIC OF KOREA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Japan and the Republic of Korea which took place in July 1994. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Japan and the Republic of Korea in July of this year is entitled A time of change, a time of opportunity. Bilateral delegations are, as the report suggests, vehicles for promoting understanding and good will between parliaments and nations. On that basis this delegation was an unqualified success.

PARA.TAB: The bilateral visit was very enjoyable. It was very well hosted and it was a very pleasant delegation to be a part of. It comprised the Hon. Stephen Martin, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, as the leader and myself as the deputy leader. Senator West led another part of the delegation later in the trip. Other members of the delegation were Mr Ferguson, Mr Hawker, Mr Horne and Mr McGauran. It was an unqualified success as far as I was concerned because we all got along very happily with each other. I think we learnt a lot, which is what we were meant to be doing.

I place on record our thanks and appreciation for the hospitality of our hosts and the help and assistance given by our hosts, officials and others whom we met on our trip. I thank the ambassador in Japan, Ashton Calvert, and Mr Mack Williams in the Republic of Korea, and their wives, who were absolutely wonderful to us on this study tour.

Others who need special thanks are Don Dobinson, Elizabeth Toohey, Adrian Morrison and their spouses. It was a happy trip, as I said. I think we also should pay a great tribute to Ian Dundas because, as the secretary of the delegation and as the person who had to get us on and off planes and on and off buses, I think he did an exceptional job. He was also a very good photographer. Some of the photos that we have come home with provide great memories for us all. Also, Claire Cooney, from the Speaker's staff, was outstanding in helping us in a lot of our endeavours.

Landing in Tokyo was quite an experience. Tokyo has a population in excess of the total population of Australia in a very small area. It is one of the largest cities in the world and it is quite awe inspiring. It is also very awe inspiring that, in a city of that size, we felt safe. We could walk through it at night or during the day and always feel safe. It is also a clean city.

The official objectives of the delegation were to assess and evaluate the political and economic changes occurring in both countries and to further develop bilateral ties. The delegation also took the opportunity to discuss matters relating to primary resources, the most obvious being coal and beef, having regard to the export values of those two commodities. I had a special interest in the area of beef. I declare my pecuniary interest at this stage. Of course, coal is a very important export for Australia. It is also very important to my state of New South Wales. Indeed, Japan is Australia's main trading partner and South Korea is our fifth largest, even ahead of Taiwan and Singapore.

We visited Japan at a time of political unrest and change. It was a privilege that we were able to be there at such a dynamic time in Japan's political history. We were honoured to have discussions with the just elected Prime Minister, Mr Murayama. He reiterated the opportunities for Japan and Australia to strengthen their relationships, particularly in matters affecting the Pacific Basin. In fact, as I understand it, we were the first foreigners to get in to see the new Prime Minister. I think we actually got there ahead of others who were waiting in the ante-room at that stage.

It was pleasing to receive assurances from both Prime Minister Murayama and Foreign Minister Kono that Japan would continue its commitment to implementing the outcome of the Uruguay Round of GATT. When we went there many people were saying that they did not think the government would stand because it is a very interesting and different type of coalition, with a socialist Prime Minister and a conservative part of the government behind the scenes. Basically, I think it will stand the test of time. Of course, much will depend on the state of the Japanese economy and its success in reforming economic regulation. It appears that the recession has bottomed out. The Japanese economy, even though it remains flat, is bumping along the bottom and I believe it is about to start moving upwards.

The recession and the appreciation of the Japanese yen have had a major impact on Japanese industry, which has faced major restructuring. As a beef producer, I was particularly interested to learn about Australia's marketing of beef in Japan, although it was very disappointing to discover Australian beef incorrectly labelled `Aussie beef: product of the United States of America' in one supermarket that we visited. It does not give me a lot of pleasure to mention that here today. Other people may want to get into the AMLC's beef promotion which, through its marketing efforts in Japan, has done a great job with Aussie beef. So, obviously, the Aussie beef program is working.

I note that the Japanese are learning the importance of lean beef. Over time, this will have a significant impact on the feedlot industry here in Australia. Australian beef producers would do well to understand the Japanese trend towards lean beef. In Japan there is a potential for a 10 per cent increase in the beef market. From discussions I had on the matter, I believe that we will see more of the 90-day grass fed beef going in. It was made very clear to us that five points—quality, TV promotion, pricing, taste, and the overall promotion of our beef—will be paramount in the future if we are to ensure that we keep that market because there will be competition from the Americans, the New Zealanders and others.

But we can expand our beef sales in Japan if we pay attention to what Japanese consumers want. It does not matter whether we are talking about the delegation's visit or any other trip; it is very important to give consumers what they want, and more so in Japan. The maintenance of quality will be crucial to that future trade, and that is the weak link in Australia's export programs and something that we must work harder on and understand more about here at home. Maybe the cooperative research centre set-up in Armidale will help us move from finding out what the consumer wants back to finding out what type of grains should be fed to the animal. That will be very important in the future.

Wool might have lost some ground but it is still a vital export worth just under half a billion dollars. In Japan we met with representatives of the Japan Wool Spinners Association and the Japan Wool Importers Association. Japan is increasing the imports of semi-processed wool and is interested in investing in processing plants in Australia. However, the representatives expressed concern about the need for Australian government cooperation in meeting environmental protection requirements. Of course, Japan's inventory has been down a little bit. Just recently there was a price surge and I hope that it does not go down any further in the next little while, because it is important that our countries remain together to keep that industry going well. The Japanese wool spinners are worried that the deregulation of the Australian wool industry may jeopardise quality assurance.

Some other points that I think are worthy of note in presenting this report are that in Japan unemployment was about three per cent—in real terms, about five per cent. However, the point was made that businesses were still labour hoarding, that is, they were not putting off workers as they may need them in the future. That is a very interesting aspect which I took from some of my notes this morning. Interest rates are at about five per cent, which is excellent. Another interesting sidelight is that 85 per cent of the farms are run on a part-time basis.

The electoral reforms in Japan will eventually give less influence to the farmers, which will be very good for the future of Australia's exports of coal. As for tourism, something like 600,000 Japanese visit Australia every year. Bali is a very big competitor to Australia. Traditionally, the Japanese have about a five- to seven-day holiday when they come to a country and they stay sometimes at one, two or three places. At one of our meetings it was brought up to us that it is important that we do not have bag handlers disputes because nothing annoys people more when they go to a country than to experience an industrial dispute. It spoils that very short holiday. So it is something we have to work at.

Another area that really impressed me was the flowers. I have never seen such wonderful, beautifully arranged flowers of such a high quality and standard as I saw in Japan. The one thing that Japanese really require is product of the highest standard, quality and consistency. We visited the Ota Flower and Vegetable Market. The flower market is worth $2 billion a year. That is a lot of money being spent on flowers but a lot of importance is placed on that area. The flowers change hands something like three times before they actually get onto somebody's mantelpiece or into an hotel or wherever.

I am quite sure that Senator West will elaborate more on this when she speaks in a moment: women in Japan are having fewer children, working longer and living longer. Less than one per cent of women are managers of businesses in Japan.

Another area of interest was the new Kansai International Airport at Osaka, which we visited. That airport will make a big difference to the relationship between Japan and Australia by giving Australians and Japanese quick and good travel access between the two countries, especially the Osaka area which has great potential.

The delegation also visited the Asia-Pacific Trade Centre, which was very impressive. The bottom line for Japan is that the market is there and we will succeed in proportion to the effort we are prepared to put in. Marketing is the key for us in Japan.

Following an outstanding time in Japan with the hospitality and absolutely exemplary organisation, we then went to Korea where there were international tensions in the political situation because of North Korea's non-adherence to the international atomic energy commitments. It did not preoccupy our minds when we were there but it was something that was going on at that particular time. The internal political situation was not as volatile as it was in Japan with the new Prime Minister and the fall of the previous government.

However, there was some potentially destabilising domestic opposition to trade liberalisation in South Korea. That is understandable in light of the fact that the agricultural sector could decline there by some $10 billion. The future of trade between Australia and Korea will largely depend on the economic reform policies currently being pursued by that country.
At this stage I wish to identify myself with the remarks made by the leader of the delegation, the Speaker of the other place, in respect of the pace of the delegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We worked hard!

—The parliament can be assured that it got full value for money from us on the trip. I can attest to the pace of the meetings and the dinners. The trip was stimulating, informative and enjoyable but it was also hard work. There should be more visits to the Korean peninsula for beef and wool issues. I do not know how many visits there have been by Australian delegations to the Korean peninsula but there definitely should be a lot more than there have been—hopefully, every second year. I know the Speaker of the House of Representatives invited a delegation from the Korean parliament to return here next year. I hope that next year another delegation from the Australian parliament will go to Korea. If we are to be successful in the Republic of Korea, we have to build up a good rapport between Australia and Korea.

PARA.TAB: One memorable part of the visit to the Republic was when we went up to the DMZ, the dividing line between South and North Korea. I was given the honour of walking on the Bridge of No Return—and I have returned, which I am very happy to say—which was really quite stimulating. I really felt the tension that exists between the two countries, the division that is there and the fact that everyone is eternally vigilant, watching out to see what is happening all the time.

The Republic of Korea is now about 50 per cent nuclear powered. That is something which should be of interest to our parliament. The country is really on the move: there are 500 new cars per day going onto the roads in Seoul, which is absolutely astounding when one thinks about it. It is astonishing to think that that number of new cars is rolling onto the roads all the time. When we look at the traffic, of course, we can understand what is happening. The fact that the Koreans are building 150 kilometres of new underground shows that they are meeting the challenge of the amount of transport that is needed in the city. By 1996 they hope they will have better tail pipe emission controls, which I believe will be a great help.

I think the opportunity to meet the President was another highlight of the trip. We do not often get the opportunity to meet people of that high rank. Obviously, that occurred because we were fortunate enough to be in a delegation led by the Speaker.

We met with the Korean Worsted Spinners and Weavers Association. The Koreans said that demand for wool would be up and the price ceiling would be about or more than 700 cents. There is a big need for research and development in the wool industry. The Koreans are obviously now investing in the tops-making process in the Geelong area in Victoria where they have joint ventures. They are doing a good thing for Australia, I suppose, because we are value adding here and we are also able to give a good finished product to the South Koreans.

My impression was that Korea was slightly behind Japan in trade liberalisation. I repeat that we must give the consumers the beef they want. It is a little harder to get beef into the Republic because it is a more restricted and controlled market. But we have to work these things out together and make sure that both our countries can prosper together, and I think that our visit will help to do that.

In conclusion, the ambassadors here in Australia, both for the Republic of Korea and also for Japan, must receive our special thanks for the assistance they gave us in this delegation. I also thank the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade here in Australia for the briefings and the lead-up it gave us before we went on our trip. The department was very helpful and that help was much appreciated. I also thank Austrade, which gave us most welcome help and assistance. It was a memorable trip to two outstanding countries, with a delegation that worked very well and was very ably led by the Speaker of the House of Representatives.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO JAPAN AND THE REPUBLIC OF KOREA

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with the remarks that Senator Brownhill, who was the deputy leader of this delegation, has made about two of the three countries that we visited. It was a memorable occasion. It was an exciting and stimulating time to be there. Less than a week before we left for Japan, we were not sure whether that part of the trip would go ahead because there had been a change of Prime Minister. We were not sure whether there would be a general election or a peaceful and successful transfer of power from one party to another.

PARA.TAB: Fortunately for us, and for the Japanese too, they were able to show what a good democracy is, and that there can be a transfer of power from one political grouping to another without the need to go to the polls and without bloodshed. It can be done peacefully, amicably and in a way that means the country remains very stable.

I share Senator Brownhill's opinion that it is a stable coalition between the Social Democratic Party in Japan and the Liberal Democratic Party. I think it will last the full term. That is something that a lot of people initially were very sceptical about. They could not see how two groups, from what would appear to be extreme opposites of the political spectrum, could work together. But they appear to be doing so, the coalition appears very stable and that is a good thing for the country and the world.

We were honoured to meet Tommiichi Murayama, the Prime Minister of Japan. I am sure that we were the first foreign group to do so. We beat the American dignitaries. There was coverage of this in the national Japanese media. We felt that we were accorded a great honour because, at that stage, Mr Murayama was two or three days away from being in Naples for the G7 conference. I thought it was a great honour for us that he took the time to meet a delegation from Australia, and we respected his doing that for us and showing us that courtesy. The Japanese were very keen to make sure we knew that it was business as usual in Japan: there had been no major shift in policy direction. That, of course, adds to the world's awareness of Japan being a stable country and the fact that a stable change of power had taken place.

The make-up of the delegation was very interesting. We were basically rurally oriented. All of us, with the exception of the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson), had either a provincial or rural base. That meant that, as a group, we were able to discuss a number of primary industry and resource trade matters that concern this country so much. It was an honour to meet a number of those very important groups and people.

The issue of women and women's representation in those countries was also raised and looked at. Australia is not the only country that is underrepresented by women in its parliaments. I think just about every country in the world is. It was an honour for me to be able to meet Takako Doi, who was the leader of the Social Democratic Party in Japan and who is now the Speaker of the Japanese Diet. It was a very great honour to be able to talk to her about the issue of getting a greater representation of women in parliament and to know and learn that women parliamentarians in Japan have similar concerns to women parliamentarians in Australia about underrepresentation. I was also able to meet at official functions several other women who had been ministers in previous governments, and I met a woman who had been a head of Japan's diplomatic postings in the Scandinavian countries.

It brought home to me that there is a very great need for us to continue with the women's groups within both the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association and the Inter-Parliamentary Union. In any parliamentary group that is set up, the women parliamentarians must ensure that, if there is insufficient women's voice in the groups, they are able to form women's subgroups to make sure that women parliamentarians are encouraged to attend the organisations and enter parliament.

As I said, it was a very interesting and exciting time to be in Japan. Another person whom I found very interesting to talk to was Ms Mariko Bando, the Chief Cabinet Councillor. She was certainly able to advise us of a number of the issues that confront Japanese women today—what their actions are, what they do, where they fit with sexual harassment, sexual discrimination and equal employment opportunity legislation, what penalties or lack of penalties they have with their legislation and what issues are confronting women in the workplace. As Senator Brownhill mentioned, women in Japan are, on the whole, marrying later and having fewer children. The Japanese birthrate is declining to about one child per family. Some concerns were expressed about that and what it means for the future. Those are issues that the Japanese have to approach and deal with.

We then moved on to Korea. Our visit to Korea took place three days after the death of the leader in North Korea, Kim Il-Sung. That was a time, of course, of great tension and people were not sure what was going to happen. When we got to South Korea one would not have known that there had been any sort of drama or any sorts of concerns about what was happening north of the border. It seemed very much business as usual. People were busy working. It was the middle of summer and it was very hot. People were still taking their weekends off to go down to the beach to seek respite from the heat. But it meant that it was an exciting time for us to be there.

We had the pleasure of meeting Kwang Nak Joo, who is now the Speaker of the National Assembly. Honourable senators may recall that last year Mr Kwang led a delegation to Australia in his capacity then as the Deputy Speaker of the National Assembly. I had the opportunity to meet him then and it was a great honour to be able to meet him again in his more elevated capacity as the Speaker of the National Assembly. He is certainly an impressive gentleman, and someone with a very shrewd political knowledge. He is a very caring and powerful gentleman. It was a great pleasure to be able to meet somebody that we had seen before in Australia and to catch up on what had been happening since his elevation.

One of the things that did strike me, and always strikes me when I go overseas to non-English speaking countries, is the necessity for Australians to learn to speak a language other than English. I am almost ashamed on occasions to say that English speaking countries have an attitude of almost assuming as a God given right that everybody else will learn to speak English. A lot of people in the countries we visited speak very good English. Some of them are educated in English speaking universities in the US, Canada and Australia. We do not seem to be doing anywhere near the same amount of work in the education area to ensure that we reciprocate. We are not doing enough to ensure that our students are able to speak any language, but particularly an Asian language because of the proximity of Asian countries and because those countries are very valuable trading partners. People who learn an Asian language also learn about the culture and the customs of the country and, of course, that knowledge is very essential when it comes to negotiating with and visiting a country.

Visits such as the one made by our delegation are very important because they enable members of parliament to learn about the customs of countries. We were very fortunate in Japan to be able to visit some of the temples and shrines. Some of the temples and buildings that we saw are over 1,000 years old. The Buddhas are over 1,000 years old. We saw the largest bronze Buddha in the world. We saw the largest wooden building in the world, which was a pagoda.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fantastic building, isn't it?

—It is just amazing. To be met by the chief monks, the chief abbots, of these shrines and to be allowed to participate in some of the ceremonies and have them perform ceremonies for us was a very moving and very spiritually enlightening experience—an experience that would be appreciated by a lot of people. I would recommend such an experience to anybody because it gives one a greater understanding of the cultures of these countries and why people think and act the way they do. Visitors see shrines and churches and things like that. I found that was an important adjunct to this trip. We learnt about business and industry, but we also learnt about what innately makes those people what they are and why they hold certain beliefs. For a better understanding of people, it helps to know those sorts of things.

PARA.TAB: I wish to associate myself with all of the comments that have been made both here and in the other place in relation to the trip to Japan and Korea. I hope that next year the Koreans will be able to respond to our invitation and visit this country. I look forward to resuming learning about these very interesting and dynamic countries and spending more time with their representatives.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the visit to Taiwan by members of the Australian parliament which occurred in July 1994. I seek leave to table the report and to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report I have just presented arises from an unofficial visit to Taiwan by a group of senators and members who were returning from a bilateral delegation visit to Japan and the Republic of Korea. The visit to Taiwan had an unofficial status because an official visit is not possible under the terms of a joint communique agreed to in 1972 between Australia and the People's Republic of China, which established the basis for Australia's recognition of the People's Republic as the sole legal government of China. The communique acknowledges the position of the Chinese government that Taiwan is a province of the PRC.

PARA.TAB: It was at times difficult for us to see what difference, if any, our unofficial status made to the conduct of our visit. In many respects, our program in Taiwan was similar to that of our visit to Japan and South Korea. Certainly, the hospitality we received and the efforts made by our hosts were at the same high level and the support we were given by the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei was just as professional and just as valuable as the assistance provided by our embassies in Tokyo and Seoul.

Before commenting further on the nature of our visit, I would like to formally acknowledge the efforts of those who contributed to the success of our visit. I would like to place on record the delegation's sincere appreciation of the hospitality of our host and the assistance provided by the Legislative Yuan and the government of Taiwan. The visit was made in response to a generous invitation of the Legislative Yuan and, on behalf of the delegation and the Australian parliament, I thank the Legislative Yuan for the courtesy extended in that invitation and for the hospitality provided. Officers of the Legislative Yuan, particularly Dr Lee, worked very hard to organise our visit and thereby ensured its success.

I would also like to record our appreciation for the highly professional work of the staff of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office, particularly Steve Waters. I also thank Senator Brownhill for his support as deputy delegation leader and our colleagues from the other place, the honourable members for Wannon (Mr Hawker), Paterson (Mr Horne) and Gippsland (Mr McGauran), for their contributions to the success of the visit.

The other person who needs a big vote of thanks for the success of this is Mr Ian Dundas, who was the secretary of this delegation as well as the delegation to Japan and Korea. He spent many hard, long hours working at ensuring that everything ran like clockwork and with the precision that we had expected.

The very successful conduct of our visit, despite its unofficial status, in many respects mirrored the nature of Australia's relationship with Taiwan. Although Australia does not formally recognise the authorities in Taiwan, we have a valuable, successful and nearly normal relationship with Taiwan, particularly in trade and personal contacts. In fact, our trade with Taiwan runs at a level virtually equal to our trade with the People's Republic of China. In 1993, the value of our trade with Taiwan was $5.1 billion, while our trade with the People's Republic of China was worth only slightly more at $5.2 billion. The lack of official recognition has clearly not prevented the development of a significant and fruitful relationship.

The Taiwanese recently launched a program to try to normalise their place in the world, including membership of the United Nations. This may give rise to Australia considering how we respond to Taiwan's initiatives within the terms of our recognition of the People's Republic of China. For example, the authorities in Taiwan have renounced their claim to be the legitimate government of the whole of China and now accept that their authority does not extend beyond the territory that they actually control.

Australia cannot and should not move unilaterally to put aside the joint communique with the People's Republic of China, but we should note that things are changing from the position in 1972 when the authorities of Taiwan vigorously maintained their claim to be the legal government of the whole of China. The government and official institutions are becoming more democratic and representative of the views of the people. Furthermore, Taiwan has developed into a major and independent trading economy. It has the second largest level of foreign reserves in the world and is the 15th largest trading power.

The People's Republic of China will continue in the foreseeable future to oppose any bid for membership of the United Nations. In these circumstances, the best approach for Australia is to urge the PRC and Taiwan to resolve the problem themselves.

The best approach that Taiwan should take to assert itself in world affairs is a matter which is of much discussion within Taiwan itself. We noted while we were there—and this has continued since then—that there was a lively debate in the Legislative Yuan as to whether Taiwan should push its claim for United Nations membership under the name of `the Republic of China on Taiwan' or simply `Taiwan'. This is not an argument of semantics—there are strong differences about the nature of Taiwanese nationalism and how it should be expressed. The conservative view is that Taiwan is a part of China, albeit a part with a different government from that of the mainland, while the more radical view is that Taiwan is a separate country not necessarily part of some `greater China'.

While we were there we had a meeting with the Legislative Yuan foreign affairs committee. The opinions that were expressed within that committee by the two key proponents are in marked contrast to one another and the debate on the differing points of view was very lively and robust.

In the long run, emerging Taiwanese nationalism, in whatever form it takes, will increasingly pose some interesting questions for those countries that recognise the People's Republic of China but also want to maintain fruitful relations with Taiwan. The best outcome will be for some form of accommodation, if not reconciliation, between the People's Republic of China and Taiwan. In the meantime, Australia will need to continue to give priority to our relationship with the People's Republic of China, not only because of its economic importance to Australia, which, as I have noted, is not that much greater than that of Taiwan, but because of its political and strategic importance.

I will conclude this part by noting that our visit extended the nature of Australia-Taiwan contacts in two important respects. For the first time, the Legislative Yuan was involved in planning and hosting a visit and we were accompanied throughout by an officer of the Legislative Yuan. I hope that this in part reflects an increasing appreciation of the value of specifically parliamentary exchanges and is perhaps also an indication of the emerging role of the Legislative Yuan. I believe that this is an important development because informal parliamentary visits can do much to fill out the relationship in the absence of more official government recognition.

I would also say that the person who accompanied us, Dr Lee, was a PhD and doctor of law graduate of Sydney University. He had the most incredible command of the English language. He probably had a more extensive vocabulary than most of us here, and was just delighted when some of the members of our delegation decided to teach him some of the vernacular. He had a capacity for learning languages that I have not seen in anybody else. He was delightful company, intelligent and stimulating in his conversation, and also had a great sense of humour. He really made some of what was already a great trip even better by his great sense of humour and his ability to understand what we were saying. There were no communication problems because of his great English ability and the fact that he had been to Australia for his PhD.

He was one of very few university graduates that we found in Taiwan who had been through the Australian university system. I think that the Australian universities should look very much to their laurels—not rest on them, but look to improving the situation. It is a country that values tertiary education, and Australia has a lot to offer in this field. But the market seems to be cornered by the universities of the United States. I think the Australian universities could do well to have a very serious look at how they can actually improve their access to this particular form of marketing, this particular area of endeavour.

Another part of our visit which I found extremely interesting was an excursion we made to Haulien county on the east coast, where we spent some time with members of the aboriginal community. The visit there was preceded by discussions in Taipei with some of the members of the Legislative Yuan who hold seats reserved for representatives of the aboriginal community. The warmth of the reception given to the delegation by the aboriginal people of Haulien and their eagerness to tell us about their lives and to show us some of their culture created one of the enduring memories of the delegation's tour, not to mention some of the more interesting photographs of the trip as well.

The opportunity to travel to Haulien was added to the delegation's program following an expression of interest in aboriginal issues by the delegation itself. This accommodation of our interest and the involvement of the Legislative Yuan in planning and managing our visit are good omens for the development of relations between the Australian parliament and the Legislative Yuan.

Also, when we went to Haulien county, we were able to visit what I think has to be considered one of the great wonders of the world, and that is Taroka Gorge. It was 10 days after a major typhoon had been through, and all through Taiwan we could see signs of some of the damage that was still there. In Taroka, at the bottom of this gorge, which was quite literally hundreds of feet down from the road, the river was still running a steely, murky grey, but the rock formations and the sheer cliffs that followed this gorge were amazing.

If anyone is wondering why Senator Brownhill is signalling like that, within this national park there are monkeys. When we got to our luncheon spot we were able to actually see the monkeys gambolling around the treetops across the other side of the gorge. It was an exciting experience, because I do not think any of the other delegates had seen monkeys in the wild—certainly I had not. Also in this national park there are bears and I think there was a snake as well. We did not want to see the snake, but the bears were up in an area that we could not get to.

This gorge is absolutely magnificent. It is well worth a visit. It should be on all of the international spots of great beauty, because it is absolutely stunning. It was also stunning to see the power of this typhoon as it had washed away bridges. The river had risen so high that parts of the roadway that we were travelling on—a lot of which, I have to say, had been hewn by hand in the last 40 or 50 years—had been washed away and were having to be repaired. For me, this visit to Taroka Gorge was an absolutely unbelievable and memorable experience, in conjunction with the visit to the aboriginal people in Haulien.

I would like to thank everybody involved in this trip for the hard work that was put in from the Australian end and by the people in Taiwan, the embassy of Yuan, and also by Ian Dundas, our secretary. It was a memorable trip. A number of the spouses came with us, and I think that added to our fun and enjoyment and our learning experience. We became like one big happy family. There was no acrimony and there was a lot of good camaraderie, good experience and good friendships that were made. I think that is what these sorts of trips are all about. They are not just about learning about the country which is being visited; they are about learning about our colleagues—and on this particular trip

SPEECH.PARA: that certainly happened. I think that we have fulfilled all of the ideals and the aims that we set ourselves. I commend this report to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with the remarks made by Senator West, the leader of the unofficial visit to Taiwan. The delegation, as Senator West said, was a very happy delegation. I must congratulate Senator West on her able leading of the delegation, and I was honoured to be her deputy on that leg of our delegation's trip through those areas that we have just been talking about.

PARA.TAB: Mr Hawker, Mr Horne and Mr McGauran were also members of the delegation; and Mr Ian Dundas, the secretary of the committee, as Senator West said, did an exemplary job once again. I did not mention the fact that our spouses were allowed to accompany us. I thank Japan, Korea and also Taiwan for allowing them to accompany us because, as Senator West said, it made a very big difference and it placed a better perspective on different issues that one cannot always pick up oneself when on a delegation.

As far as Taiwan is concerned, it is rather a matter of personal regret to me, as secretary of the Australia-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group, that we were not able to conduct a proper official visit. That is something I may talk about in a moment.

I first visited Taiwan in 1986. I noticed a great deal of change in the eight years since 1986, not the least being the fact that so many more people now are driving motor cars compared with when I had been there previously, when people rode about more on motor scooters.

I take this opportunity to thank our hosts in Taiwan for their courtesies and hospitality during our time there. Senator West has already mentioned Dr Lee. I was asked by one of my colleagues a little while ago whether I actually did teach any Australian slang to Dr Lee. I can assure senators that I did not. I am a very clear English speaker, even though I sometimes have trouble rolling my tongue around different things.

Dr Lee was a great help to us and gave us an insight into the modern Taiwan. Steve Waters, from Australian commerce and industry—our representative there, as Senator West said—was absolutely outstanding in giving us an insight into the country. That is what these delegations and these trips are all about. We go to learn about other countries, and we invite back to Australia people from those countries so that they may see what we have to offer.

We had a very informative program. We met with senior ministers, government officials and business leaders. In doing that, we did not have too much spare time, although the spare time we had was very much appreciated. We did see things that we requested to see. Taiwan is not just an industrial country; it is a country of great beauty, as Senator West has already indicated. Taiwan is our fourth largest trading partner in Asia. It is our seventh largest trading partner overall, with a total of something like $5.1 billion in world trade. It is good to see the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) in the chamber at the moment because he knows the importance to us of Taiwan as a trading nation. He knows we must keep our trade going well.

Trade is certainly in our favour at the moment, with a surplus of just under half a billion dollars. We export unprocessed foods and raw materials to Taiwan, although we are exporting increasing amounts of elaborately transformed manufactures—and that is important for Australia. From Taiwan we buy office machines, computers, metal products, textiles, electrical machinery, sporting goods, games and toys. It is a vibrant country and we must recognise its strong commercial links with Australia, despite the lack of recognition.

As a guest of Jerome Yen, I was able to be present last week here in Canberra at Taiwan's 83rd anniversary celebration. At that function, former Senator Brian Archer expressed hope that it would not be too long before Taiwan was able to take a place in the United Nations. There is evidence in Taiwan of a review of that position. We have to remember that Taiwan has been restructured. It is changing its position in terms of full membership of the United Nations; it has to come into the mainstream of world politics.

The Taiwanese believe that they are a continuation of the republic of 1912. There is a feeling among some people in Taiwan that countries with populations of only 100,000 are members of the United Nations, whereas Taiwan, with 21 million people, is denied such membership. Because Taiwan is denied a position in the world forum, it is being excluded from international and multilateral arrangements. Its status of recognition obviously will be addressed in the future.

Our bilateral relations with Taiwan are magnificent in that we now have direct air links. The fact that we could fly back directly from Taiwan to Australia was a big change and I am sure will help our relationships in the future. Senator West already mentioned our visit to the east coast and to the aboriginal areas where some 266,000 hectares of country, about seven per cent, has been set aside for the aboriginals of the area. The hospitality that we received in that neck of the woods is something I will remember for the rest of my life.

Some 50 per cent of beef in Taiwan is imported. That is an area where Australia must remain vigilant to try to make sure that we get our share of any increase in imports. I had visited the Taipei World Trade Centre once before. It was great to visit it again, along with visits to China Steel and other places I had visited before. There are 800,000 farmers in Taiwan. As a farmer myself, I took a great interest in meeting farmers there. Farmers comprise about 3.8 per cent of the work force of that country, whereas here in Australia our farming community comprises only 0.64 per cent of the total community. We must be cognisant of comments by the leaders of Taiwan that agriculture holds the key to national development. The Taiwanese lead the world in fish farming. They are good performers in tourism and trade generally, but they are bad performers as far as we are concerned in terms of education and investment in Australia. Those are areas in which we must work hard in putting Australia's case.

We must regard the subject of education as a serious export to countries such as Taiwan. I believe it is one of the areas that we have to work hard at as a country. We must seek to ensure that other countries of the world want to send people here to gain tertiary education, and in so doing to meet Australians. One hopes that when such people get to the top of their companies or make achievements in their lives, they will want to build on their relationships with us.

We in Australia need prestige and quality-seeking universities rather than price conscious educational institutions. We need universities that are more coordinated and which have less rivalry when trying to sell their education facilities to Taiwan or any other parts of the world. We have to have the Oxfords or Cambridges here in Australia because that is what the Taiwanese are looking for when they go overseas. They want a university of prestige.

Our trade with Taiwan suffers from the lack of political willpower. Business does react to politicians and we as politicians have to push more to further our trade with Taiwan—and I am talking about here and now. Certainly Taiwan should not be ignored but often is. We should be working hard at improving our links with Taiwan. We must sell our Australian culture—and that is not happening in some of the countries we visited—to get it known to the people in that region.

Much needs to be done in Taiwan in terms of the environment. Since 1986, when I was last there, the Taiwanese have started to rectify some of the problems. There has been quite a change but there is still a lot to be done. There is a niche for Australia to be in on the side of environmental changes. When this morning I scanned the official itinerary for the delegation's visit, I noticed that our pace was just as constant in Taiwan as it was anywhere else. It was very worthwhile. The fact that my fellow travellers all arrived home very tired showed that we worked hard and learnt a lot. I hope one day that we can return to re-examine what is happening there. I hope that some of the people who come here from Taiwan will learn that we want to be their big trading partners. I again wish to thank my fellow travellers. I also thank the secretariat, the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade people and others here in Austrade who gave us good briefings on Taiwan before we went. I congratulate Senator West on the way she led the delegation in Taiwan.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Message from His Excellency the Administrator of the Commonwealth of Australia was reported informing the Senate that His Excellency had, in the name of Her Majesty, assented to the following law:
Debate resumed.
Clause 11.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we adjourned this debate we were debating the opposition's amendment No. 5, which deals with the definition of an organisation. At the time the debate was adjourned I was saying that letters carried between offices of an organisation may not now be able to be carried in the same way as before and that this may impose an extreme penalty on some.

PARA.TAB: I can quote one example which demonstrates the absurdity that arises even in the context of partnerships. I refer to the firm of Sly and Weigall, the lawyers who act for Ausdoc who appeared before a committee hearing. That law firm comprises one partnership of which the Sydney partners and the Canberra partners are members. Accordingly, a letter can be sent by courier from the Sydney office to the Canberra office of Sly and Weigall. That comes under the exceptions because it is within the definition of an organisation.

It just so happens that, for historical reasons, the Melbourne office of Sly and Weigall is a separate partnership. Neither the Sydney office nor the Canberra office could have a letter couriered to the Melbourne office unless it came within one of the other exceptions relating to price and weight—it would have to go by Australia Post. Other organisations affected are state governments. Under the definition of organisation—I guess this also applies to the Commonwealth government—separate departments are regarded as separate organisations so document exchanges cannot take place between two departments by an end to end service.

The opposition has moved this amendment because we believe it gives us a much tidier definition of organisation and certainly one which would benefit the majority of those people who use document exchanges for the purposes that I described earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Ferguson said, this amendment seeks to broaden the definition of organisation for which internal mail is made an exception to the reserve services. It is an attempt to open more of the reserve services to competition.

PARA.TAB: When we were considering this amendment before lunch Senator Ferguson said that he would like to know the Australian Democrats' basic reason for not supporting this amendment. The basic reason is that Senator Ferguson and the opposition would like to see Australia Post deregulated to as large an extent as possible and we would rather see Australia Post stay where it is as far as regulation goes. That is the reason for the position we have taken in relation to this amendment. A line has to be drawn somewhere. Wherever we draw the line, there will be drawbacks and it will look somewhat artificial. But we feel that the line might as well be drawn here, where it is. We think this bill already goes too far in deregulating Australia Post and we will not support any further deregulation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the government I indicate that we will not accept the opposition's proposed amendment. I make the following points. We note that the opposition is not content that we have agreed to allow the carriage of mail between offices of the one organisation to permit a company to contract out its internal mail deliveries. The opposition now wants to ensure that this step towards liberalisation is extended way beyond the scope intended by the government's phased approach to competition. The current act reserves to Australia Post the collection and delivery of organisations' letters unless the organisations use one of their own employees now that the mailbag may be contracted out in certain circumstances.

PARA.TAB: The government does not propose to provide greater liberalisation at this time nor approve any current illegal practices. The amendment takes no account of the fact that the bill deliberately sought to place both the public and private sectors on the same footing. The opposition amendment is therefore inconsistent with that approach.

The changes in this legislation are best seen as a transitional stage to test competition in the letters market, ensuring Australia Post is still able to meet its community service obligations. There will be further opportunity to revisit these issues in the 1996-97 review of competitive arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —The real concern in our moving amendment No. 5 is that the current definition of an organisation in the proposed legislation is much too narrow and, in particular, does not treat a company and its subsidiaries as a single body. It is also of significance that the definition treats state government departments as separate organisations. Therefore, the transport of mail between departments within a state government—in particular, the concern of the Victorian government has been raised in relation to this matter—would not be able to be undertaken by a private contractor. It would have to be reserved for Australia Post under the legislation as it is drafted.

PARA.TAB: In a Senate committee hearing on this legislation the minister responded that the existing legislation does not prevent employees of an organisation from delivering mail. But that is not sufficient in our view. We want organisations to be able to contract out the delivery of their mail when that mail is being delivered between various sections of an organisation—whether it is between different offices of the one company, between a company and its subsidiary or various subsidiaries, or, as I have already indicated, between departments of a state government.

We have moved this amendment to ensure that there is a broader definition of organisation, so that related bodies within the meaning of the Corporations Act 1989 will be able to contract out the carriage of mail between their various constituent parts. We believe that is only reasonable. Again, if the government is really interested in reducing the costs in the business environment so that Australian businesses can be as efficient and competitive as possible, this amendment ought to pass through the Senate and be incorporated into the legislation.
Amendment negatived.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 12 and 13—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 14.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 14, page 8, at end of proposed subsection 32A(2), add the following word and paragraph:
";and (d)specify that the rate reduction mentioned in subsection (1) applies to interstate deliveries and to intrastate deliveries".

SPEECH.PARA: The Australia Post explanatory notes in relation to the bill indicate that the proposed interconnection arrangements will apply only to bulk mail which crosses state borders. This restriction discriminates against larger states. For example, interconnection discounts may apply to bulk mail that is transported by private contractor between Sydney and Melbourne, but not to bulk mail transported from Cairns to Brisbane—which is nearly one and half times the distance. This amendment seeks to ensure that interconnection discounts are not restricted to interstate mail. I think the rest is self-explanatory without my going into any further detail.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not accept the amendment proposed by the opposition. It is unnecessary because the bill does not limit the application of the rate reductions to apply to the bulk mail interconnect service. The current terms and conditions only include interstate rates and are a commercial decision by Australia Post. It reflects the assessment that there are no savings to Australia Post on intrastate transportation by other operators.

PARA.TAB: The schedule of discounts being proposed has been reviewed by the Prices Surveillance Authority, which has not expressed any objection either to the charges themselves or to the rationale on which they have been determined. Operators' access to appropriate discount rates is assured because the bill provides for the arbitration role of the Trade Practices Commission in the new section 32B. If anyone wants intrastate discounts and Australia Post declines, that person can ask the TPC to arbitrate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Ferguson on behalf of the opposition. In doing so, I direct the minister's attention to evidence that was given before the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Communications and Infrastructure in regard to the bulk interconnection service rate. The minister said that there is nothing in the legislation to prevent an intrastate bulk interconnection rate being provided but that it was a commercial decision taken by Australia Post.

PARA.TAB: I refer the minister to evidence given to the committee on 19 September 1994. Australia Post then said that the nature of avoidable cost had prompted the government to restrict competition within the intrastate line haul area on the grounds that there are avoidable costs of transferring letters interstate but minimal avoidable costs for transporting letters within a state, because even when the volume reduces the infrastructure remains the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, that is true.

—In his remarks a moment ago the minister said it was a commercial decision taken by Australia Post; he did not say that it was a decision taken by the government. Can the minister tell us which it is?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not a member of the committee but that was evidence provided by Australia Post.
—That is right.

—I can only suppose that Australia Post is using the definition of itself and the government as one; but I am informed by my advisers that it was a decision by Australia Post. I want to emphasise the last point I made in response to the amendment, namely, that the TPC will arbitrate if there is a dispute on price. As I understand it, that is a new provision that has been inserted and the TPC will be the arbitrator.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Chapman looks at the recent record of the Trade Practices Commission under the chairmanship of Professor Fels—who is a great devotee of Hilmer competition policy, et cetera—I would be staggered if a private operator could not get a fair shake out of the TPC on what was a competitive rate for intrastate services provided by Australia Post. If Australia Post tries to jack it up and overcharge to knock the private operator around, I think an application to the TPC, in view of its recent track record, would be looked upon very favourably. I am sure that after one or two rounds with Professor Fels and his gang at the TPC, Australia Post would quite rightly learn its lesson and not try to use the system to put private operators at a disadvantage. I think that is a new provision that ought to be acknowledged.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that response. I simply make the point that one of the companies that gave evidence to the committee, Mayne Nickless, expressed the view that intrastate work was the component of total cost that was most likely to benefit from competition. Therefore, Mayne Nickless put to the committee the argument that the intrastate segment for bulk mail, as well as the interstate segment, ought to be opened to competition.

PARA.TAB: The minister talked about the Trade Practices Commission, but the Prices Surveillance Authority also expressed concern that discounts will apply only if the bulk mail has been transported interstate by a private mail operator and not intrastate. We believe that the situation ought to be clarified by being spelt out in the legislation; and that bulk mail interconnection rates ought to be available for both interstate and intrastate private mail carrier operators. It is for that reason that we have moved this amendment, which I believe is worthy of support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been given further advice. I point out to Senator Chapman that a Mr Ludlow, an officer of Australia Post, gave evidence to the Senate committee on 19 September and said:

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that we did not propose to the PSA that intrastate be included was due to a matter of clarity and simplicity within our price structure.
In that evidence, which is set out on page 27 of the report, Mr Ludlow made it pretty clear that he was speaking on behalf of Australia Post.

PARA.TAB: I want to put on record some further points about this issue. The government agrees that Australia Post be required to provide additional discounts to bulk mail customers based on Australia Post's estimate of the average transport cost per letter avoided by Australia Post in respect of letters lodged for delivery under the bulk mail interconnect service. The main costs avoided by Australia Post are on transport. Discounts will continue to be provided separately for bulk mail lodgments that are pre-sorted and where mailers undertake some other part of the service instead of Australia Post. Under this service customers will have the choice of using operators other than Australia Post who may charge less than Australia Post for the transportation of mail to a point close to the point of final destination, or be able to ensure that mail is transported to a certain location for final delivery by a guaranteed time.

Australia Post will publish discount schedules which will be made available at post offices, with different rates expected to apply for letters delivered in the same state of lodgment from those lodged for delivery in another state. Australia Post has consulted the Prices Surveillance Authority and held a public forum in April to consult with major bulk mail customers on the proposed arrangements, and the proposed schedule of charges has been approved by the Prices Surveillance Authority. A copy of approval and schedule is attached to the brief that I have. In view of the interest this matter is generating, I seek leave for this material to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
