TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be able to influence the terms and conditions for interconnection through the PSA monitoring of reserved letter prices, including for bulk mail; the ministerial power of review of standard letter prices; and an independent investigation by the Trade Practices Commission, which will report to the minister on disputes between Australia Post and a bulk mailer in relation to the level of discount to apply. The minister may direct Australia Post to act in accordance with the commission's recommendation but may not vary it.

PARA.TAB: It can be seen that we have a pretty well balanced arrangement for the bulk mail industry for intrastate service. We have indicated that it can charge lower than post offices because of the interconnection arrangements. So Senator Chapman's plea for the amendment is starting to hack into Australia Post at a level that will just mean someone else having to pick up the loss. The amendment would start to affect the operation of Australia Post as a balanced GBE operating a holistic approach to handling its commercial activities as well as providing a community service.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 15 agreed to.
Clause 16.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be opposing clause 16. The clause prohibits the discounting of stamps and postal franks. It is claimed by Australia Post that a small number—and we believe it is a very small number—of postal agents and licensees have been selling stamps to customers at a discounted price. However, the post office agents say that Australia Post itself effectively discounts by allowing bulk mail and advertising discounts. In effect, it is doing exactly the same thing. While I know that special conditions apply to these discounts, they are available only to post offices and not to postal agents or licensees. This means that the latter can miss out on a significant amount of business.

PARA.TAB: Post office agents also claim that Australia Post is out touting for this sort of business by using discounts and bulk mail discounts. Post office agents claim that the proposed provisions in the bill are like taking a sledgehammer to an ant. I certainly believe that the government is taking a very big stick to rectify what is supposedly a very minor problem. Australia Post says that it is a minor problem and the post office agents themselves say that it happens only a very few times.

The provisions allow Australia Post to take out a Federal Court injunction if there is evidence of discounting. We would have to agree that allowing Australia Post to take out a Federal Court injunction when there is evidence of discounting is just amazing. We do not believe that bulk mail and advertising discounts should be reserved only to post offices run by Australia Post. We also know that there is no evidence to suggest that there is widespread discounting which requires such tough provisions in the bill.

I am not sure of the Democrats' position on this clause. We know that Australia Post offers discounts, and probably just about everybody in this place is aware of the fact that such discounts can be obtained. No doubt some people will claim that Australia Post is supposed to provide a uniform service at a uniform price. That may have been the case once, but right now this argument falls down because it does not apply to bulk mail and advertising mail discounts. In fact, as I have pointed out, Australia Post does discount.

For that reason, we will be opposing clause 16. The steps taken by the government in this clause to try to stamp out what it believes is a very small number of postal agents and licensees who have been selling stamps to customers at discounted prices is taking far too big a stick to solve a very small problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Ferguson said, this clause prohibits the sale of postage stamps below face value. The Democrats will be supporting the clause as it stands. We will not be opposing it, because we believe it would eat into Australia Post revenue by encouraging stamp price discounting. We understand that discounting has been started by only a few licensed post offices in recent times and we do not want it to get any bigger.

PARA.TAB: The competition introduced by this bill goes far enough and we do not want to see it go even further. The Post Office Agents Association has said to us that the situation is unfair because Australia Post is free to offer discounts in other areas; but licensed post offices are also free to discount non-stamp Australia Post products in the spirit of competition. We see absolutely no problem with that; but we do not see why stamps should be able to be discounted, thus taking business away from post offices, as they stand at the moment. We will be supporting clause 16.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason for the prohibition on discounts in the retail price of stamps is to ensure that all people can have access to a standard letter service at a uniform rate of postage. This is the case whether they buy stamps from Australia Post or from a licensed post office or post office agent. It is not equitable that a person buys stamps from one postal outlet at one price, while another person pays a higher or lower price for the same service elsewhere. Maintaining an efficient national delivery network requires economies of scale, and random discounting by some outlets reduces revenue and undermines these economies, which affects services for all users.

PARA.TAB: Since 1910, Australia Post has held an exclusive right to issue postage stamps, enabling it to make a letter service reasonably accessible to all Australians wherever they reside or carry on business. Clarifying the position on the retail sale of stamps ensures that this policy can be upheld while Australia Post completes its current retail networking restructuring and with all users making a reasonable contribution to the cost of maintaining the network. These issues will be revisited in the 1996-97 review of competitive arrangements.

I have to say to Senator Ferguson, who represents and takes a particular interest in rural areas, that if we allowed the discounting of stamps, I bet one stamp to London Bridge that the cheapest stamps would be available in the metropolitan area and not in rural areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —So is cheaper petrol and so is cheaper everything else.

—Yes, I know. But the point is that again it will be seen as another disadvantage for regional or rural Australia. Then the next argument will be, `Well, we can't get discounted stamps in our rural area as can people in the metropolitan area. Therefore, we want the government to subsidise or reduce the price overall.' So a downward cycle starts to occur which will affect revenue and the overall national system.

PARA.TAB: There will be a review of these arrangements in 1996-97 and the industry—and, above all else, the community—will have a chance to see how these arrangements are working. We have this bill about right in the balance between effective competition and providing a broad service to all members of the Australian community. We ask the chamber to reject the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that the minister has missed the point entirely. The issue raised by Senator Ferguson—as I understood what Senator Ferguson had to say—was not so much whether or not stamps should be discounted but who should be able to discount stamps. As he indicated, there is evidence that certain Australia Post outlets are already discounting stamps—selling stamps at below their face value.
—Not at a retail level. Give us an example.
—Bulk mail stamp rates.

—As Senator Ferguson has interjected, people can get bulk mail rates from certain Australia Post outlets but not from others. Obviously, that is inequitable. It is not a matter of whether there are discounts but of who is entitled to provide them. If certain Australia Post outlets are entitled to provide discounts to their customers, and an agency wants to provide the same discount, why should it be prevented from doing so? That is the issue that the minister needs to consider.
—The minister has said all along that the object is to provide a uniform service at a uniform price, but that does not happen.
—On the stamp; you are confusing the bulk rate.
—The minister is saying that it is okay for Australia Post to discount but it is not okay for agents. That is not uniform pricing.
—But they do not discount the actual sale at the retail level.

—They do. If people ask for a bulk rate when they have a number of articles to post, they can get those letters franked at a discount rate, but not if they go to a post agent. So it is not a uniform service at a uniform price.

PARA.TAB: There is a definite advantage to Australia Post in this particular area. The minister is talking about making sure that people do not undercut Australia Post, but we have a situation where Australia Post can undercut the agents.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are undercutting because they provide a bulk service.

—But if people go to a postal agent with bulk mailing to be done, they cannot get stamps at a cheaper rate. They can only take their bulk mail to Australia Post to negotiate a special deal. I am making the point that there is not a uniform service for a uniform price. Australia Post has a definite advantage in being able to offer discounts that other agents are not allowed to offer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we might be at cross-purposes here. Senator Ferguson is talking about situations where people have bulk mail. Because their letters have been pre-sorted in some form or another, which helps the post office, the post office offers a discount rate. That is fine; that is a bulk rate for the service provided.

PARA.TAB: If this clause were opposed, the standard stamp rate of 45c could be varied all over the place because there would be a competitive arrangement on individual stamps irrespective of the service provided. Once that happens, we would no longer have a standard stamp rate across Australia and that would be inequitable. As a former state party secretary, I have been driven to distraction by having to pre-sort election leaflets and direct mail for every post code in South Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't we all!

—I suppose it has driven all of us nuts, bundling things up till 3 o'clock in the morning. We all know that if we pre-sort we will get a bulk rate discount. That is different from what Senator Ferguson is proposing. With his proposal, the individual standard stamp rate will no longer be 45c. He is proposing that post offices be able to sell a standard stamp individually at a discount rate—say at 43c—and with no change of service, simply to create throughput. I can see big city post offices with big throughputs being able to offer the discount but guess who will lose out—the smaller country post offices that do not have the throughput.
—They are not going to lose; they're 45c now.

—But when people in the country see people in the city—say, at the Goodger Street post office—getting a discount when they are still paying 45c, I know what the short-term reaction will be. They will be asking why people can get a stamp for a postcard from the Goodger Street post office for 43c while they are paying 45c at the Port Vic post office.
—They are used to that.

—No, they are not used to that because at the moment everyone pays 45c. Nothing irritates people in the bush more than that sort of discrepancy. We are talking here about a GBE with certain monopoly rights, out of which city people would be doing better than country people. I do not think that is the best outcome.

PARA.TAB: At the moment there is cross-subsidisation so that service to the bush is maintained by the profits from the bigger post offices in the city. If we allow discounting on the standard rate, quite apart from the bulk service area, we will find that the ability of the post office to cross-subsidise will reduce. The taxpayer will then have to pick up the difference as a community service obligation—and we all know how difficult it is to argue for that in the budget. In the end, it will mean reduced services to rural and regional Australia. Nevertheless, I can indicate that in the review of competitive arrangements in 1996-97 these issues can be revisited.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 17 to 24—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 25.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 25, page 13, lines 26 to 35, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
"25. Section 79 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subsections (5) and (6).".

The bill seeks to extend the circumstances in which the Governor-General may terminate the appointment of the director of the board of Australia Post. Under clause 25 of the bill, the Governor-General may terminate that appointment if the minister is of the opinion that the board has not notified the minister of significant events, has not notified the minister of significant business activities, or has not kept the minister informed or has not provided reports, documents and information required by the minister.

PARA.TAB: We consider that the granting of such powers to the minister provides an undesirable degree of government leverage over Australia Post's corporate operation. It creates a very dangerous precedent and we do not believe that it should be supported. Therefore, this amendment seeks to prevent the proposed extension of the circumstances in which the appointment of a director may be terminated.

We agree that significant matters need to be reported but we do not agree that the minister should have sole discretion in determining what is important. As it presently stands, the bill significantly widens the minister's power to dismiss a director of the board of Australia Post and for that reason requires amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment seeks to prevent the minister from sacking the board for failing to inform the minister of significant financial and corporate developments. We believe that the minister should be informed at all times of significant financial and corporate developments. This chamber would probably be the first to complain if we wanted to know that sort of information and the minister did not have it because he or she had not been informed. We note that a general power to sack the board exists in section 79 of the act anyway and we see no problem with the bill's attempt to make the board more accountable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Bourne was spot on when she said this place would be the first to move to censure the minister if he did not act decisively if something went wrong and the director did not properly inform the minister. We have already had a number of cases—certainly all the cases in which I have been involved in this place—of the Senate censuring ministers, I think inappropriately. The difficulty we always have with the current opposition is that, if a minister does take the appropriate action, he or she gets condemned or censured. If he or she does not take the appropriate action, he or she gets censured. In the context in which we are moving with government business enterprises, the minister must be expected to be able to have the power to deal with a director who does not keep him informed in the appropriate manner, as outlined in the legislation.

PARA.TAB: The government will obviously not accept the amendment. The amendment proposes the removal of the new provisions requiring the Governor-General to dismiss any director who, in the opinion of the minister, fails to comply with an obligation under sections 41, 46 or 47. Section 41 requires the preparation of an annual report, sets out audit requirements and requires tabling by the minister. Section 46 requires the board to notify the minister of significant business activities, including the formation of subsidiaries requiring substantial business, and taking on a significant new business activity. Section 47 requires the board to keep the minister informed of the operations of Australia Post and to provide such information or reports relating to those operations. It is very basic, business-type information on which one would expect a director to keep a minister fully informed. If the director did not, I think there would be a good case, depending on the circumstances, for the minister to deal with the director.

These provisions reflect government policy to apply to all Commonwealth authorities and companies. They do not provide the minister with any particular leverage over the board. The legislation in which these provisions will be given general effect, the companies and corporations bill, has been examined by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and it did not comment on these provisions. So we strongly believe that this amendment should be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no doubt, as Senator Ferguson said in moving this amendment on behalf of the opposition, that clause 25 of the bill as it is currently drafted gives undue discretion and undue power to the minister to terminate the appointment of a member of the board of Australia Post. The legislation clearly extends the circumstances in which a minister may recommend to the Governor-General, and, in effect, require the Governor-General, to terminate the appointment of a director of the board of Australia Post.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bourne referred to section 79 of the existing act, which provides the conditions under which the appointment of a director may be terminated. As I read those conditions, they appear to me to be quite adequate. In essence, apart from misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity, the Governor-General shall terminate a director's appointment where the minister is of the opinion that the performance of a particular director has been unsatisfactory for a significant period of time. I believe that strikes the correct balance.

On a number of occasions earlier in the debate when we proposed amendments the various ministers at the table said, `The opposition in its amendment wants us to go further with this legislation, the Democrats don't want us to go as far as we have gone, but we believe as a government that we have struck the right balance with this legislation.' In relation to this issue, I believe the existing act strikes the right balance. It sets out reasonable conditions under which the appointment of a member of the board of Australia Post may be terminated—that is, where the minister is of the opinion that the performance of a particular director has been unsatisfactory for a significant period of time. In other words, the government can monitor the performance of the board and individual directors. If, over a period of time, it believes they are not complying with the requirements of the legislation and fulfilling their duties adequately as directors, they can be sacked.

The clause in the amending bill gives the minister the opportunity to much more capriciously sack a member of the board. We believe that is unreasonable and unsatisfactory because it is much more dependent on the immediate opinion of the minister than the opinion the minister may have developed over a period of time. So it does open itself up to capricious behaviour on the part of the minister. It gives the minister undue power and discretion and therefore effectively gives the government an undesirable degree of leverage over Australia Post's corporate operations.

We believe for those reasons, and the fact that it creates a dangerous precedent, that this extension of the circumstances for the sacking of members of the board should not be supported. As an alternative, the amendment proposed by the opposition ought to be supported, which will prevent the proposed extension of the circumstances under which the appointment of a board member may be terminated.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 26 to 28—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 29.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 29, page 27, after proposed subsection 90ZA(1), insert the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: " `(1A) Australia Post must ensure that, before the article is destroyed, the following information is recorded, to the extent to which it is evident without unfastening or physically interfering with the article's cover:

TAB.TAB: (a)the sender's name and address;
(b)the intended recipient's name and address;
(c)what the article contains.

PARA.TAB: `(1B) If the sender's name and address has been recorded, Australia Post must, as soon as practicable after the article's destruction, cause written notice to be given to the sender:

TAB.TAB: (a)advising of the article's destruction and the reasons for its destruction; and
(b)stating the following information, if it has been recorded:
(i)the intended recipient's name and address;
(ii)what the article contained.

PARA.TAB: `(1C) If the sender's name and address has not been recorded but the intended recipient's name and address has been recorded, Australia Post must, as soon as practicable after the article's destruction, cause written notice to be given to the intended recipient:

TAB.TAB: (a)advising of the article's destruction and the reasons for its destruction; and
(b)stating what the article contained, if that information has been recorded.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment would ensure that, as far as physically offensive mail is concerned, before an article is destroyed certain information is recorded; that is, the sender's name and address, the intended recipient's name and address and what the article contains. If the sender's name and address have been recorded, Australia Post has to give written notice to the sender that it has been destroyed, with some other information.

PARA.TAB: We understand from Australia Post that physically offensive mail is very physically offensive in general and that, in general, if it is physically offensive mail, it is meant to offend the person at the other end. It is very seldom sent by accident—say, fruit or something that is rotting—so it would not be appropriate to tell the person at the other end that the mail had been destroyed or even that it had been in the mail. We understand that we do have support for this amendment. It basically provides for a bit more accountability so that people inside Australia Post have to write down when they destroy something and have to tell the person who sent the item that it has been destroyed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will support the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Proposed clause 9A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move my postponed amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)After clause 9, page 4, insert the following clause:
"9A. After Division 1 of Part 3 of the Principal Act the following Division is inserted:
`28B. In this Division:
"performance audit report" means a report under section 28D;
"prescribed performance standards" has the meaning given by subsection 28C(1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Performance standards to be met by Australia Post

SPEECH.PARA: `28C.(1) The regulations may prescribe performance standards (the "prescribed performance standards") to be met by Australia Post.

PARA.TAB: `(2) The prescribed performance standards must relate to:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the frequency, speed or accuracy of mail delivery; or
(b)the availability or accessibility of:
(i)post-boxes or other mail lodgement points; or
(ii)offices of Australia Post or other places from which Australia Post products or services may be purchased.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Auditor-General to report on compliance with prescribed performance standards

PARA.TAB: `28D.(1) The Auditor-General must, in relation to the financial year starting on 1 July 1994 and each later financial year, audit, and report on, the extent to which, during the financial year, Australia Post met the prescribed performance standards that were in force.

`(2) The audit must be conducted in accordance with a methodology that the Auditor-General determines is consistent with prevailing performance audit methodology, and a statement of the methodology used in conducting the audit must be included in the report.

`(3) The Auditor-General may request Australia Post to supply information that the Auditor-General considers is reasonably necessary to perform the audit, and Australia Post must comply with the request.
`(4) The Auditor-General must give the report to the Minister on or before 1 November in the next financial year.
`(5) The Minister must cause a copy of the report to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after its receipt by the Minister.

`28E.(1) If, in a performance audit report, the Auditor-General reports that Australia Post has not met a prescribed performance standard, Australia Post must prepare a service improvement plan to ensure it meets that prescribed performance standard as soon as practicable.
`(2) The service improvement plan must be given to the Minister on or before 1 March in the financial year after the financial year to which the performance audit report relates.
`(3) The Minister must cause a copy of the service improvement plan to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after its receipt by the Minister.'."

SPEECH.PARA: Our first amendment seeks to insert clause 9A and would empower the minister to set performance standards for Australia Post by regulation. Australia Post's performance against those standards would be scrutinised by the Auditor-General and underperformance would have to be rectified by Australia Post devising a service improvement plan. The audit results and service improvement plans would then be tabled in parliament. Standards could cover the frequency, speed or accuracy of mail delivery, the availability of mail lodgment points or the availability of retail postal services—for example, through post offices. We envisage that national standards would be set, based initially on the standards in Australia Post's corporate plan. Remaining standards will concentrate on areas which do not receive the benefits of competition, in particular, rural and remote areas.

PARA.TAB: We are pleased that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology will be reviewing services to remote and rural areas inside the life of every parliament. This amendment provides an important framework for these reviews. We believe that the minister should take into account the results of the first review before deciding the additional standards, and our amendment provides the flexibility for that to happen.

The purpose of the amendment is twofold: on the one hand, it provides an accountability mechanism for improving postal services in rural and remote areas; and, on the other, it prevents the introduction of further competition, which we believe is likely, particularly under a coalition government, from eroding services in those areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —We certainly will not be opposing this amendment, but I would like to make one comment. In moving this amendment, Senator Bourne spoke about trying to improve services to rural and remote areas. Earlier, we tried to move an amendment to ensure some immediate improvement, particularly to roadside delivery services. The Democrats talk about wanting performance standards and audits in place before those improvements in services to rural and remote areas can take place. I think it is only delaying what might be available to those people already. Senator Bourne is taking things a bit far by talking about this proposed new division providing a better service and better standards to rural and remote areas. Earlier, we had the opportunity to improve those standards, had our amendment been initially carried.

PARA.TAB: While we will not be opposing this very long and convoluted amendment, I would have much preferred the Democrats' agreement to a very simple clause which would have improved services to country areas far sooner than a revision of performance standards and an audit will allow. I am not going to say we reluctantly agree. We certainly do not oppose this because we can see that it also has some merit; but, in saying so, I believe there is also merit in some immediate consideration of those services which are currently not being supplied to people in rural and remote areas who, we believe, should be getting them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot agree with Senator Ferguson's criticism, particularly relating to that earlier amendment that we rejected. It was clear from a government perspective, and I think the Democrats made similar comments, that the opposition's amendment would have significantly weakened the community service obligations and led to a lessening of service for rural and remote communities.

PARA.TAB: In regard to this amendment, the government has confirmed that service standards to rural and remote areas will be maintained and has agreed that a letter service should continue to be made available at a uniform rate of postage to all Australians wherever they reside. To safeguard rural postal services, the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) announced in a joint press statement in February this year a parliamentary review of Australia Post's community service obligations which is to be completed once in each parliamentary term. Representatives of rural and remote communities will be invited to contribute to the review, which will provide these communities with an opportunity to have a direct say in their postal services. The government believes that it would be premature to move away from this approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is if they ever get the letter on time.

—I can tell Senator Ferguson that, in Tasmania, we will make absolutely sure that they get their letters on time. That is one of the reasons we reject the opposition's general philosophical approach in this area. However, while mechanisms are already available for the minister to change community service obligations, and the government considers this to be the appropriate policy for ensuring that services in rural and remote areas are adequate, equitable and up to date, to assist the passage of the legislation the government will not oppose this amendment. This is on the basis that there is an understanding that the minister will consider any performance standards regulations after the parliamentary reviews into Australia Post's community service obligations.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Remainder of the bill—by leave—taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Sherry) read a third time.
Debate resumed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the current Austudy-Abstudy supplement introduced on 1 January 1993, voluntary student loans are available to tertiary students who wish to trade in part or all of their Austudy-Abstudy benefits for an interest-free loan of twice the amount of benefit traded. The Student Assistance (Budget Matters) Amendment Bill removes the existing repayment deadlines so students who have received Austudy payments can repay all or part of the benefit at any time during the year in order to maximise the amount of their supplementary loan. The bill also makes supplementary loans available to students who do not currently qualify for Austudy due to the spouse income test, provided that the spouse's income is less than $35,000. The coalition does not oppose these new provisions to the Austudy-Abstudy supplement scheme.

PARA.TAB: When the second reading debate on this bill commenced on 20 September, the coalition moved a very important amendment designed to address the great social inequity of rural students being excluded from participating in tertiary education. The intent of the coalition's amendment was to exempt the Austudy assets test for farm families declared to be in exceptional circumstances during the period of that declaration. I am heartened that the government finally acknowledged this great injustice in its drought relief package that it brought down on 21 September, with the commitment to remove the assets test for all families in exceptional drought areas.

This measure will provide relief for many people. I just do not know how many people; I expect it will be 7,000 or 8,000 when all the applications are in. Last week in Queensland, 3,000 applications came in, and I know many more will come in. It has given those people some relief out there to know that their children will receive a tertiary education. However, we do believe that the government's measures do not go far enough. We will persist in moving our amendments to exempt the Austudy assets test for farm families in exceptional circumstances, because this exemption will also encompass the farm families struggling on low or zero incomes due to exceptional circumstances but not necessarily drought induced exceptional circumstances.

There are a number of people now on wool exceptional circumstances. Wool exceptional circumstances funding finished on 30 June but there are still 1,900 people accessing funds under those wool exceptional circumstances. Under the government's drought package those people would be ineligible to receive Austudy for their children's education.

Our amendment would also benefit farm families in South Australia and Victoria suffering from exceptional circumstances beyond their control such as severe frosts, destroyed harvests or things of that nature. We also have grave concerns about the prospects of rural young people who are living in regions not currently declared severely drought affected but which have been drought affected in the past and, as a result, whose families are struggling to meet their commitments as they are still paying off debts that they have built up over a period of very high interest rates.

The government's new Austudy provisions in the drought relief package will not help those young people. In order to alleviate the barrier that rural youth have traditionally faced in accessing tertiary education, the coalition twice moved an amendment to a student assistance bill earlier in the year to waive the Austudy assets test to all holders of a health care card, which was issued by the Department of Social Security to low income earners. We moved that amendment twice, and I understand that the Democrats will move a similar amendment today. We will support the amendment moved by Senator Bell because, in effect, it is the same as the amendment that we moved previously.

A key government budget commitment last year was to exempt the Austudy assets test for all health care cardholders. The commitment was stated in various Department of Employment, Education and Training publications, including the Austudy application form, the Austudy guide to student finance, the DEET budget kit and a DEET press release. Those are four commitments that the government made to students who could not access Austudy.

There are many people out in rural Australia who could access a health card. Some have accessed the card and some are struggling not to do it. That was a commitment given in black and white in the budget, and the government and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Crean, reneged on that. He came in and apologised and said that it was a departmental mistake and he had nothing really to do with it.

A lot of that goes on in the Labor Party. People in departments make mistakes—and we have seen it in respect of the CAA today—where ministers will just not accept the responsibilities of their departments. They do a Pontius Pilate and say, `Well, it really isn't our fault because the department made a mistake.' Under the Westminster system, the minister is responsible for his department and he must either honour the commitment of his department or resign. The minister responsible for education certainly has not resigned. Many students thought they would be able to undertake their tertiary education, given the commitment of the health care card, only to have their hopes dashed.

The government broke this commitment on 7 February, 1994 with no public announcement whatsoever. It broke the commitment when the Austudy officers were advised by an internal memo that the assets test was to be applied to all applications. With this callous revocation, the government smashed the hopes and aspirations of a number of young people. I have spoken to these young people and, in fact, some of them have gone on television to present their case to the people. I believe the young people who did that certainly put pressure on the government in such a way that the government had to respond with a drought relief package that included some assistance to Austudy.

As I have said before, I believe the Democrats have picked up this amendment, which was carried twice in the Senate, in the face of unmoving opposition by the government. The government has laid that bill aside. The coalition will obviously support the amendment moved by Senator Bell, as it is the same as our original amendment.

The onus is squarely on the government to support these crucial amendments to the Student Assistance (Budget Matters) Amendment Bill in the committee stage. The government has gone some way to giving these young children an education, particularly the ones in drought affected areas. But there are many children who will still not be able to access Austudy. This is of the greatest concern to all primary industry people at the moment, as they go through very difficult times and struggle with the drought and struggle to feed their sheep.

I think what goes through their minds now is, `If I can get my children a decent education, a tertiary education, maybe they will not have to do this in the difficult times. At least if I do this for them and give them that tertiary education, if they do not want to come back on the farm and go through the agony that we are going through now, they will have an option.' The main concern for primary industry people at the moment is to get their children educated with a tertiary degree that will be acceptable in the wider community and that will give them the option of going back on the farm or having the opportunity to go out and get a job in other areas of Australia.

I say to the government, in hope rather than expectation, that it should support these amendments. We will put the amendments and they will go to the other house. By bringing on this drought relief package, the government has created the situation, unwillingly and unknowingly, where some 16- to 18-year-old children who are in the worst affected drought areas are allowed access to education. They can go to university, TAFE or somewhere else, but the children who are not in what is decreed by a declaration to be a drought declared area will not be able to access Austudy.

So there will be two types of young people in rural Australia. Those in the drought declared areas will be able to go to university or TAFE, and many of the ones who are not in those areas will not be able to go. I ask the government to consider the implications of the drought relief package. The package is welcomed—I am not knocking it—but I say that other people will not be able to access Austudy unless these amendments are passed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the two senators who have contributed in this debate, Senator Margetts and Senator Boswell. I will take up a couple of matters from their contributions. Firstly, the principal aim of the student assistance programs is to provide an equal opportunity—I stress the word `equal'—for all Australians to access education.
—You are not doing it.

—I will get to Senator Boswell's concerns in a moment. This is achieved through the provision of financial assistance to students who would not otherwise be able to continue their education. The student assistance budget has doubled since 1987. Expenditure has grown from $750 million in 1987-88 to an estimated $1.663 billion in 1994-95. In 1994-95 it is expected that 553,860 students will be assisted, compared to 536,390 in 1993-94. They are very basic and fundamental facts that are important to remember in the context of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: In her contribution, Senator Margetts raised the issue of rent assistance. As has been mentioned before, the government announced in the budget that rent assistance would be extended to homeless Austudy and Abstudy recipients. Extension of rent assistance to all students receiving away from home and independent rates would be very costly and needs to be considered in the context of other government priorities.

I would like to make a couple of comments about Senator Boswell's contribution. I recognise Senator Boswell's heartfelt and very active concern for the rural community. But this government, not just in response to Senator Boswell's contributions in this place, which are always, I think, recognised as being legitimate concerns—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a fine parliamentarian.

—Yes, I have to say that Senator Boswell has a very good relationship with the government. But the opposition is not always right. I think what has to be emphasised is that, even though Senator Boswell has recognised the drought relief measures that were announced a fortnight ago as being well targeted towards those areas in this country critically affected by drought, that does not necessarily mean from a government perspective that we can automatically carry those measures over to everyone outside the drought affected areas.

PARA.TAB: Some of the elements of that package affect Austudy. With the introduction of the drought relief payments, the government has addressed the needs of drought affected farm families with nil or low incomes but highly valued on-farm assets which may have prevented them from getting Austudy. Farming interest groups have, for some time, been seeking such a concession for farm assets, and these measures address this request.

The government will consider the amendments proposed by Senators Woodley, Gibson and Bell. The issue of what amendments are appropriate to be made to the bill is a matter that will be discussed further when the matter is dealt with in committee. I understand we are to put Senator Margetts's motion to a vote now, but I would indicate that I will then be moving that the consideration of the bill be made an order for the next day of sitting to allow the discussions that are occurring on the other amendments to continue.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the bill in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.
Consideration resumed from 24 August.
The bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 6, page 3, proposed subsection 24(1), line 14, omit "an officer", substitute "a senior officer".
(2)Clause 6, page 3, proposed subsection 24(3), after definition of "relevant warrant", insert the following definitions:
"`Senior Executive Service office' has the same meaning as in the Public Service Act 1992;
`senior officer of the Organization' means an officer of the Organization who holds or performs the duties of an office that is :

TAB.TAB: (a)equivalent to a Senior Executive Service office; or
(b)designated as an office of Manager (Senior Officer Grade A) by the Director-General under section 85.".

SPEECH.PARA: I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to this bill.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to outline the coalition's position in relation to this bill. It is to be noted that this bill relates to a number of pieces of legislation. The coalition notes these amendments and supports them, of course, in that they were brought to the attention of the Senate by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I believe the aspect of delegation in relation to the warrant is an important aspect in that the delegation is changed from an officer to a senior officer. I think that in any aspect of delegation the government must be terribly careful that, where it is dealing with the delegation of power to authorise such warrants, it be to a person of sufficient seniority and not just anyone; we do not just delegate to the office boy the ability to authorise a warrant. Therefore, the coalition supports the amendments. I note that for the record.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with the bill in general terms. This bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and, in particular, the two aspects dealing with the amendment of sentencing principles and with penalty in the Crimes Act were canvassed. I might say that they are perhaps the most salient points to deal with.

I would indicate that the coalition agrees with the inclusion of cultural background in relation to sentencing principles. I believe that is an aspect which is relevant in a country such as Australia, where there are diverse cultural backgrounds. In my state of Western Australia there have cases where tribal Aboriginals have been dealt with before the courts and, of course, they have operated under a different cultural background. They have also had to face some sort of penalty from their own tribe and clan. Also, some aspects of a culture bring out different sorts of behaviour in people, and that has to be recognised. In particular, this relates to Aboriginal offenders, but it could apply to anyone in the community.

This is not a defence, and I state that quite clearly. It is by way of a sentencing principle. I recently spoke to a judge who said that perhaps we are enumerating too many principles for sentencing and that we should just leave it to commonsense. I agree with that but in relation to the legislation on the books, we already have a number of matters such as the nature and circumstances of the offence, the degree to which the offender has shown contrition and the degree to which the offender has cooperated with the law enforcement agencies. If this were not included, it would appear that parliament was saying that was not such an important aspect to be considered. Therefore, I think it is very important that it be included.

I believe the amendment to the penalty provisions of the Crimes Act is sensible. I believe from my own experience that, if someone does breach a recognisance or a security, there should be a range of options available to the court in sentencing that person. It is much as if someone is on probation. The state that I come from, Western Australia, does not have a suspended sentence provision. Other states might have, although not all of them. If people breach such a recognisance or if they cannot pay reparation or restitution, the court should be left with the matter to deal with afresh and should have that ability to provide a range of options of sentencing from imprisonment, to a further suspended sentence, to a fine, to perhaps probation, although the Commonwealth does not have probation as the states know it.

In relation to other aspects of the bill, there are amendments to the Transfer of Prisoners Act dealing with the ACT so that prisoners can be included in the transfer of prisoners scheme operating in Australia. I think that is a sensible amendment. The amendment to the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 is sensible in allowing the Australian Federal Police officers on Christmas Island to receive such reports.

I do not intend to go any further into the detail of those other amendments; suffice to say that the main issues, I believe, are the sentencing principles that I have outlined and the penalty provisions, which I think are a step in the right direction. A court should always be given as much choice as possible in relation to sentencing. I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the amendment moved by the government. We believe it is an essential amendment. It was brought to the attention of the Senate by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, as Senator Ellison has said. If the government had not moved this amendment, we would have. We believe it is very important for the government to ensure that, when authority and power is delegated, it is done so in a carefully circumscribed manner. The class of persons to whom the delegation is given must be clearly defined. Obviously, the highest possible level of competence must be chosen for such delegation.

PARA.TAB: On the matter of cultural background, which was one of the matters referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the Democrats welcome that amendment. The evidence before the committee was overwhelmingly in support of including cultural background. I believe that is a relevant matter in the sentencing of federal offenders. I think we need to make that distinction and take it into account when guilt or innocence is determined by the court. That has certainly not been the case. The bill seeks to introduce it simply as a matter to be taken into account when the sentence is under consideration by the court.

It is appropriate to take that into account in a multicultural society. It is a developing area of Australian law. How do we cope with different cultural backgrounds where people are used to different laws? While it is very clear that Australian law must be paramount and that obedience to Australian legislation must be the absolute standard that we as a multicultural society pursue, there is some room to consider its impact in areas such as sentencing.
I commented on the other provisions during the second reading stage and I will not take that any further. The Australian Democrats will be supporting this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ellison and Senator Spindler for their support on behalf of their respective parties. I note the role of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. Having been a member of that committee, I might say that it is a very important and worthwhile committee, unlike some others we have in this place. But that is for another time and debate. I thank honourable senators for their contributions.

PARA.TAB: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Sherry) read a third time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 6, page 4, proposed subsection 19(3), lines 5 to 10, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsections:
"`(3) Proceedings for an offence against this section must not be brought except with the consent in writing of:
(a)the Ombudsman or an authorised person; or
(b)if the Ombudsman or an authorised person refuses to consent—the Attorney-General.
`(4) In this section:
"authorised person" means a person who has been authorised in writing by the Ombudsman to give consents under subsection (3).'.".
I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendment which I have moved to this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Senate for very long. Heaven knows, this government needs a bit of help in rearranging its program. This program is so far down the gurgler. Those of us with a good spirit and a kind heart want to do everything we can to assist the government in that process. There were times when we were going home early because the government did not have any bills. I have had bills ready for weeks. Day after day I come here ready to do bills and they are shifted off because those opposite cannot organise their program. I will make a contribution to assisting, but I cannot let this matter pass without making a few remarks.

PARA.TAB: The amendment circulated is the one saying that we cannot go ahead with a prosecution for a false complaint if the ombudsman does not want us to go ahead; it has to be referred to the Attorney-General. That amendment has been taken up as a consequence of a very sensible reference of this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Yet again, it may be only in a small way, but somebody's rights are being protected because senators in their committee work did their job. I suppose we have to have a bit of good grace and say that the government had the good sense to listen.

I had some second thoughts, momentarily, having agreed with this amendment myself, that I would like to put on the record, because other people may have the same second thoughts and it may mean later that we will have to look at it. My second thoughts were these: when we establish a DPP, we want an independent person looking at whether prosecutions should proceed or not. We say that a DPP should have the job rather than the Attorney-General because we want to de-politicise the prosecution process.

What we are actually saying here is that in the end it will be the Attorney-General—in some cases—who decides. We are saying that the Attorney-General should have the matter referred to him or her, as the case may be, but in these circumstances it is the AFP who would want to pursue a prosecution against a citizen and it would be the AFP's credibility at risk.

Those opposite might say that the Attorney-General or the Minister for Justice is responsible. As they come under the same portfolio, in the end the Attorney-General is responsible. The point is that the Attorney-General is going to be more independently minded, we assume, than the AFP itself. That is the only basis on which we recommend this—if those opposite understand the point I am making.

Normally we would say, `Let's keep the Attorney out of prosecutorial things.' But we say that it is different in this instance because the prosecution, on behalf of the AFP, is by an arm of the government against a citizen. That is different, I think, from the normal circumstances. In any event, the Attorney is going to be more objective—we hope—than the AFP necessarily could be, since it is against the AFP that the false complaint is allegedly made. That was the first point I wanted to make, having rushed into the chamber because the government's agenda is all over the joint.

There are some other points I want to make. Some time ago the Australian Federal Police asked for a review. That request was made in April 1989. I was in this parliament then but it was five years ago, heading on for six. It was not until 1991 that the government established a working party to look at the Federal Police concerns, as part of a review of the act as a whole. Mr Temporary Chairman, if you are concerned about the relevance of my remarks, I am speaking to the title. The working group considered proposals from interested parties and considered the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration review of the ombudsman's office. Honourable senators will remember that a request was made in 1989 by the AFPA for these matters to be looked at. That did not happen until 1991. Now, about five years later, we have some legislation going through parliament.
We think the amendments do some good things. Unlike the Democrats, and in contrast to the view put to us by the Law Council, we support there being an offence of making a false complaint.

TALK.START.PARA: —We agree with that.

—Oh, good. We support that and think it is a good thing. It is easy to make a complaint against the police. It is easy to put them to great bother and effort as a consequence of a false complaint and then walk away laughing. That situation will now change.

PARA.TAB: So a request was made back in 1989, there was some delay before a review was conducted and then there was some further delay before the legislation was introduced. A Senate committee and the Attorney-General's Department have come in—Senator Spindler can correct me, but I am pretty sure about this—and said, `The minister has had a look at this and we think the whole thing needs to be reviewed.' It really does raise the question of when is this ever going to end?

To the minister and me it might not make much difference on a day-to-day basis, but I am quite sure it makes a difference to the officers of the Australian Federal Police. Since 1989 they have been asking for things to be fixed up. Having thought they might have got there, there is now going to be another review. It is just a constant process. I am not arguing that the government should stop reviewing things because it did not do it properly the first time—it does not want to be embarrassed by constant review. What I am arguing is that when it does the review, for heaven's sake do it properly in the first place. Clearly, that has not happened in this case. It simply shows that the responsible minister, Duncan Kerr, has not got a grip on this matter at all. He has let it drift; he is not sure where to go.

With a bill coming forward that the AFPA has been looking forward to for some time, we find we have to say, `We will deal with those problems in the next review.' This is no way for someone to administer a portfolio; it is no way to deal with the Australian Federal Police; and, frankly, it is no way to deal with the parliament in terms of wasting its time. We will have to read another review and we will have to go through the process of looking at another bill which, if it was all done properly in the first place, might have been able to be done in one bite.

Apart from that, with the reservations I have added, we support the amendment. We think it is a good thing. We will have to watch and see how the new offence is dealt with and how many people get caught by it; and whether people feel confident to still make complaints, with this new offence hanging over their heads. I feel confident that members of the community will make complaints that are genuine and that all the provision of this offence will do is get rid of the non-genuine complaints—and that will be a good thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of amendments, which are being circulated in my name, have been brought to the attention of the coalition parties and the government—indeed, of all honourable senators. The somewhat rushed, stop-start nature of the program this afternoon made it impossible to put the amendments before everybody in the chamber on time this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: In speaking to amendment No. 1, circulated in my name, I would like to say that the Australian Democrats welcome very much a number of the amendments contained in the bill. We welcome the way in which the role of the ombudsman is strengthened by the bill, in particular the power given to the ombudsman to investigate matters of her own motion. This places her in a position closer to that originally contemplated by the two relevant law reform commission reports.

This attention to the process of complaints against the AFP, and the role of the ombudsman, arose out of the AIDEX demonstration. In large measure, it was due to the 114 complaints by people who claimed that they were roughly handled and assaulted by police. These complaints came to the attention of the ombudsman's office. The Democrats are very pleased that that has now resulted in some very worthwhile amendments to the complaints process. We do note that the review in this area continues. We look forward to further amendments as a result of that. It may now be appropriate for me to move amendment No. 1, circulated in my name.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—It would not be appropriate at this time. We do have a government amendment before the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendment No. 1 seeks to insert a new clause after clause 2 of the bill.
—But we are taking the bill as a whole.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, by way of genuine cooperation I would like to indicate to the Democrats that we are not supporting any of their amendments, so they can have leave to move them all at the same time and speak on all of them. I am not suggesting that we should finish things simply because of the time, but if they adopted this course there would be the possibility of finishing this bill tonight.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, given that this matter has already been discussed in committee, I think that what Senator Vanstone has advised is satisfactory—as long as Senator Spindler does not think his amendments are not getting reasonable consideration. I support her proposal, if it is acceptable to Senator Spindler.
—I would be happy to accept that procedure, but obviously I would wish to speak to all the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.After clause 2, page 2, insert the following new clause:

TAB.TAB: "2A.After section 5A of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Immunity from use of information given by a complainant

SPEECH.PARA: `5AA. Where a person makes a complaint referred to in section 5, the following are not admissible in evidence against that person in any criminal proceedings:
(a)the information, including any document, given by the person for the purpose of making the complaint;

TAB.TAB: (b)the fact of the production of the document (if any) by the person;
(c)any information, document or thing obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of the giving of the information or the document.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 6, page 4, after proposed subsection 19(3), insert the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "`(3A) Proceedings for an offence against this section must not be brought unless the persons referred to in subsection (3) are satisfied that evidence of the offence can be corroborated by a person other than an AFP appointee to whom:

TAB.TAB: (a)the false information was provided; or
(b)the complaint relates.".

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 16, line 8 (page 7) to line 11 (page 9), omit the clause.
Clause 17, page 9, paragraph (a), proposed subsection 67(1), line 15, omit "Subject to section 52A, proceedings", substitute "Proceedings".

In respect of amendment No. 1, the Australian Democrats agree with the submission made by the Law Council of Australia that there should be a general privilege for information provided by complainants in complaints to the ombudsman. Such a privilege would preclude any statements made by a complainant in a complaint to the ombudsman being used in subsequent criminal proceedings. This is something we need to guard against.

PARA.TAB: The rationale of such a privilege is that there should be a clear separation between the criminal misconduct of a complainant and his or her complaint against police officers. Police officers should not be able to abuse their power in the knowledge that the victim was effectively silenced through fear that making a complaint might implicate him or her in criminal activity. The privilege would be strictly limited to information furnished to the ombudsman in relation to a complaint alleging police misconduct. Accordingly, I believe this is an important amendment, and I commend it to the committee. Amendment No. 2 circulated in my name—
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Senator Spindler, amendment No. 2 proposed by the Australian Democrats has now been superseded by the carriage of the earlier government amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not quite, Mr Temporary Chairman. Amendment No. 2 contains two matters. In part, it contains the matter that has been addressed by the government's amendment, and we welcome that. But a second issue has been combined in this amendment, which is that, apart from the ombudsman's consent, we also require corroboration from someone other than a member of the AFP before a charge can proceed.

PARA.TAB: In relation to clause 16, which is the subject of amendment No. 3, the Australian Democrats believe that the power which such a clause would give to the commissioner of the AFP is undesirable, and that is the power to deal with the disciplinary process in-house, as it were, once a member of the AFP has pleaded guilty to a disciplinary charge.

We believe the principle that such matters should always be dealt with in public by the Police Complaints Tribunal should not be given up. I think a number of submissions were made on that point, including a submission by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. It is also contained in recommendation No. 226 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. Accordingly, I believe this is an important amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I looked back at the statements I made with regard to last year's annual report of the Energy Research and Development Corporation—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a very dangerous thing to do.

—It is. I noticed that at that stage not much indication was given about what the split was between the various new research projects. I am pleased to say that page 41 of this year's report shows the split within the research projects. The previous year's report showed a total of $11.6 million for new research projects. It was unclear from that report how much money was spent on renewable energy research. Now we know how much was spent because this year's report states that in 1993 research into renewables totalled roughly $3.17 million. That was 27.4 per cent of the research dollars. That was a bit disappointing since we could perhaps expect around 50 per cent of the research money to go into renewables.

PARA.TAB: However, we have found out from this year's report that that research funding has in fact gone down. It has gone down 26 per cent to $2.336 million. It has also gone down in percentage terms. It is down to 23 per cent of funding for research projects. So the commitment by the government in terms of research into renewables seems to be decreasing rather than increasing.

I do note, however, that there is a slight increase of roughly four per cent in funding going to research projects in planned energy use, or demand management. That has gone up from roughly 15.26 per cent of the total to 18.14 per cent. Whilst that is good, there is also a growing amount of information on energy management, how it can be achieved and how it saves money. I am sure the majority of these kinds of projects will say exactly that. The problem I see is that demand management, at both the state and federal levels, still has to be implemented through actual program changes.

I had a suggestion the other day—and I think it is a very good one—that the energy impact of every major new project, and especially every major capital works expenditure, should be part of the project and that the government should be required in every new proposal and every new major policy change to look at what the energy impact will be.

In this way some of these well researched demand management proposals of energy efficiency and energy conservation can be built into the way we plan our policies. Obviously we are getting a lot more information—which is good. However, we are stopping short of implementing that information. Instead of having a small demand management branch, what we have to do now—and what I am hoping the government will do as part of its response to the greenhouse strategy—is look at how demand management can be built into every major program and certainly every capital works program.

I notice, however, that the research dollar in total has decreased from $11.5 million to just over $10 million. We are putting less into energy research than we were previously. It would appear that government revenue is increasing, but one wonders where it is going. Perhaps it is going into areas other than research. That seems to be the situation with a lot of research programs at the moment; perhaps the development side may be taking over from some of the research side. We need to look into that.

The Energy Research and Development Corporation is obviously an important body. It is vital that it sees that its role as involving energy trends and research that private industry is not involved in. If it involves fossil fuels there may not be a dollar in it. Certainly the best thing for Australia is to look seriously at energy reduction and the use of renewables. One can only hope that we will all seek to ensure that in this area Australia goes in the right direction.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the Commission's charter is, amongst other things, to promote fair and open dealing between the insurance and superannuation industry and its customers. I note further in the report that the insurance commissioner attempts to maintain a close liaison with the general insurance industry, consumer bodies and other interested parties on issues affecting the industry and insurance policy holders.

PARA.TAB: Elsewhere in the report, the insurance commissioner talks about a code of practice in relation to general insurance. The commissioner reports that in July 1993 the government announced its intention to establish a task force to develop a structure for a compulsory code of practice governing the relationship between insurers, intermediaries and consumers in the general insurance industry. Elsewhere the report talks about social justice, access and equity, and indicates that the commissioner's responsibilities for the administration of the Insurance Contracts Act will improve consumer protection, and the formulation of a general insurance industry code of practice will enhance social justice and equity for insurance consumers.

I was interested to read those matters in the report because I have raised with the insurance commissioner a matter of access to general insurance. I wrote to him on 4 October, the same day as I wrote to the Attorney-General and Senator Schacht about customs matters in the Torres Strait. I have not received a reply from the insurance commissioner. I am not criticising him because obviously it takes a while to look at it.

I wanted to raise publicly the difficulty that business people and home owners on Thursday Island find in getting any sort of insurance at all. I have raised this question with Suncorp Insurance, one of the biggest insurers in Queensland, and asked whether it was true. I am told by constituents on Thursday Island that they are simply unable to obtain general insurance. They tell me that it is practically impossible to obtain fire insurance. Insurance companies which provided that insurance in the past will not take contracts now.

When I asked my constituents whether they were able to get theft insurance, they just laughed at me and said that it was not worth asking about. As I have mentioned in this chamber previously, there is a lot of petty theft and some quite major theft occurring on Thursday Island. A lot of the things stolen from the shops on Thursday Island end up in New Guinea. That leads the local people to the conclusion that many of the stolen goods are being exchanged for drugs in New Guinea, and those drugs are then coming into Australia via the Torres Strait and Cairns. That is another aspect of the matter which I have taken up with the Attorney-General, and with Senator Schacht—if he ever gets around to finding it—and his department.

It is unfair that any Australians should find themselves in the position where they simply cannot get any insurance. There is a fire station on Thursday Island. The insurance companies should be aware that the people have some protection. Fires and, at times, violent tropical storms occur on Thursday Island. But these people are simply unable to insure against these things.

That is terribly unfair. We must have a society where Australians, no matter where they choose to live or where they are forced to live, should have access to the same services and insurance cover as other Australians. The government should look into this matter. As I say, I have raised the matter with the commissioner and I eagerly await his response. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
