SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp, who has an appointment in Melbourne, has asked me to make the following comments on his behalf in relation to this report:

PARA.TAB: Some months ago the Department of Veterans' Affairs provided a briefing to me about the activities of the department, as one of my responsibilities is to handle Veterans' Affairs bills in the Senate. Air Vice Marshal Alan Heggin, Director of War Graves, provided details on the activities of the Office of Australian War Graves. I have since had the opportunity to use the services of the office and I commend its excellent work to all Australians.

Service records of World War I soldiers can now be obtained on application to Australian Archives. Indeed, I was pleased to read that some 700 files per month are now requested by the public seeking information on behalf of relations who served in the First World War. Where the individual was killed in action, the Office of Australian War Graves can provide the location of the grave. As it states in the annual report, for those unable to travel to the grave site, the office will arrange the provision of photographs.

As a result of the work of the Australian Archives and, in particular, Kon Tsogas and his staff, I was able to obtain the service record of a relation, George Kemp—a young man in his early 20s who enlisted in 1915 and was killed in the second Battle of Bullecourt on 5 May 1917. The files were comprehensive and included key documents from his enlistment to the final tragedy of his death.

The Office of Australian War Graves was able to provide me with the location of his grave at Queant, near Villers-Bretonneux in the north of France. The director, Alan Heggin, forwarded to me photos of the grave and last month members of my family were able to visit the cemetery.

Some 416,000 Australians enlisted in the First World War, and there are some 21,000 First and Second World War graves in France. As these soldiers died at such an early age, many did not have the opportunity to have families of their own. Whereas the Australian War Memorial and the Office of Australian War Graves do so much to maintain a sense of their sacrifice, it is true that the memory of these brave soldiers has inevitably faded over the years.

SPEECH.PARA: Some 75 years later, many of those who carry the same name as the World War One servicemen know little about the service record of their earlier relations.
Before I was able to obtain George Kemp's records, an uncle of mine, Len Kemp was the only person who could recall him. Len, as a young boy, visited George prior to his embarkation for Gallipoli.
Information about young men like George can now be readily obtained thanks to the good work of Australian Archives.

As the Australia Remembers Program is underway, I hope that greater use will be made of the office of War Graves and Australian Archives so that more Australians will learn about the sacrifice of their forebears and take the opportunity to visit their final resting place.
This concludes Senator Kemp's remarks. I join with Senator Kemp in commending the work of these two organisations: the Office of Australian War Graves and the Australian Archives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to place on record my appreciation of the tremendous help that the Office of Australian War Graves gave me several months ago in providing details of World War 1 graves in Europe and the Gallipoli peninsula in preparation for my visit to some of those areas in July and August. The assistance I got from the office was extremely good. The office was very cooperative, very efficient and very helpful indeed. The Office of Australian War Graves is part of the wider Commonwealth War Graves Commission in many respects, although it is independent. I also want to place on record my deep appreciation of the work of the wider Commonwealth War Graves Commission.

PARA.TAB: Many honourable senators, I guess, have visited the cemeteries in Gallipoli and some of the other fields of battle in the First World War—ranging from Lebanon through to France and other areas. It is an extremely moving experience to visit those sites. I had the great honour and privilege of laying wreaths at Lone Pine, Anzac Cove and the Turkish memorial on the Gallipoli peninsula late in July. It was amongst the more moving experiences in my life. It is a great tragedy that, just a few weeks after that, massive bushfires swept right through the Gallipoli peninsula and destroyed much of the foliage around the memorials. Fortunately, as I understand it, the memorials themselves have not been destroyed, but it is quite a scene of desolation at the moment.

To visit the Australian national memorial at Villers-Bretonneux is one of the more moving experiences that one can have. I was privileged to do that as well. My visit was made such a memorable one due, very importantly, to the assistance that I received from the Office of Australian War Graves and also from the Australian embassies in France and in Turkey.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Short, I would like to thank members of the Office of Australian War Graves who greatly facilitated my visit to Gallipoli. Their office at Canakkale in Turkey certainly provides enormous assistance to parliamentarians visiting that heritage area. It is an area of heritage not only of significance to Australia but also of significance to the Turks. It was where Kemal Ataturk first became the national hero, which role enabled him to bring Turkey very much into the 20th century and to create the basis on which it could become the dynamic nation it is today.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to mention, as Senator Short did, that damage of various kinds creates problems for the Office of Australian War Graves. The devastating fires at Gallipoli have been mentioned—in fact, I spoke at some length about them in this chamber. I also note from the annual report that local bandit or rascal activity in the Port Moresby area has necessitated the strengthening of security arrangements at the Bomana War Cemetery.

The report notes that revised approach and entry arrangements have been introduced and security staff are on duty throughout each day. Visitor harassment has diminished markedly since the changes have been introduced. Although several instances of minor vandalism have occurred at facilities of the Office of Australian War Graves in Australia, these have been addressed promptly and rectified and so are not major problems. It is a concern that those problems in Papua New Guinea have emerged and I regret that the office has had to undertake that kind of expensive protection.

I am glad to see that there is still a determination to continue the program of upgrading many of the present assets—I suppose one can call them that; they are called assets in the annual report—of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission, some of which are now over 45 years old. In particular—and this might interest Senator Margetts—the commission has installed solar power irrigation systems in six war plots. This has been both commercially beneficial and a step in the right direction in terms of energy conservation, I imagine Senator Margetts would think.

TALK.START.PARA: —So do I.

—And so does Senator Macdonald. The report mentions that there has been a replacement of agricultural drainage systems in Springvale war cemetery and in the South Australian garden of remembrance. What is important to recognise is that all of this activity—such as the sinking of a bore at the Bomana War Cemetery to provide an artesian-sourced irrigation system which should minimise reliance on Port Moresby water supply and achieve substantial savings in operational costs, along with the realignment of headstones and the restoration of stonework—means that there is still a continuing requirement for funding of this office. I am glad to see that this government is continuing with that funding. Perhaps many people forget that appropriate remembrance of the contribution of Australians who died serving their country is a matter of expenditure. It is expenditure that all Australians should be proud to see is being so effectively undertaken by the Office of Australian War Graves. I commend the annual report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to again protest against the government's mean-spirited and ill-advised approach to the funding of the CSIRO. As outlined in this report, CSIRO's priorities are now set in favour of mineral resources, manufacturing information and communications, and environment—leaving agriculture in limbo. CSIRO's primary industry research was hit hard when $60 million was sliced from its budget. These cuts are impinging on the future competitiveness of our agricultural export sector. This is a sector that still provides 25 per cent of our export dollars, and that is a figure that is often forgotten. It is a sector with a great deal of potential and a sector that has been neglected by this government for too long.

PARA.TAB: The export dollars that primary industry brings into this nation, and on which much of the infrastructure of the nation has been built, are still essential to reducing our current account deficit. In August we notched up a $2.1 billion current account deficit, the highest in five years, a level much greater than financial markets had tipped. I am told that the current importation of grain and the substantial reduction in primary industry exports will add $3 billion or $4 billion to the balance of payments problem for at least the remainder of the year. We have to face the fact that, if this nation were a business, the receivers would have moved in and changed the locks.

Overall, as announced in the Working Nation paper, the CSIRO funding cuts amount to $20 million per year being taken away from primary industry. This has not been helped by the worst drought since white settlement and the general rural recession, which have reduced primary industry contributions to agricultural research. It is interesting to note that a recent cost benefit analysis conducted by the CSIRO Division of Wool Technology showed that its recent activities provided a return of $123 for every research dollar spent.

The cuts that I have talked about will mean that 138 jobs will be shed in the Institute of Plant and Animal Production. We must remember that these job cuts follow significant asset sales. While there is arguably some merit in the rationalisation of research sites, it is reckless to support massive cuts to research staff because of the difficulty of retraining when things turn around. This is a very big wastage from which we will be hard pressed to recover.

Morale is at an extremely low level. The inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs into these cuts took evidence in Sydney, Armidale, Brisbane and Perth, with further hearings to be held in Melbourne and Canberra and an inspection undertaken at Geelong. The inquiry has taken 166 submissions, a large number of which came from disgruntled CSIRO scientists, rural land protection boards and farming organisations. All these people, from scientist to farmer, despair for the future of their work.

I look forward to the inquiry's findings, due to be released by the last sitting day this year. I hope that the government, which vehemently resisted the inquiry, takes note of the findings. If funding matched primary industry's export status, the eight primary industry research divisions would have their budgets supplemented, not reduced. But no, agriculture bears the brunt of this government's cost cutting once again. The government's talk of enhancing regional Australia has been shown up as hollow rhetoric when decisions such as these are taken. If CSIRO facilities are closed in regional centres, as is presently happening, these centres will suffer enormously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to speak briefly to the annual report of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. I felt it important to attend one of the hearings of the current inquiry into research funding, especially in relation to rural research, that took place in Perth. A number of very interesting points came out during that hearing. Certainly, there is a change in the direction of a number of aspects of funding and there seem to be a number of reasons for that.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, it would seem that the push to privatise funding, or for CSIRO to gain a greater proportion of its funding from private sources, is having a negative effect on the total amount of research. Certainly, it would reduce the amount of research being done in rural areas because of the lack of dollars in the rural sector to provide for CSIRO projects. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Lieutenant Colonel Fred Evans MBE, ED, JP: Death

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I attended the funeral of one of the most decent, honourable, dedicated, hardworking, effective and community spirited people I have known. He was Lieutenant Colonel Fred Evans, MBE ED JP, who died, aged 81, on Saturday at the Culburra Retirement Village that he had done so much to establish.

PARA.TAB: He was a man who in retirement achieved more than most people achieve in a lifetime of work. His sense of service, which carried him into a distinguished career in the army, also prompted him into making an unparalleled contribution to the quality of life in the Culburra region on the south coast of New South Wales after his retirement.

Memorials to Fred Evans abound in Culburra, not only by way of the bricks and mortar, the buildings and institutions, the very existence of which depended on his initiatives, but also in the hearts of all the residents who accepted his leadership, who responded to his enthusiasm, who acted on his encouragement to get things done and who have benefited accordingly.

In the last few years Fred Evans had been forced to relinquish many of his formal roles in the community because of ill health. Nevertheless, and despite the directions of his doctors, he continued to play a key advisory role in a wide range of activities.

When I was Fred Evans's local federal member of parliament, as member for Macarthur from 1975 to 1983, I quickly became aware of his vision for his area and his determination to achieve it. His strength of purpose was matched by his remarkable courtesy. It was almost a pleasure to be pressured by him to take up his causes. It was a rewarding experience to be gently and politely chastised for not enough progress being made. That such a gentle man should be so strong and so capable of such achievement without the need to rely on tough words, bullying, unpleasant language or unkind behaviour speaks volumes for his decency, his skill and his dedication.

He was still giving me the benefit of his advice right up to his death. Only today I received a letter from him—the last he wrote to anyone—telling me that I must keep up the fight for proper and responsible behaviour by parliamentarians in their commercial ventures. He reminded me that I had to attend the Culburra senior citizens' Christmas dinner in December this year because I had missed it last year when I was our delegate to the United Nations General Assembly in New York.

I would like to briefly place on record some of the contributions of Fred Evans to his nation and his community. Born in 1913 in North Sydney and educated at my old school, North Sydney Boys High School, Fred enlisted in the Citizens Military Force in February 1931 at the age of 18. He was commissioned a lieutenant in 1938. When World War II came he served in Malaya, unfortunately, and was a prisoner of war there for three years and eight months, during which time he saw probably the worst aspects of human behaviour. Yet that did not change and may even have enhanced the generous nature and the decency of spirit that Fred Evans demonstrated all his life.

After the war, he graduated to the Australian Staff College. He was a member of staff of Queen Elizabeth II during her first official visit to Australia in 1954 as an army liaison officer and assistant New South Wales state marshal. He then went to Korea as an Australian representative on the United Nations Military Armistice Commission.

He retired from the permanent army, of which he had become a member straight after the war, in 1960. Prior to his retirement he had been heavily involved in many activities, such as the Boy Scouts parents' committee, organising and fund-raising, and junior football committees, in which he was heavily involved and, of course, a patron. He was appointed a justice of the peace in 1953. He assisted in the formation of local ex-servicemen's registered clubs and arranged and maintained assistance for the disadvantaged children's home at Campbelltown in New South Wales. Unfortunately, he suffered two coronary occlusions in 1972 and two more in 1976. Ill health forced his retirement from work in March 1973 and he was then classified as a totally and permanently disabled ex-serviceman. As a TPI pensioner he probably worked harder than most able-bodied people, but for good causes.

After his retirement to Culburra he intended to spend time gardening and fishing. He found that there was so much community involvement available to him that he did not get much fishing or gardening done. He became the foundation committee member of the Culburra Community Development Organisation, which was a body formed to deal with local government and development matters. He wrote its constitution and has always been its adviser, assistant secretary and principal spokesman and has prepared all of its major submissions for an enormous volume of activities, most of which seem to have come to fruition. He was awarded an MBE in the Queen's New Year Honours in 1979 for services to the aged and the community. He was awarded the RSL Anzac of the Year Award in 1991.

Two major events that took place in 1975 which turned his life into complete dedication to community work, in which he was still involved in a leading and advisory role at the time of his death, were the formation of the Culburra and Districts Community Health Service and the Culburra and Districts Senior Citizens Association. This senior citizens association was started by his wife, Avis, caring for older people, particularly those living in isolation, and having them socially at her home. Realising the urgent need for such an organisation, Avis and Fred arranged for the Culburra Community Development Organisation to call a public meeting for those interested and this association was inaugurated in July 1975 with 15 members. It quickly grew to in excess of 100 and now has a membership of 832. It has the largest such membership of any organisation of that kind on the south coast of New South Wales.

Fred Evans became its foundation president, wrote its constitution, had it registered as a charitable organisation, arranged its exemption from sales tax and arranged for tax exemption for donors of $2 or more. This went on despite the fact that in 1982 he had open heart surgery for a six by-pass operation. A long convalescent period did not diminish his determination to proceed. He organised a whole series of guest speakers, monthly luncheons and so on.

He was extremely active in the procurement of and planning for the building of the Culburra Senior Citizens Centre, which is the largest of its kind on the south coast of New South Wales. I was overjoyed to be involved with him in that project. He convinced the local council and the architect of what was required to meet the needs of all senior citizens in the area. It was at his insistence that the Prime Minister officially opened the building, on the basis that no person of such high office had ever been to Culburra before. He arranged for local school children to line both sides of the main road to see their Prime Minister, no matter what the politics were.

He guided the association with his capable, energetic leadership and broadened the interests of the association in a wide field by his involvement in Sydney in the New South Wales Council on the Ageing and the Senior Citizens Week Advisory Committee in the Premier's Department ever since its inception. He was Deputy Chairman of the Shoalhaven City Council's Senior Citizens Advisory Committee and played leading roles throughout the region in senior citizen activities. He was heavily involved in state-wide senior citizen activity as well. He was the coordinator for the annual contest by the New South Wales Council on the Ageing in its Senior Citizen of the Year activity.

Probably the major thing which he was also involved in was the growth of the retirement village at Culburra, of which he was a resident when he died. This has now a 40-bed nursing home, 30-unit hostel and 30 self-care units, all emerging as a result of long, hard, continuous negotiation—writing, conferences and so on—for which Fred Evans was the driving force. He is a man who was highly regarded by everyone in Culburra. I extend my condolences to his widow, my dear friend Avis, who spent almost 60 years as half of a wonderful partnership, and also to his children, Wendy, Pam, Robert and Doug, his grandchildren and great grandchildren.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I was speaking during the debate on an MPI on the Civil Aviation Authority and the way in which the government had administered it. Since making that speech I have received a letter from a pilot holding an airline transport pilot's licence. The information therein illustrates the point I was making at the time. I will take a few moments of the Senate's time tonight to read most of the letter to the Senate. This pilot had chartered, on a private charter for seven days, a Navajo Chieftain from Seaview Aviation. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: On return to Archerfield from the 7 days trip the aircraft was delivered to its agreed point of hire. A fax was received from Seaview requesting the aircraft to be flown back to Lord Howe Island as
it was urgently needed the next day on Saturday 12th March.
That is this year. The letter continues:
I agreed to perform the delivery flight (gratis) and delivered it to Lord Howe Island on 12th March 1994.
At Lord Howe Island I pointed out the door problem again and requested how I was to be returned to Archerfield and was advised I was to be passengered back on the 4.00 pm service.

At 3.00 pm I reported in as a passenger for the flight and was told that there was a problem . . . requested me to captain the flight to the mainland. I advised that I could not do that as I already had flown for the last 8 days, I was too tired and (although I did not tell him) I was not route checked.
I was advised that there was another pilot who was not experienced who could do the flight and "would I supervise him". I said that would be a better option.

Prior to departure I started querying the pilot on the weather forecast, and his flight plan and load. He had no weather forecast, and I observed him telephone the CAA briefing office and give them some verbal information. There was no written flight plan—the whole flight was performed on GPS and the information given to the CAA in advance as guestimates. The information even referred to a reporting point 100 DME Ballina. (Ballina has no DME).
I estimate that the aircraft was 200kg overloaded at departure Lord Howe Island. The pilot taxied onto the runway at LHI together with another aircraft and lined up together on the threshold markers.
The pilot lifted the aircraft at least 20 kts prior to take-off safety speed.
The pilot proceeded to lean both engines together in the climb.
The crosswind at Ballina Airport was in my opinion beyond the aircraft's demonstrated limit and the pilot landed the aircraft with considerable flare instead of "driving it" onto the runway.
The pilot did not observe my requests in relation to the operation of the aircraft and I was powerless to enforce the position as I was not employed by Seaview Aviation.
I discovered that my name was used on the flightplan as the captain of the aircraft for that flight.
On a special return flight to Archerfield with the Chief Pilot I let him know of my displeasure about the situation and of the performance of the pilot I flew with. On the return flight—
that is, on the flight from Lord Howe Island to Ballina—
I made comments about the door light problem and was able to show him the compensating errors of a "door ajar warning light" being inoperative and a loose main door latch.
In my opinion I find it impossible to believe that Navajo Chieftain Aircraft at the weights they are operated could legally operate into Lord Howe Island given its runway length.

That is a really striking letter. One is required by law to have a weather forecast and submit a flight plan before flying a hire, charter or regular public transport flight. It is not possible to fly solely with GPS as a navigation aid on those types of flights. GPS is highly developed and highly accurate but it is not allowed by the Civil Aviation Authority as a primary aid.

PARA.TAB: To report that one is 100 miles from Ballina DME means that one can fix one's position accurately by the use of distance measuring equipment installed at Ballina airport. And there is no DME at Ballina, so that was a falsehood. The fact that the aircraft was at least 200 kilograms overloaded is very dangerous. Light twin engine aircraft have very little margin of performance. If they lose an engine on take-off, in the climb or even on the cruise, they have great difficulty in maintaining their altitude. The position is made absolutely untenable by overloading the aircraft.

People look at aircraft like DC3s and think they are old-fashioned and all the rest of it. But when a DC3 is loaded in accordance with its flight manual and the throttles are opened on take-off, that aeroplane will fly if it loses an engine. It will take off, it will climb, it will fly round the circuit and land back on with the critical engine inoperative, with the propeller unfeathered in fine pitch, with take off flap setting and the undercarriage down. It has that reserve of power—if loaded accordingly.

My colleagues in the Senate here always amuse me when they elect to charter around their respective states with a twin engine aircraft in the belief that it is safer. Light twins are safe if they have been properly maintained and they are flown by well-trained pilots. Sadly, a lot of the pilots in the charter field do not meet the standards of competence of a regular airline pilot who goes through a rigid training regime and is subjected to checking by check captains on a regular basis.

I would always rather fly, on the rare occasions I charter aircraft, in a single engine aircraft because I know if anything goes wrong there is no option for the pilot: he does not have to think; he just has to land straight ahead and we all walk away from it. But, with a twin engine aircraft, all it means is the accident is displaced another 200 yards or half a mile further on from where it would have happened with a single engine aircraft—and probably in a great deal of confusion.

The next point in this letter is that the pilot leaned both engines on take-off. On take-off power setting there is a very rich mixture. When the climb is established, the initial leaning takes place and when the aircraft is on the cruise the mixture is leaned out even more. But both engines are never leaned simultaneously—a very bad technique—because if there is a problem in the fuel flow, one loses 100 per cent of the power. One always leans one engine at a time, and when that is safely and correctly accomplished, one leans the other.

The aircraft was lifted off 20 knots prior to the take-off safety speed. The operator's manual for the aircraft lays down a certain speed under which the aircraft should not be lifted off the runway and the climb attempted, because if an engine is lost in that phase, the airspeed must be high enough to ensure that the aerodynamic controls on the aircraft, particularly the rudder, the elevators and the ailerons, are operative. Below that speed the aircraft is uncontrollable and an accident will ensue.

This pilot's name was used on the flight plan as the captain of the aircraft. That is grossly dishonest, and it says a great deal about the standards under which that company operated. I come back to the point I made last week: where people fly for hire and reward, they must meet minimal safety standards. Passengers who walk into a terminal and pay for a ticket are entitled to know that all reasonable steps have been taken to ensure the safe execution of their flight, that they are flying in an aeroplane that has been properly maintained, has been properly loaded within the flight manual limitations, and is flown by crew who are properly trained and checked in that aircraft and are operating responsibly in accordance with the operations manual of the company.

The Civil Aviation Authority has not exercised that surveillance in the past. I hope that the lessons of the immediate past have caused a major review of its policies with respect to priority. It is also true that the go-

SPEECH.PARA: vernment, although it has been told by me and many other people in this parliament that this was going on, has also been negligent in discharging its authority with respect to supervising the CAA.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the conflicting claims by the People's Republic of China, Vietnam and several other countries, over sovereignty over the Spratly Islands, and surrounding areas, in the South China Sea:
(1) What Australian firms have been awarded exploration and production contracts for mining (oil, gas or any other minerals) in the disputed areas of the South China Sea.
(2) With which Governments have these contracts been signed.
(3) Do any of these contracts involve sea-bed areas claimed by another country.

(4) Have any Australian companies sought advice from the Australian Government on the possible effect these contracts could cause to trading and diplomatic relations between Australia and the countries involved in the disputed areas: if so, what advice have they received.
(5) Have any countries claiming sovereignty over areas in the South China Sea expressed concern to the Australian Government over commercial activities by Australian companies in disputed areas.
(6) Can the Government report on any positive progress in suggestions by the Philippines to demilitarise the Spratly Islands.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No Australian firm has been awarded exploration or production contracts for mining in the disputed areas of the South China Sea. The Vietnamese Government has awarded a BHP Petroleum-led consortium an exploration block in an area 250 kilometres from the Vietnamese coast to develop the Dai Hung oil field. This block is outside the disputed area.
(2) Not applicable.
(3) Not applicable.
(4) Not applicable.
(5) Not applicable.

(6) While there were media reports in March 1994 of a Philippines proposal for talks on the withdrawal of all military forces from the Spratly Islands, I am not aware of any subsequent reference to such talks by the Philippines, or of any reaction to such a proposal by other claimants to the Spratlys. It is not clear whether bilateral or multilateral talks were intended. Australia, however, welcomes and supports preventive diplomacy initiatives designed to build confidence between the South China Sea claimant countries. We encourage further regional efforts to resolve these conflicting claims through preventive diplomacy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the details of Singapore's alleged move to resume arms sales to Burma.
(2) Please detail the nature, cost and use of the equipment planned for Burma.
(3) What is the Government's view of Singapore's alleged move to resume arms sales to Burma.
(4) What is the Government's position on Singapore's `constructive engagement' policy with Burma.
(5) Does the Australian Government's definition of `constructive engagement' include arms sales.
(6) Will the Australian Government be expressing its concern to the Singaporean Government on planned arms sales; if so, what will be the message.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The Australian Government is not in a position to confirm media reports that a number of Singaporean companies are selling arms and other military equipment to Myanmar. The Singapore Government's policy is to `neither confirm nor deny' reports on Singapore's international arms sales.

(3) The Australian Government's position on defence sales to Myanmar is well known. While there is no international embargo on defence sales to Myanmar, Australia has implemented its own ban on defence exports to Myanmar, and has urged countries known to supply arms to Myanmar to discontinue such exports.

(4) In keeping with their policy of `constructive engagement' with Myanmar, the ASEAN countries, including Singapore, would like to integrate Myanmar into the region in ways acceptable to the broader international community. In parallel with our firm stance towards Myanmar, we have been encouraging the ASEAN countries to use the opportunities provided by greater engagement with Myanmar to send some clear messages about the need for reform in that country. My discussions at the ASEAN Post Ministerial Conference (PMC) in Bangkok in July revealed general acceptance, including by the ASEAN countries, that progress would be achieved through dialogue and engagement by the international community, rather than through confrontation and isolation; that the idea of benchmarks provided a means of gauging movement in Myanmar; and that there should be a relationship between concessions to the State Law and order Restoration Council (SLORC) and progress in Myanmar.

(5) No. I assume that the honourable senator is not using the term `constructive engagement' to describe Australian policy towards Myanmar. There has been no change in Australian policy towards that country.

(6) Australia will continue to take appropriate opportunities to raise its concerns about the situation in Myanmar, and related issues such as arms sales, with the ASEAN countries, including Singapore. Our position on defence sales is clear; our message is to discourage such sales.
